PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. As background I advise the minister that over the weekend I received a letter from a university science graduate, a Brook Sumner, saying he had unsuccessfully applied for over 100 jobs in the last three and a half months with some of Australia's leading companies. He says—and I am happy to let you have the letter:

QUESTION.PARA: I have studied in an attempt to improve my employment prospects but to no avail. To then see the Prime Minister telling a group of students with very real concerns `. . . get a job', really sticks in my throat.

Minister, will you now condemn this cheap shot at students and will you accept responsibility for youth unemployment in this country running at 27 per cent, and much higher in Labor's heartland, and also for the historically high levels of unemployment and underemployment of recent university graduates?

TALK.START.PARA: —The context in which the Prime Minister made his remarks ought to be fully understood. He was not dealing with a demonstration by young unemployed or by people expressing concern about the employment situation; he was dealing with a peculiarly noisy and loud and offensive demonstration by students who were making the utterly spurious claim about the government's intention to have up-front fees for undergraduates, something that we have never believed in and never will implement. We have made that absolutely clear over and over again. The Prime Minister's remark in that context should be seen as an essentially tongue-in-cheek, ironic riposte, and one that was perfectly understandable in the circumstances of the case.

PARA.TAB: So whatever may be the situation so far as any individual is concerned—it is always impossible to comment on the employability of a particular individual without knowing the circumstances of the case—the truth of the matter is that those students demonstrating on that day are more likely to get jobs than any other single class of Australians. Under this government in the last two years the economy has created over 500,000 new jobs—in fact, 570,000 since that commitment was made—more than 720 new jobs every day. The unemployment rate of graduates is little more than half of what it is for the population as a whole, and about a third of what it is for those who did not complete secondary school.

This is not a government that believes that anyone without a job at the moment can get one at will. That is not the situation. Because we know it is not the situation, we have introduced as many programs as we have to deal with it. Why would we introduce Working Nation last year, at a cost of $6.5 million over four years, if we thought that there were sufficient jobs available for everyone who wanted them? Why would we have introduced the most radical training and employment initiatives in our history if we thought that work was available to everyone who wants it? Of course it is not; of course it should be. But we are working a hell of a lot harder than those opposite could conceivably imagine to produce that particular result.

When those opposite say that Working Nation is a waste of money, as they have done, they are making absolutely clear their own indifference to the very people they are shedding crocodile tears about in this kind of question. Of course it is the case that some young people are more vulnerable to unemployment than others. The most vulnerable are early school leavers. To address this, the government has introduced policies which have produced a quite dramatic growth in the number of students staying on at school to complete year 12. Over the last decade year 12 retention rates have doubled, to 77 per cent.

Our objective remains that, by the year 2001, 95 per cent of 19-year-olds will have completed year 12 or equivalent. In addition, as part of the Working Nation measures—those very measures upon which the opposition has poured nothing but scorn since their implementation—we have introduced the youth training initiative to address the specific needs of young people. That commenced this year on 1 January. It aims to assist unemployed kids between 15 and 17 to gain appropriate and ongoing employment by providing access to suitable education, training and work experience opportunities with, in order to achieve this, kids being assisted by case managers—managers who will help young people search for suitable work, training or education opportunities and will be able to refer clients to labour market programs.

New income support arrangements, called the youth training allowance, will provide support for young people participating in the YTI. They will also be assisted to obtain places with an increased number and range of entry level training and labour market program places available to these young people.

That is what we are doing about kids getting jobs. That is what we are doing about early school leavers, kids in that age range, and that is what we have been able to do so far as graduates are concerned and others who are more obviously satisfying the skill needs of the market at the moment. It is a very proud record indeed, and it stands in dramatic contrast to the way in which those opposite have approached this issue—all rhetoric, all puff, all inconsistent assertions about spending too much money on the wrong things—when what they are doing is doing nothing for the young kids of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question because, really, the minister, in his answer, went down the same path of seeking self-congratulations. He says, `We have a proud record.' Minister, do you call a proud record 27 per cent of young Australians who are seeking work being unable to get a job? Are the historically high levels of young graduates who cannot get a job part of your proud record? Wouldn't you do better by apologising on behalf of your Prime Minister for his cheap shot and facing up to your responsibility as the national government rather than gloating about successes that are basically false?

—I have answered that question in the way that that question is best answered: by straightforward facts and figures—not rhetoric, not huff and puff, not nonsense, not crocodile tears, not complaints, not whinges, not policy vacuums but specific policy proposals that have been addressing real problems and producing real results. You scoffed and you chortled when we talked about 500,000 new jobs over the next three years. You said it could not be done. It has been done in just on two years. There have been 570,000 new jobs created—720 new jobs every day—since that commitment was made. That is the record, and we stand by it.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives of Thailand, His Excellency Mr Bunharn Silpa-Archa. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both enjoyable and productive.

TAB.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, last December you announced a major restructuring of the statutory arrangements for the meat and livestock industry. Can you advise the Senate of the progress to date in implementing the arrangements? Has the industry responded positively to the changes that are being made?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that the industry has responded positively. As senators would be aware, the government announced last December details of new arrangements that will provide the meat and livestock industry with much greater responsibility for its own affairs, move it to a less regulated environment and reshape the statutory bodies to allow them to better address the future commercial and consumer challenges for the Australian beef industry, which of course is a multi-billion dollar industry, both domestically and particularly with exports. Australia is in fact the world's largest exporter of beef.

PARA.TAB: The legislative changes that will give effect to all of this will be introduced in parliament this week—I think on Wednesday. Central to the new arrangements is the establishment of a new representative meat industry council. The council has a clear responsibility for developing the vision and strategic directions for the meat industry and for formulating broad industry policy. The council consists of industry leaders who are nominated by industry organisations as agreed with the peak industry levy-paying bodies. That is the key to this new council: it comprises representatives of industries that are actually paying the levies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good idea.

—It is a good idea, Senator Panizza. Thank you for that commendation. In order to continue the momentum for change generated by the reform process, an interim council, chaired by Robin Bligh, has already commenced work. Geoff Jureidini, who has extensive senior management experience in the food industry with companies such as Allied Mills and Goodman Fielder, has recently been appointed as the chief executive officer for the MIC.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to report that the interim MIC is working extremely well. It has already set about tackling some of the important issues facing the industry. In particular, I wish to advise the Senate that the new MIC is addressing the difficult but crucially important area of food safety, with a view to achieving a coordinated industry approach.

The council held a workshop involving representatives of the major industry bodies, companies and federal and state governments in Sydney this month. I am very pleased with the positive and immediate response by industry to this vitally important issue. The involvement of the MIC is a clear demonstration of the industry's desire to take charge of its own affairs and not to shirk the difficult issues confronting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it not the case that the Canberra by-election is a direct rebuff of a prime minister who has ignored the concerns of mainstream Australia and that Australians are sick and tired of his arrogance, his political grandstanding while overseas, his cynical manipulation of events to suit his own view of the world and, most importantly, his insensitivity, not just to the people of Canberra but also to university students, families and older Australians—in fact, to anyone who is concerned with what is happening in Australia rather than redesigning Berlin, conducting Mahler or running the Bundesbank? Why is Tasmanian leader Michael Field not right when he says that the government is out of touch, arrogant and complacent? The Prime Minister says that he has heard the message, so why does he continue to blame everyone but himself when he is overwhelmingly the problem?

—Nobody doubts that there are a number of messages for the government in the Canberra by-election result. It would be foolish of us to say otherwise. Some of those messages are, particularly when dealing with the greenest electorate in the nation, that it is very important to get your decision making processes right and be seen to be right on an issue like woodchips. It is also the case in an electorate like this that, as so much elsewhere in the country, there is a high level of uncertainty about the economic future. It is important to be able to convey the message that not only do we have a strong growth rate at the moment but that that growth rate is sustainable and that interest rates, to the extent that they need to rise at all, will certainly not need to rise, on all our present expectations, to anything like the levels that prevailed in the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: It is necessary to get these messages across, but it is very difficult to do that before you have actually put a budget down and before the community, the electorate, has had a few months to see for itself that our confidence, our optimism, is in fact justified. That is a very relevant consideration, but what we have to take into account, learn and appreciate is the need to communicate and to understand better the immediate nature of the concerns that people in the community do have about this issue.

There were obviously some local factors that need to be taken into account in the electorate and we need to take into account the fact, of course, in weighing and balancing all this, that for better or worse, deserved or otherwise, your new leader is still, for the moment anyway, enjoying a little bit of a honeymoon, a honeymoon that is going to be a pretty tarnished old affair by the time it is over. But it will be over and I think people will see these things in better perspective.

I do not accept that the result should be personalised in the way in which you have chosen inevitably to do. I know you cannot think in policy terms. Those on the other side of this chamber, on the other side of this parliament, are not serious about policy. If you were serious about policy you would tell us what you are going to do about the situation of the economy rather than just saying what you are not going to do. If you were serious about policy you would tell us what you are going to do about media ownership. If you were serious about policy you would tell us precisely what you are going to do about all the other issues which are on the agenda at the moment and from which you want to do nothing else but duck and run and hide.

You can duck and run and hide for a few more weeks, I suppose—maybe even a few more months—but you cannot duck and run and hide forever. Sooner or later you will have to make clear to the Australian public positively what it is you stand for. When you do that, the nakedness of your policy aspirations, the nakedness of your claims to be able to better govern this country, will be starkly revealed to the whole country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the Leader of the Government in the Senate has finally acknowledged the futility of personal denigration. So let us deal with the issues. Now that the New South Wales election is safely out of the way, and the Prime Minister has acknowledged that interest rates were an issue which spooked the electorate in Canberra, will you rule out further increases in interest rates prior to the budget? When will you stop using interest rates as your only, and very blunt, instrument to try to fix the current account deficit?

—Of course we are not in the business any more now than we have ever been in the business of ruling anything in or out. We have constantly made clear that the very high priority is to keep interest rates down, to keep inflation down to keep interest rates down, and to have a fiscal strategy in place which will produce that result. But we are not in a position now, nor at any time, to make that kind of pronouncement. Senator Alston knows that perfectly well. He is talking, as usual, through the wrong orifice.
—Order! That level of language really is not appropriate, Senator Evans.
—I would request that you ask him to withdraw it.
—Order! In the interests of Senate harmony, would you withdraw that comment?
—Nostrils, ears? Which one would you like? I withdraw.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. What progress has been made in establishing a national air and space museum at Point Cook in Victoria?

—The closure and sale of the Laverton and Point Cook airfields was announced in May 1991 as part of the Defence Force Structure Review. Following that announcement, I established a consultative committee with representatives of Defence, the Victorian government and the local council to consider the future option of the two sites. The review took into account the fact that a range of non-airfield activities was to be maintained by Defence at both airfields. These included the RAAF college and the RAAF museum at Point Cook. Essentially, the outcome of the committee review was that non-aviation uses would be pursued for the Laverton airfield and that Point Cook should remain available for aviation purposes.

PARA.TAB: My predecessor had given his in-principle approval for the use of Laverton for the National Air and Space Museum of Australia, NASMA, while it remained a Defence airfield. In view of the decision to market Laverton, I agreed to consider Point Cook as a location for NASMA. Discussions to identify arrangements to permit the establishment of NASMA at Point Cook have been under way for some time between Defence and NASMA officials. In part, those discussions have focused on the need to protect Defence's interest in maintaining the value of its historical asset and in preserving the viability of the RAAF museum. At the same time, I understand that NASMA has been finetuning its structure and its business planning.

As a result of these activities, I am now in a position to announce that I have given in-principle approval to the establishment of NASMA at Point Cook. The proposed agreement between Defence and NASMA has two principal components. One covers the display and storage facilities on the northern tarmac area, which will operate under a 50-year lease. The second relates to NASMA assuming responsibility for the management of the airfield operations at Point Cook on a revenue sharing basis.

The outcome has been possible because of the cooperative arrangements that have developed between the RAAF museum and NASMA. These will involve the sharing of some facilities and the development by NASMA of display areas. Construction work is scheduled to begin later this year, and the opening of NASMA is planned for late 1996. The benefit that this brings to Defence will be recognised through the offsetting of NASMA's rental obligations. A feature of the agreement will be that it maintains a viable operating airfield to complement NASMA's museum display activities.

The opportunity will be afforded to NASMA to operate on a commercial basis. As soon as a formal agreement is in place, Point Cook will be available for airfield operations. Subject to satisfactory resolution of the various issues between officials, this proposal has the potential to offer the public a first-class Australian aviation museum which will reside appropriately at the original home of the Royal Australian Air Force at Point Cook. I add that this will create employment opportunities in the western suburbs of Melbourne. It is a win-win situation for everyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer the minister to the huge cuts to hospital budgets in South Australia, cuts that will result in substantial increases in waiting lists and increasing stress on staff. I ask the minister three questions. Firstly, when will the federal government act to remove the incentives for states to cost shift—in particular, by using case mix funding as a mechanism, or excuse, for cost shifting? Secondly, when will the federal government pay the states the money due to them under the Medicare agreement as a result of the number of people dropping out of private health insurance? Thirdly, when will the federal government acknowledge that it must put more money not only into the public hospital system but also into community health services in order to reduce the demand on the public hospital system?
—A good question.

—I am glad that an opposition senator has said it is a good question. I am about to tell the Senate exactly what I said about New South Wales. I will answer Senator Lees's question by giving her the facts about the figures from South Australia, including state funding and Commonwealth funding. In 1991-92, the state figures were $423,517,000. In 1992, that figure fell to $404 million. In 1993, it fell to $334 million.
—Would you like these?

—I could put glasses on; I thank those smart senators opposite. This means a real percentage drop of over five per cent in the first year and a massive 18 plus per cent drop in the last year. That is what the Liberal government in South Australia has done in health expenditure to the state. It makes very important reading.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, Commonwealth funding has increased from $363 million to $384 million to $476 million. I will give Senator Lees those figures exactly later. They show a direct and significant increase in Commonwealth funding to the states and a dramatic 18 per cent decrease in state funding to hospitals in the last 12 months. So it is a very good and telling question.

What is happening in South Australia is exactly the same as is happening in New South Wales. The states are shifting the money out of the hospital system and then blaming the Commonwealth. The record is that Commonwealth money is increasing and that state money is decreasing. Senator Lees's question is a very important one. While the Commonwealth continues to make a direct and real increase in its funding and is honouring its Medicare agreements, the states are pulling out of the funding. As Senator Lees has alluded to, at the same time they are using the introduction of case mix as an excuse to justify this dramatic cut.

Further, Senator Lees asked about cost shifting. The Commonwealth is very concerned about it. Since the inquiry has been under way and the review, which was triggered by the two per cent change in figures, has been conducted, there has already been a review and an interim report on the Commonwealth-state agreements. The Health Insurance Commission has been requested to investigate any reported instances of services being billed to the Commonwealth which should properly be paid for by the states. In some cases, this activity may be fraudulent or illegal as well as contrary to the Medicare agreement.

The minister has written to professional organisations and the state ministers setting out her objection to contrived cost shifting. It is pleasing to note that, on the figures to this point, there seems to have been a reduction in cost shifting by the states to the Commonwealth while that review was under way. One thing that review has shown is these figures: that Commonwealth money is increasing and that state money is decreasing. The state government in South Australia, not the Commonwealth, is responsible for the dramatic increase in waiting lists at the Flinders Medical Centre and the Adelaide hospital. The state government has to answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you don't give them enough money.

—It is decreased money in real terms. If it is not enough, why on earth is it cutting its own funding? It is a nonsense argument to be saying that there is an increase in waiting lists while it is cutting its own funding. What is the logic of the South Australian government cutting its funding to hospitals and then complaining about large waiting lists? If it is serious, it would keep its commitment along with the Commonwealth. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. She has ignored several parts of the question. The figures given are quite misleading. A look at the total amount of money spent on health in South Australia, particularly on hospitals, since 1983 and the percentage that the Commonwealth is contributing shows that it has declined. The state has made some very substantial cuts, particularly to the Flinders Medical Centre, where 20 per cent of its surgery has basically been cancelled for three years. When is the money due under the Medicare agreement—forget about the reviews; we are talking about the money—to be handed over to the states? When will the minister do something about the cost shifting? It is fine to say that she is running another review about it. But there is not just the cost shifting to the federal government; there is also the cost shifting to the consumers—the patients—and their families. Is the federal government going to act, or is it just going to keep blaming the states?

—That is a bit heroic, Senator Lees, and flies in the face of the figures I have just given which have emerged from the review. That review was conducted as a consequence of the decline of two per cent in the number of people who are privately insured and the concern that this was going to push more people onto the state hospital system.

PARA.TAB: The data that has come out of that review makes quite clear what I have already said and confirms the figures provided to me that the Commonwealth is increasing its funding. If that money is not getting through to the states, I will certainly follow that up and see whether there is anything further I can offer you on that. There has been a large amount of cost shifting by the hospitals onto the Commonwealth, particularly in relation to pharmaceuticals in the outpatients area. The largest complaint is with our state governments misusing and cutting back dramatically their funds under the screen of the Commonwealth's responsibility and also under the protection of the increased Commonwealth money. In relation to the community, we have a number of initiatives in place to try to assist, particularly HACC increases. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister representing the Minister for Justice. With regard to the wide coverage that the Aum Shinri Kyo sect has had since the appalling nerve gas bombing of the Tokyo subway last week, will the minister confirm, firstly, that it was members of this sect, including one of its leaders, that visited Australia in September 1993;, secondly, that they did breach visa conditions while in Australia which led to them being refused further visas to come to Australia; and, thirdly, that that is why they subsequently sold the Banjawarn station in Western Australia? What is the status of Australian Federal Police investigations into the sect's activities in Australia and, in particular, what is the chemical in the drums that were reportedly found at the station last week?

—I will answer the second part of the question first. The Minister for Justice has told me that routine follow-up inquires are being conducted following the incident in Japan. As a consequence, AFP members have attended the sheep station. They have returned to Perth after inspecting the property and locating a quantity of chemicals. The chemicals have been removed to a laboratory and are currently being tested to confirm their content. At this time, it appears that the chemicals are associated with the processing of minerals and are consistent with those which the sect members attempted to bring into the country some 18 months ago. I cannot say any more with respect to any ongoing investigation or assessment.

PARA.TAB: In relation to your question about whether these people entered Australia, I am told that a group of members of the cult, led by Mr Chizuo Matsumoto, visited Australia in September 1993. They were brought to the attention of Customs and immigration officers on arrival at Perth because of the behaviour of some members. I think you raised this question in here some time ago. The group was found by Customs to be carrying mining equipment. Two members were later charged with carrying dangerous goods and each fined $2,400 and ordered to pay court costs.

I am told that, at that time, a request for advice was made to the entry operation centre in Perth. That centre advised that they should be counselled on the conditions of their visas and allowed to enter. At that particular time there was no clear basis to cancel the visas on immigration grounds.

My further advice is that a number of group members have applied for visitor visas in Japan since their visit in September 1993 and all have had their visas refused on the grounds that they do not meet the requirements of the Migration Act and regulations. Once the background of the group became known, all subsequent visa applications were refused. I point out that the department is not in a position to deny granting a visa unless it does have credible adverse information on hand prior to the grant.

I can say with respect to the members that four have applied three times for visas and have been refused three times. One has applied once and has been refused once. Their representatives in Perth wrote to me in May 1994 requesting intervention. My senior adviser wrote back in June 1994 saying that I would not get involved and that, in fact, I had no power to intervene in the case, nor would I. I do not think at this stage that I can add much more. I am sure you will have a supplementary question and I suspect I will have to take it on notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to my question to the minister on 27 September 1993, the minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: As to federal intervention, apart from the answer I have given today, I do not know what Senator Chamarette is talking about. So I think her follow-up question probably does not go to any relevant point. I will have it checked to see whether there is anything in it.
What follow-up did the minister make to the matter that I raised in my question and, if there was anything of substance, why did the minister not make those findings public at the time?

TALK.START.PARA: —Follow-up is automatic and was made between my office and the department as a consequence of Senator Chamarette's question. I can get some information on whether or not that question led to any further investigations by the department. What I do know is that publicity given at the time and investigations taken pursuant to these people being stopped and checked on entry led to any future application by them for visas being stopped.

PARA.TAB: I am also informed that these people were placed on alert lists within Tokyo very soon after the incident, and they were placed on local warning lists at the post in Japan. That is an extra measure to ensure that, when people in these circumstances apply for visas, early steps can be taken to ensure that the visa application is refused. If there is any further information I can add this time, I will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the conference on climate change which is already under way in Berlin. The government has indicated that it is essential that the main developing countries become part of any new greenhouse protocol. What is the minister's assessment of the current attitude of the main developing countries towards joining any new greenhouse protocol? Further, could the minister detail what, if any, initiatives the government proposes to take to effectively encourage the developing countries to take a positive approach to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions?

—As Senator Kemp knows, the first conference of the parties is being held between 28 March and 7 April. This meeting has a very substantial agenda. There is no doubt that many issues will need to be addressed in order to pave the way for further implementing and developing the framework convention on climate change.

PARA.TAB: Australia's approach to the negotiations at the Berlin meeting will be governed by our need to protect and defend our environmental, trade, economic and foreign policy interests. That will include our commitments to global action and also to Pacific island countries, which are vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. Our negotiating position for the framework convention has been finalised by the government. The delegation that will be going to Berlin is drawn from a range of government departments. It will include representatives of state governments, industry, business groups, environment organisations and the ACTU.

I am confident that the consultations that have been held amongst those groups and the careful consideration that the government has given to its negotiating objectives will result in us being very well prepared to protect and advance Australia's interests at the first conference of the parties. There is a strong consensus among many countries that the commitments in the climate change convention are inadequate and that they will not meet the convention's objective. That is a view that is shared by the government, and we want to see a strengthening in the commitments of the convention.

Australia will not be blocking any progress in Berlin, as might have been suggested by some media commentators. There is no change in relation to Australia's position on what I believe is a very fundamental point indeed. At Berlin we will be supporting the agreed set up negotiations on a protocol to build on the commitments in the convention based on the convention's principle, including comprehensive approach and equitable burden sharing.

There will be a difficult and complex negotiating task in Berlin. We will be seeking to protect and promote all our interests and we remain committed to global action on climate change. Specifically in relation to the issue of developing countries, we recognise that climate change is a global problem. We agree that it is important that developed countries whose economic progress has been a significant cause of the problem of increased levels of greenhouse gas emissions need to play a key and leadership role in the global response.

I do not think we can ignore the fact that by early next century emissions from developing countries will outstrip the emissions from developed countries. That is the nature of the complexity of the issues that we face. Our response to this particular problem—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. My question is set against the background of suggestions that last week's horrific Tokyo subway chemical weapons attack could herald a new wave of international chemical weapons terrorism. Given the apparent ready availability of materials which can be used to manufacture chemical weapons, such as the extremely toxic nerve agent sarin, can the leader advise the Senate how effective the chemical weapons convention is likely to be in combating terrorist use of this type of material? In addition, when is the chemical weapons convention likely to enter into force?

—Needless to say, the Australian government was appalled, as I am sure all honourable senators were, by the attack in Tokyo and condemns it in the strongest possible terms. We do express our deepest condolences to the victims of this mindless act of terror and indeed the Japanese government, which has had to deal with the problem.

PARA.TAB: While the sense of public outrage is entirely appropriate, I think it is fair to say that there is no real evidence to suppose that this incident does herald a new era of terrorism characterised by the use of chemical weapons. It is true that the technology and materials to produce some chemical weapons, such as sarin, are theoretically available to those with appropriate qualifications in chemistry and access to commercial chemicals. But the nature of these weapons is such that, at least in the homemade form, they are likely to be difficult to manage, unpredictable, indiscriminate and extraordinarily dangerous to those who would seek to employ them.

Among the measures which states can take to minimise the risk of CW use by terrorists is to bring about the speedy entry into force of the chemical weapons convention, which bans the development, production, acquisition, stockpiling, retention, transfer and use of chemical weapons and does put in place a comprehensive verification regime to ensure compliance. Of course, the CWC's verification regime is aimed at states and is primarily designed to detect and deter military related chemical weapons activity. The use of these weapons in war, as during the Iran-Iraq conflict, remains the greatest threat associated with CW. For example, the worrying reports of Iran stockpiling CW in the Straits of Hormuz is exactly the sort of issue the CWC was designed to deal with. But the global banning and destruction of CW will also reduce the chance of their falling into the hands of terrorist groups.

Equally importantly, the strict controls which the convention will put in place will make the illicit procurement of the necessary chemical weapons precursors, particularly from international sources, that much more difficult. Article VII of the convention requires states to implement measures to prevent production of CW in any place in their jurisdiction. Thus the convention does oblige governments to take steps to ensure that individuals or groups of individuals do not make, keep or use CW within their territories.

I think we are already seeing, in states' implementation of the legislation pursuant to this treaty, that states are concentrating their minds on the need to fill various legislative and regulatory vacuums that did previously exist before the convention. Australia's implementing legislation, the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act, which we passed last year, for example, as well as expressly prohibiting production or use of chemical weapons, will establish a system of permits and notifications allowing monitoring and control of production, possession or use of a range of chemicals which are useable either as chemical weapons or as precursors to their production. These certainly include sarin and precursors for its manufacture. The maximum penalty prescribed by the act for serious breaches is, in fact, life imprisonment, so you are talking about a very serious set of legislative sanctions.

As to your last question, 159 states have signed the convention, and 27 states, including Australia, have so far ratified the convention. Current indications are that the trigger for entry into force—that is, the deposit of the 65th instrument of ratification—will occur sometime towards the end of this year. Entry into force will then occur automatically 180 days later.

The impact of the Tokyo attack on this legislative and ratification activity has already been shown in the steps taken by the Japanese government itself, for example, to accelerate its ratification of the CWC and to pass necessary legislation through the Diet as early as next week. That is something we very warmly welcome.

I should just finally add by way of a footnote that our commitment to preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including chemical weapons, is further underlined by the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill, which is currently before the parliament, and that will strengthen our control over involvement by Australians in producing weapons of mass destruction anywhere in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Minister, what is the cost to the government of the better cities seminar being conducted in Parliament House today and tomorrow, which the Minister for Housing and Regional Development is sponsoring? What invitations were issued to parliamentarians to attend? Why is it that, of the 45 participants included in the agenda, no less than nine are Labor Party politicians, one is a Labor Party mayor and at least one is a Labor Party candidate, yet there are no representatives of any other political party? Why is it that, apart from a minor role for two officers from the New South Wales and Western Australian planning departments, no state government, other than the Queensland government, appears to be involved? Why is it that no state ministers will be speaking, in spite of the fact that the better cities program is supposed to be a joint Commonwealth-state initiative?

—Let me say that the better cities program is, in fact, a program funded by the federal government at the initiative of the federal government, and one for which we have received some criticism from the opposition. It was very much on the priority of its Fightback hit list just before the last election. So for the opposition to come in here now and claim ownership of it, Senator Macdonald, I think requires a great degree of gall.

PARA.TAB: I am informed that the seminar and exhibition will be attended by practitioners, academics and other interested people from around the country. There is a highly respected list of speakers, and presentations from the 26 area strategies provide a welcome opportunity for the unique success of the better cities program to be described by those most responsible for its implementation. I am informed that the majority of the speakers and invited participants have come at their own expense, demonstrating the enthusiasm for the achievements of the program.

My further advice is that the activities planned for the two-day seminar and exhibition include the launch of the better cities national status report 1995 and the coordination of activities between the better cities managers, which would have taken place anyway. The national status report is a public document and it lists these achievements and the current issues that must be addressed in the final stages of the better cities program.

I am informed that the people who implement the better cities program on the ground come from a variety of state departments, local government organisations, development corporations, statutory authorities and the private sector. Let me state that this particular program is not by the Labor Party for the Labor Party: it is an initiative of the Australian government which has a great degree of support on the ground.

Only a few days ago, I was in Adelaide with the Prime Minister and the Premier of South Australia. Much of the better cities program in that state is recognised not just by those representing the federal government, but also by those representing industry, the private sector and the state government. What the better cities program is all about is building up the infrastructure in regions in places like South Australia and elsewhere to ensure a more productive and efficient use of our resources and provide a more efficient base for industry. Senator Macdonald, in his normal way, asked some nitpicking questions in respect of speakers. I will take those on notice, as I will his next bombast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, that was all very interesting but it had nothing to do with the questions that I asked. The questions I asked were: why is it that nine of the 45 participants are serving Labor Party politicians, one is a very high profile Labor Party mayor and at least one of the other speakers is the Labor candidate for Jagajaga, which is Senator Gareth Evans's old seat? Why is that the case? Why weren't any politicians from other political parties invited to it, or is it just another Commonwealth funded Labor Party campaigning exercise?

—I will make two obvious points. Nine out of 45 is about 20 per cent. I do not know where the other 36 come from. Until I look at the list, I am in no position to respond to your question in a balanced way. Nine out of 45 is in fact 20 per cent. That is a very low proportion. I do not know who else has been invited. I do not know the background of the other speakers or representatives of local government. I will take that on board. In respect of Jenny Macklin, the candidate for Jagajaga—
—An excellent candidate.

—She is an excellent candidate, Senator Carr. Why is she an excellent candidate? Why is she a person who would be appropriate to speak at this particular venue? Because she has been involved for a long time with the federal government as a policy adviser to departments, to ministers, in respect of this particular program. It is very much part of her policy work that has led to the development by the federal government of policies for the regions. She is a very good and very credible candidate. You may not recognise her, but she is recognised in the field as someone who is in command of policy research and who does a good job of it. That is why she is speaking. (Time expired)

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the minister of his claim that the Prime Minister's `get a job' remark was tongue in cheek. Why is the Prime Minister able to indulge in such remarks but not able to respond courteously and usefully to criticism and real concerns expressed by working students about real costs, real charges and real fees which universities have asked them to pay? Will the Prime Minister acknowledge that his remark was an insensitive insult and a slur on students, particularly the 80 per cent of Austudy recipients who have had to find employment to be able to continue their tertiary studies? What job offers has the Prime Minister made to tertiary students who may need a job to pay the fees that his government is permitting universities to charge? When will the Prime Minister apologise to the students concerned?

—The Austudy program is one that has been overwhelmingly successful in enabling students to undertake full-time study. Almost 500,000 students receive it. For between 10 and 25 per cent of these students, it is estimated that Austudy has meant the difference between staying or not staying at school. Although it is the case that family income testing arrangements have been modified recently to better target assistance to those in need, it is also the case that academic requirements have been relaxed, providing greater access to assistance by students.

PARA.TAB: As to the income test and the issues that you are most specifically concerned with, it is the case that Austudy has a generous student income test. Full-time, full-year students are permitted to earn, as you would be aware, up to $6,000 in a financial year with no reduction at all in their Austudy entitlement, although any earnings above that amount does reduce your benefits by $1 for every $2 earned. This income test has been criticised as being more generous than the one for jobsearch allowance and newstart allowance, which allows earnings of only $1,560 a year or $60 a fortnight.

It is not unusual for students to undertake employment in vacation periods to obtain additional finances to support their study. I do not think one ought to overstate the notion of people having to go to work in order to sustain themselves. That was part of my student experience and I suspect that of many other people in this place at the time that we went through—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were sponsored by Slater and Gordon.
—Would that I had been; I wasn't. Just memories. At least I got a buck from somewhere, Senator Alston. I do not think anyone was too keen to employ you during your student days.

PARA.TAB: I think I have already made the point about the $6,000 worth of extra income they can in fact get, and I think the concern that has been expressed about this is to some extent misplaced. Obviously, as with all these things, we would like to be more generous. It is undoubtedly the case that some students could do very well with extra assistance on these fronts. But we have to balance that against the massive costs to budget that are involved in a time of tight budgetary discipline which is being urged upon us by all and sundry. We think, under those circumstances, the balance that has been struck between these different aims, criteria and amounts is really the best that anyone could do in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Really, Minister, that answer was avoiding the issue; it was not paying any attention to the insult. The real question I was asking was: how is it that the Prime Minister is able to make such gratuitous insults and not even address the concept of an apology, which you have not addressed in your answer either?

—It needs to be appreciated that the particular demonstration the Prime Minister was dealing with was based on a totally false premise. Everyone was getting very excited, including my own kids who told me they were out there demonstrating. I asked them what they were demonstrating about, and got the same false premise thrown back at me that the government was about to introduce up-front fees for undergraduates. That is the basis on which the demonstration was mounted, and that is not our policy although it has been yours on the opposition side—and why you are so noisy about this I cannot imagine.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that that is the context in which the Prime Minister was responding to people who were getting stuck into him on a basis that had absolutely no foundation whatsoever. It was a political occasion, a political exercise. He was responding politically, tongue in cheek, essentially ironic, as I said, and I do not think you ought to get too excited about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of genuine concerns being expressed by the grain industry about the disease risk with imported grain. Minister, is it true, as has been claimed, that pathogens—that is, disease-causing bacterial viruses—are so widespread in some states of the United States of America that grain from those states can only be used for stockfeed? I ask: can the minister explain why all imported grain should not be steam treated to eliminate any risk before going out into country areas, as the cost of about $10 per tonne is small indeed compared with the risk, which is a very real risk?

—The most scrupulous exercise has been engaged upon in respect of this difficult issue, and that exercise is continuing. The manual that is in the process of being prepared for protocols on the importation of grain is not yet concluded. In fact, several hours of my time last Friday were consumed in finalising the arrangements for that manual.

PARA.TAB: It is a difficult issue. We are having to import grain into Australia in unprecedented quantities not simply because of the drought but also because of the major structural change that has occurred in Australia's primary industries over the last 10 years. To give a simple benchmark, just taking beef cattle alone: in Australia in the early 1980s we were feedlotting somewhere around 100,000 head of cattle; in just 10 years, that figure has gone from 100,000 to close to 800,000. That just indicates the growth of that industry and the way in which the grain industry of Australia has grown with it.

Of course, there has been a similar increase in the intensive feeding activities of the pork industry, for example, and also the chicken industry. All of these industries employ thousands of Australians in permanent jobs, they are extremely important industries for Australia, and they have to be sustained not just to support those jobs but also to support the export performance that those industries have achieved over the last 10 years.

All of those issues were thrashed out at a major meeting of all of the parties which was chaired at my request by Don McGauchie, the President of the National Farmers Federation. I attended that meeting. All of the people representing the major peak bodies, in terms of the grain industry, the lot feeders and the chicken industry, were there. It was acknowledged, even by people who are concerned about the importation of grain, that it was not in Australia's interests to have export orders lost to Australia—with the great difficulty of then winning them back from some of the processors—by having a shortfall in the grain which is essential to the continued health of those industries. So it is not an easy question to resolve; it is an extremely difficult one.

It is also fair to say that the requirements that have been placed on grain are scrupulous. To get to one of the central elements of Senator Crane's question, which is problems in particular states in the United States, the protocols do not just involve what happens to the grain when it arrives in Australia; they go all the way back to the source. AQIS has rejected a number of applications for the importation of grain where it was thought that the problems associated with grain in those particular places in the United States were too great to be contemplated. That is why the grain has been sourced from states such as Kansas and Nebraska—that is, the central western states of the United States—where it is considered that those problems pose a very low risk. Of course, that is then augmented by the need to treat the grain for pests prior to it leaving the United States and then by the scrupulous procedures that are now in place in Australia once it arrives.

But it needs to be acknowledged, as I have said, that this is a new thing for Australia. With the exception of the importation of, I think, around 10,000 tonnes of durum wheat a few years ago for the pasta industry, there has been no history ever of Australia importing levels of grain to this quantity. I can assure Senator Crane and indeed the Senate that this exercise will be conducted in the most scrupulous fashion and that the final manual that will contain the protocols for the importation of grain, which hopefully will be a lesser need rather than a greater need over the remainder of this year, has not yet been concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that answer there was one particular element that the minister did not answer. Minister, a couple of weeks ago you showed me a book relating to rabbits and the damage they have done. Similarly we have been concerned about green aphids coming into this country and the damage they have done. Can you explain why, in terms of the fact that grain can be steam cleaned, you did not answer that part of my question and why this is not being put in place, because it would ensure that, at a very low cost with regard to the risk, no diseases would get in here?

—Apart from anything else, it is because some of the uses to which the grain has to be put are destroyed by heat treatment of the grain. In most cases that kind of treatment is okay, but there are some particular requirements in particular processed food industries—
—Like what?

—If you do not know, Senator, you should. As a primary producer yourself, you should know. There is semolina for starters. The kinds of products that are produced from specialist wheat, such as durum wheat, are not assisted by those processes and there are particular requirements for pet food industries that are also not assisted.
—How much is imported?

—If you do not know, Senator Crane, you should know, frankly. I am happy to organise a briefing for you and you can be told a few things that you should know anyway. As I have said before, the key issue is that the grain industry of Australia is going to be protected. At the same time, major Australian industries that use grain and employ thousands of Australians cannot be seen to suffer. They have legitimate needs that also have to be supplied. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. The minister will recall that, when he released the Conroy review of the Australian Customs Service in February last year, he stated that he embraced the broad themes of the report which included the need for Customs to establish closer links with industry. I noticed an AAP report last week claiming that Customs was to `trade its baseball bat for a smile' in its dealings with industry. I ask: what are the specific steps the minister and Customs have taken to implement this industry friendly approach that would elicit such a description?

—The report released last year following the Conroy review attracted considerable interest from those opposite. That review is now the subject of a permanent reference to the Economics Legislation Committee of the Senate, which is to receive regular reports on the implementation of that review. The other day I went to a private meeting of that committee with officers of my department. There was a very useful and fruitful discussion with members of the Senate on the progress made in the last 12 months.

PARA.TAB: What we are talking about here today in response to Senator Murphy's question is the release last week of a report called Looking to the future, which was a review of the industry audit processes within Customs. This is what I would consider one of the first major steps forward in setting a new priority for Customs' relations with industry in this country. When we established the industry advisory board for Customs to get closer advice from industry about the way it should be run and its relations with industry, the first thing it advised me to do was to establish some industry panels to look at specific areas.

One of these panels was established to look at industry audit. It was chaired by the chief executive officer of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, Ian Grigg, with a majority of industry representatives. It presented a report to me which was released last week called Looking to the future. It is a major report on changing the way Customs will deal with industry. In auditing the processes of industry and in meeting its compliance arrangements, there will now be a theme of self-assessment based on proper risk assessment. This self-assessment will mean that industry will assess what it should pay and the processes of what it should pay, rather than having every transaction checked or attempted to be checked by Customs irrespective of the size. This is a major change and led to the phrase `trading the baseball bat for a smile'. Both industry and Customs will very much welcome this arrangement.

Also, the industry panel recommended that we have a one stop shop approach for contact between industry and Customs. Up till now a company having a dealing with Customs may have had to go to three or four different sections of Customs to deal with all its arrangements. We want that to change to a one stop shop approach—one contact with one officer for all the arrangements for Customs. This will be part of Customs' new commercial advisory service.

It was also recommended by the industry panel that the officers in this new process should be appropriately trained and accredited with training. This will be another major change in the way Customs prepares its officers for this new culture of being closer to industry. In particular, the training process will be one in which there will be a proper accreditation in externally evaluated training courses so that the Customs audit officers receive the appropriate training.

This is a genuine micro-economic reform that Customs has performed for Australian industry. It will reduce the cost of compliance for industry. An issue that industry has raised consistently has been the cost of compliance with government regulations. The whole process and report of the industry panel is about reducing the cost of compliance on the basis of self-assessment. Customs accepts the fact that 99.9 per cent of industry in complying with customs regulations is honest, and will be willing participate in this new system. It is a major step forward. I look forward to give further reports to the Senate in the near future on similar matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—by leave—Given the reports in today's media, I thought it appropriate that I should make a brief statement in parliament this afternoon. It is my intention on 19 May next to retire from politics and to resign my seat in the Senate. My decision is motivated primarily by a determination to pursue a second career in the law by accepting an offer to become a director of the international and trade law division of the Sydney firm Dunhill Madden and Butler. The establishment of a new office represents a very real challenge to me personally. The offer that was made to me is substantial in its dimensions, from a firm that is accomplished in a number of areas.

PARA.TAB: The timing of the announcement is made very deliberately: after the New South Wales general election campaign. This announcement could not have been made prior to the poll on Saturday. I think we have had more than enough federal intrusions. I underline that I spoke with both the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) last week to tell them of my decision. I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the end of last week outlining my reasons for retiring from politics.

It is my intention to leave politics for the law to pursue a second career which offers both the potential to make a contribution on international issues which are of real consequence to this country and of real interest to me personally and to re-establish a family life where separation in different cities becomes a feature of the past. Essentially, a decision of this nature is better made at age 42 than at age 49.

When I canvassed opinion within political and industrial circles of the New South Wales ALP over the summer, it became clear that endorsement for another term in the Senate was secure if I sought it. This caused me to think very seriously about my future and that of my wife, Lynne, and my family. In particular, my sons, Nicholas and James, are entitled to more consideration than I have been able to afford them in the past.

Quite frankly, after 18 years in political and public office, having arrived in the New South Wales ALP structure at age 24, it is time to make a decision for a departure. I must say I was very gratified by the indications of firm support from a number of old friends and my peers generally, especially given the problems associated with Centenary House in Sydney, which has caused my party such great difficulty and me such personal pain.

Given all this, it is time to depart soon, well before the general election, to give my party plenty of opportunity to make a deliberate choice about a successor and to give that man or woman plenty of time to establish himself or herself well prior to 1996. It also enables me to complete the task of leading the parliamentary consultative delegation to Vietnam for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) which I regard as an issue of very real importance. Beyond that, it enables me to ensure that my staff are placed in secure employment and all my undertakings as a senator are honoured. It is my intention in this regard not to leave anything undone.

I trust that indicating my intention to retire will be accepted for what it is: a display of good faith. I hope that at an appropriate time closer to 19 May there may be an opportunity for some observations. I thank the Senate for extending me this courtesy this afternoon.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a very short statement in response to that.
—What if everyone wants to get up and say something?
—There will be another opportunity, obviously, to acknowledge Senator Loosley's—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

—I would like to say two or three sentences—that is all. Grace, gentlemen and ladies—grace. It is the sort of courtesy we would reflexively extend to those opposite. If they do not want to give leave, that is fine.
—I understand leave is being granted.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply wanted to say this: there is bound to be another opportunity before Senator Loosley departs this place to properly acknowledge his contribution, but I want to say for the record right now that I find it a matter of great disappointment that Senator Loosley should be leaving us. He has, I think, been an outstanding member of this Senate and a particularly outstanding Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Certainly in that capacity he has been a very strong support for me on I think very much a bipartisan basis, and that has been acknowledged throughout the parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is understandable that Senator Loosley should have made the decision he did for the reasons that he has articulated. I appreciate him doing so in a way that gives ample notice to us all of the time frame involved. I think it has been a decision both made in good faith and announced in good faith, and it ought to be accepted as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to a seminar taking place in Parliament House today as part of the better cities program.

SPEECH.PARA: While Senator Bolkus spoke a lot about the better cities program—I mention that just briefly—my question really related to this parliament and taxpayers' money being used once again to promote Labor Party politicians and candidates. One of the things that the Canberra voters said in the by-election on Saturday was that they were sick of the arrogance of Mr Keating and of this government. It is an arrogance which has continued with today's seminar, where all of the nine Labor party parliamentarians—none of them very distinguished, I might say; there is Barry Jones, Mark Latham, Jenny Macklin, who is the candidate, Paul Elliott, Lindsay Tanner, Martyn Evans, Maggie Deahm, Jim Soorley, the Mayor of Brisbane, Silvia Smith, who is struggling to maintain her place—

TALK.START.PARA: —All stars!

—Yes, all real stars. I realise when I read their names that I do not know most of them. There is also Gavan O'Connor and the Deputy Prime Minister, Brian Howe. He is really on his way out—about to be given the shove as Deputy Prime Minister. All of these people are given some platform amongst a very distinguished group of other participants to try to do something for the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: This insensitivity is similar to the way the ALP simply appointed all its running mates and fellow travellers to the board of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It is similar to the way Senator Bolkus has appointed his wedding party to the Immigration Review Tribunal. The global diversity conference in Sydney in a couple of weeks time is just stacked with Labor Party ministers and parliamentarians. There is very little input from the coalition, except for my colleague Senator Short. I suppose only one of Senator Short's calibre is needed to compete with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and all the other ministers who will be there.

At the Bureau of Immigration Research conference a couple of weeks back, six of the distinguished speakers were disinvited because Minister Bolkus did not like their politics. He tried to get rid of 20 and ended up getting rid of six. He disinvited them. They had been invited and he had the invitations withdrawn. This all demonstrates the same sort of thing. It is all done for the mates and at taxpayers' expense. It is all done to try to give the Labor Party some additional kick along at taxpayers' expense.

The conference is about better cities. Senator Bolkus told us what a good program it is. If it is so good, why did the member for Herbert, Mr Ted Lindsay, question better cities expenditure in Townsville? Mr Lindsay accused the Labor council in Townsville of using the money from better cities to do water and sewerage works, which is the normal prerogative and the normal responsibility of local government. Those are the sorts of things that should be done with local government funds, not with special Commonwealth allocations. That is the type of work that local authorities should be funding. All other local authorities have to pay for those things, yet the Townsville Labor council, according to Mr Lindsay, seems to be getting a bit of a kick along in spending better cities program moneys improperly.

There certainly is a need for funding urban infrastructure. We have recognised that in the linking Australia program, which the coalition has announced, but this urban infrastructure program is one that needs to be effected sensibly, where the need is greatest. It should not be done in a politically motivated way as the principal expenditure in this better cities program has been.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not looked at the detail of the program Senator Ian Macdonald has raised in his question to Senator Bolkus this afternoon, but I did listen carefully to Senator Bolkus's argument. I have some problems in associating the remarks made now by Senator Macdonald with what Senator Bolkus put on the record earlier in question time. I need to have another look at what the minister said to see whether any misrepresentation of his words has been made by Senator Macdonald and whether that needs to be corrected at another time.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to comment on another matter that Senator Ian Macdonald has raised. This also received currency in the media some time ago. It relates to the matter of the disinvitees to the Bureau of Immigration Research conference on multiculturalism and population in Adelaide last month. I am not going to deny that certain individuals on the preliminary speakers list who it was suggested might be invited were then not invited at a later time.

The inference in that is that all of the people who were disinvited were replaced by Labor mates or by people who were friendly to the government, friendly to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs or friendly to the individual views of Senator Bolkus. Nothing could be further from the truth. Obviously, Senator Macdonald did not read or examine any of the media that came out of that conference. His colleague Senator Short was on the agenda about six times and spoke on numerous occasions, but there was not a great deal of reporting of his comments. From my perspective the major result of the outlook conference—and I was an attendee and a speaker at the conference—was those comments attributed to Professor Helen Hughes.

As I understand it, Professor Hughes was not on the original list of speakers, but she was on the amended list. Certainly, the views that she put forward at the conference could not be said to be, by any stretch of the imagination, complimentary to government in any shape or form. I was at Mary and Nick's wedding and, to the best of my knowledge, I cannot recall seeing Professor Helen Hughes there. I am pretty certain she was not. Perhaps I can examine the group photograph.

My reason for rising is to try to get some honesty into this debate. That is hard. People get up in the parliament time and time again putting emphasis on areas on which there should be no emphasis and misrepresenting other areas, which I think is what happened here today with the motion to take note of the minister's answer. I hope that the people who read Senator Macdonald's comments, before they start using them and putting them into history, will check the facts of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to comment on this matter. I share Senator Macdonald's concerns about the sensitivity of the way in which the government is handling the seminar that is taking place in Parliament House today and tomorrow called Better Cities: Urban Change in Action. I am of the opinion that no-one from the opposition has received an invitation to participate in this important conference. If you look at the agenda of the various sessions, as Senator Macdonald has pointed out, there are some 40-odd people participating and presenting papers. The only politicians that are doing so are those of the Labor Party flavour and colour. Many of them are introducing some pretty provocative statements.

PARA.TAB: Take a look at the listing of the National President of the Australian Labor Party, Barry Jones. He is speaking on `Cities, the information economy and telecommunications'. Tricia Castwell, from the Australian Conservation Foundation, is speaking on `Achievable aspects of change in the environment'. Ms Jenny Macklin, the endorsed Labor candidate for Jagajaga, is speaking on a major transport paper. Various sessions are being hosted by other backbench MPs. The Labor Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Mr Soorley, is speaking on `The changing nature of our capital cities'. There is certainly no balance on that agenda or in any of that discussion and that seriously concerns me.

Similarly, I have concerns about a number of very important questions raised by Senator Macdonald and me in the Senate estimates, both at the original hearings and at the supplementary hearings, relating to housing and urban development matters. It took weeks and weeks for answers to be provided. I think it was a list of some 68 questions that we placed at those supplementary hearings. The answers were delivered to our offices very late last Friday. It is still interesting to look through the list at the questions which have not yet been answered. Yet they are the very points that are now being addressed in this major conference today with this whopping great display all through the Great Hall. All of the areas are a set-up.

For example, questions by me noted on this schedule to the estimates committee relate to statistics documents provided at the hearings. A further question relates to the detail of funding and research for housing research funds. There is a question relating to the urban design task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and what period a person on either Mr Keating's staff or the staff of the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe), Mr Campbell, worked for the task force.

There is a question relating to information on the relationship between the review teams and the advisory groups. I asked a question relating to the involvement of Ms Macklin, the Labor Party endorsed candidate, with the review. I asked when agreement was reached on the winding-up of her consultancy. Senator Macdonald asked about the staffing of the review. There is a further question relating to expenditure review details of AURDR, including allowances for travel, meeting fees, salaries and consultants. None of those issues have yet been addressed, yet all this investment has been made into this very major program today.

I have not yet had a chance to look through the other 60-odd answers that were delivered to my office on Friday afternoon. A look at them reveals that we probably would like to be participating in some of these seminar panels and asking questions but, obviously, the timing coming out of Mr Howe's office and/or the Department of Housing and Regional Development is an attempt to frustrate any involvement by opposition politicians or the private sector.

Similarly, as Senator Macdonald has said, it is very obviously a stacked conference. A cynical point of view is that it could well be described as a Labor Party marginal seat strategy meeting when it looks at infrastructure. It is not so much the important infrastructure that affects local government, but the infrastructure of how votes will be counted at the next few federal elections. It needs a much more critical view than the patsy and presentational view that Mr Howe would seek to give it by putting together a totally structured and organised committee considering one side of the argument only.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to Australian Standards for imported grain.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the minister lost the plot today, particularly with regard to the second part of my question. In fact, it is quite clear that he did not understand the question. Hopefully, he will enlarge on his answer.

PARA.TAB: I have received some information from the Bureau of Resource Sciences with regard to grain coming into this country and how easy it would be for rusts, bunts or smuts, which are all diseases of plants in the various grain production units in this country, to affect grains such as sorghum, wheat, barley and a variety of others. It says quite clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: Consequently, any dust clouds associated with the loading or unloading of bulk quantities of grain could contain airborne spores such as rust spores.

That is one example. A very similar situation, although not the same, exists with bunts and smuts. In Australia, we have quite an extensive breeding program, which has led to the development of plants that have some, if not total, resistance to these pathogens. This document says:

However, unlike many other fungal pathogen groups, both the smuts and bunts are characterised by the ability to develop new highly virulent, physiologic strains or forms of the disease each new generation. This is because it involves sexual reproduction and the possible recombination of virulence genes. The progeny from a single generation can differ from each other and from the parent culture in their virulence.

The Australian grain industry's production this year, in the unfortunate and difficult circumstances that Australia now finds itself in because of the drought that has occurred in the grain industry, particularly on the eastern side of the country—Western Australian grain growers were more fortunate—is being used to basically fulfil our export obligations. The quality of its product enables the product to be used for purposes other than stock consumption.

PARA.TAB: It is important that the minister treat this particular matter—and particularly the second part of my question—more seriously. The long-term damage and cost that could occur to the Australian grain industry has not been overestimated. I understand that there is a method available whereby these diseases can be eliminated. It has been explained to me in layman's terms that it is a steam cleaning process—in scientific terms it is probably more technical than that.

By using this process we could make sure, at a relatively low cost of $10 per tonne or a five per cent increase in the price of the product, that these diseases do not come into Australia. There is possibly one downside to this process and that is, as the minister identified, that we could destroy some of the uses for these specialist grains. That being the case, the only option is to bring the grain that is required for those purposes from Western Australia even if it does cost a little more. The long-term damage that could occur to grains, such as barley, sorghum, oats or lupins, from rusts, smuts and bunts could be quite horrendous. I urge the minister to take this matter more seriously than he did today rather than make a personal attack on me and say that, as a wheat grower, I should know what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) has a very difficult decision to make in respect of the standards to be set for imported grains. He made the point today that the grain being imported was sourced from the US central west where there was little risk of pathogens and weeds. He said that was also augmented by pest treatment in the United States and careful control in Australia. We have no history of importing grain into Australia. He said that the final manual will be appropriate.
