PARA.TAB: I believe the minister should consider going against the advice of AQIS if it gives the green light to lesser protocols than heat treatment because of the enormous risks and ramifications to the Australian grain industry. Clearly, there will be leakage from trucks. Pathogens are not destroyed by kibbling and can even be transported in dust. Some $10 per tonne is a small price to pay to protect an industry which is absolutely vital and has not had much help, good seasons or good prices for about 20 years.

I support the importation of grain, especially in this case and given that the drought is continuing, because it is not interfering with the local production used for consumption. The drought has had a dramatic effect on grain supply. Over the last 10 years or so we have had a dramatic increase in intensive agriculture. That is certainly the case with feedlots and pork and poultry production.

To put that into perspective, the winter cereal crop in New South Wales normally amounts to about five million tonnes per year. Last year it was about a million tonnes. In the last 10 years, the increase in usage of feed grain has been five million tonnes. The pressure on domestic grain producers is enormous. People in the industry feel that the intensive livestock industry, especially feedlots, has added about $20 a tonne to domestic grain prices. This could be even higher—it could be between $60 and $80.

I believe that, despite subsidisation from some of our competitors, the import parity price that is applied at the moment is, on the whole, acceptable to the grain industry, especially to those who acknowledge the importance of the intensive livestock industries. But our grain industry needs to have complete protection. For that reason, when the manual is completed as the minister says it will be, he should look very carefully at the issue and not give the green light to the importation of grains without the restriction of heat treatment. In terms of the overall grain industry, it will be a very small price to pay.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with both of my colleagues who have already spoken on the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) to Senator Crane's question about the importation of grain. I think the minister said that it is very important that we keep our intensive animal industries going in Australia. We all agree with that. It is very important.

PARA.TAB: In fact, last year I had a meeting with people from the intensive animal industry in Tamworth. In the Tamworth region, 360,000 tonnes of grain are consumed each year in intensive animal industries. It is very important to that region that we have an intensive animal industry, which includes feedlotting, poultry, pigs, et cetera. It is also very important that we keep our grain industries protected from any of the diseases that may come in. I think some of them have been mentioned already. They include the grey leaf spot, Stewarts wilt, Gosses wilt, the boil smut, Downey mildew, the loose kernel smut and the head smut. All of those come from the southern areas of the United States.

The minister said that the government is making sure that the grain comes only from Kansas and Nebraska. But can we be absolutely sure that the containers over there are bringing the correct grain and have been cleaned properly? If the grain is sourced from safe states and treated on the seaboard here, there is not a problem in the world. The problem is when we bring it inland, which we have done in my area.

I have had a look at this in Tamworth where the grain is imported. It is brought to Tamworth under a very strict protocol, which includes trucks that are sealed. It is brought to the mill at Tamworth, where there is now an exhaust fan in place to make sure the dust does not get out. It would be so much easier if there were heat-treating for all those grains at the seaboard. Incidentally, I have also had a look at the seaboard at Newcastle to see whether there was any spillage or breaking of the protocol there.

Basically, the concern of my colleagues and myself is that, if we can make it safer, keep the intensive industries going and not allow anything to cause jeopardy to our very important grain industries, it will be all for the better. Queensland has installed a heat-treating plant. I stand corrected on the figure, but I think it costs $300,000 per heat-treating plant. It is not a fast plant to get things going.

If the government were to put the money into those plants at the seaboard, we would not be concerned with protocols and whether or not we should transport the grain to the country. If any of the dust or diseases get into our grain crops, there will be a bigger problem for the intensive animal industries in the future. One of the most important things is that the two industries work closely together and help each other. If the intensive animal industries have brought in some diseases, it is no good them trying to grind down the prices from the farmers who are producing the grain and, at the same time, expecting grain to be produced the rest of the time, because it will affect both the intensive animal industries and the grain industry.

Basically, the minister disappointed me in his answer when he said that the government is still working out the protocols to secure what is happening and make it even more advantageous to both sides of the industry. The government has had the time to do this since last November when I visited with the minister the people from the intensive animal industries in that region. It is now time that the protocols were got right and we had those heat-treating plants at the seaboard so that grain can be brought in when it needs to be brought in.

At the moment, there should not be any need to bring in grain, as there is a sorghum crop. I know that a lot of the grain which has been brought in has been rubbish anyway. We should be buying locally produced grain which is of the highest quality and which will remain at the highest quality as long as it does not get any disease.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Alston (from 400 citizens) and Senator Bell (from 700 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag

PETITION.PARA: 1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag and condemns the attack on the Australian flag by the Prime Minister Mr Keating while he was overseas.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a referendum.

Dear Mr Creed

I refer to your Chairman's letters of 3 February 1995 regarding recent amendments to the Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Regulations and the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Regulations.

The amendments to the Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Regulations provide for the refund or remission of charges in specified circumstances at the discretion of the Secretary. In the case of the Secretary and representatives of the relevant industry groups not agreeing on the refund or remission arrangements, the Secretary has full discretion as to the course of action.

The Secretary is under no legal obligation to refund or remit over-recovered revenue. The discretionary power gives the Secretary the necessary flexibility to treat each case on its merits and allows factors such as previous years recovery and AQIS's financial position to be considered. In all cases to date, the Commonwealth has reached agreement with industry groups on the format of any refunds or remissions.

AQIS's impartial role in administering the Committees ensures that the interests of all persons affected by a decision, but who are not directly involved with the industry group, are considered.

The amended regulation is not capable of differential application. Any decision to remit or refund charges after consultation with relevant industry groups will be uniformly applied across a program. Any move to differential application would require legislative amendments.

In relation to the amendment to the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Regulations, AQIS has decreased the quantity charge for inspection of bulk grain exports to reflect the reduced AQIS costs and increased industry activity in this program. The same charges were increased significantly in 1989 as part of AQIS's move from 50% to 60% cost recovery. As part of the Government's program of micro-economic reform, AQIS later moved to 100% cost recovery from 1 January 1991.
The current reduction in costs is the result of the implementation of the Government's reform package for AQIS announced late in 1993.

The Committee would, therefore, appreciate some further detail on how charges will be refunded. For example, is it envisaged that the Secretary would, at some point in a financial year, determine that surplus moneys existed; that these should be remitted; and, following consultations with representative organisations, that all those who had paid an establishment registration charge would be entitled to receive a refund of a set percentage of that charge?

In addition, the Committee would appreciate some elaboration on how the "impartial role" of AQIS in administering the Industry Review Committees ensures that the interests of those not directly represented on those Committees are considered.

In your letter, you note that, in all cases to date, agreement has been reached with industry groups on the format of any refunds. As the current procedure seems to be operating effectively, could you also advise the Committee of the reasons for the new regulatory powers.

Dear Mal,

I refer to your letter of 2 March 1995 regarding recent amendments to the Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Regulations which provide for the refund or remission of charges in specified circumstances.

The confusion which still remains about the purpose and application of the amendments could probably best be resolved by providing the committee with some further background information and a practical example of how the amendments are being applied.

The amendments are the mechanism which allows the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to return revenue which is surplus to cost recovery requirements to its clients. A similar provision was added to the Quarantine Act 1908 by amendment in late 1994.

The amount of surplus revenue is determined once AQIS financial statements for the year are finalised. The 1993/94 financial year was the first in which AQlS's financial reporting was in sufficient detail to analyse the cost recovery performance of each commodity group. It was also the first financial year in which AQIS operated under accrual accounting.

In determining the most appropriate method for returning surplus revenue, AQIS has sought agreement with the relevant industry consultative committees. The industry consultative committees are the established fora for discussions with industry regarding cost recovery arrangements. The industry representatives are drawn from all sectors of that industry. Each affected industry group has been given the opportunity through the consultative process to recommend a process by which funds would be returned to that group of AQIS clients.

In the case of the fishing industry, AQIS advised the Fishing Industry Advisory Committee (FIAC) that there was surplus revenue of approximately $666,000 from 1993/94. FIAC advised that the industry's preferred method of retuning funds was through a partial rebate of a set percentage of annual registration charges in the subsequent year and a product testing program.
The former is being achieved through the remission powers contained in subregulations 6 (8) and (9), the latter by administrative arrangement.
AQIS has administered this process in an impartial way by ensuring that industry proposals for the return of surplus funds benefit all participants in the industry.
The current procedure, which you have referred to as operating effectively, has been possible because of the new regulatory powers.

With regard to the typographical error in Note 2 of the amending regulations, I am advised by the Office of Legislative Drafting that the error has no legal bearing and that the necessary correction will be made at the first appropriate opportunity.

Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 3 February 1995 concerning the Military Superannuation and Benefits Trust Deed (Amendment) (No 2 of 1994) made under section 5 of the Military Superannuation and Benefits (MSB) Act 1991.

The first of your enquiries related to the review processes available to applicants where the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner exercises his discretion in respect of the partial release of preserved superannuation employer benefits. My Department sought the advice of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) on this matter and that advice forms the basis of my comments.

The MSB scheme is currently subject to the standards imposed by the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 (OSSA) and its regulations. These standards place restrictions on the early release of benefits to ensure that superannuation benefits are preserved for use in a person's retirement. However, there will be circumstances in which an applicant might be able to access the benefit before retirement and OSSA provides for this by allowing the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner the discretion to determine circumstances for the early release of the benefit. He will consider such an early release on the grounds of severe financial hardship or for compassionate reasons.

An application for early release where a person is experiencing severe financial hardship would normally be approved by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner where there are no assets which could reasonably be used, in the next six months, to cover the gap between personal income and expenses associated with the basic necessities of every day living other than by making use of the preserved superannuation benefit. Where financial difficulties have arisen because of compulsive behaviour patterns, such as gambling, an application would generally not be approved.

In exceptional circumstances release of a benefit may be approved on compassionate grounds by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner notwithstanding that the applicant is not in severe financial hardship. For example, where the applicant can establish, with documentary evidence, that he or she is unable to obtain finances from other sources or the applicant is suffering a terminal illness.

The review process for assessing the release of preserved employer benefits was revised by the ISC in 1993, along with other aspects of the function, including the development of a revised application form. These developments were undertaken in consultation with the Privacy Commissioner and the Commonwealth Ombudsman.
The ISC has implemented and is operating a two tiered internal review system in relation to its decisions of this kind under OSSA.

The original decision to release preserved benefits (or otherwise) is made following application to either the Sydney or Melbourne offices of the ISC. The officers making these decisions rely on a set of internal guidelines. Successful applicants are notified by letter, usually without explanation of the decision. Unsuccessful applicants are provided with a notification which explains why the application was unsuccessful and advises that the decision can be reviewed if the applicant is dissatisfied.

If a review was requested, it would be undertaken by an ISC officer in the same office who had no involvement in the decision. Similarly, if the outcome of the review confirms the original decision, the applicant is advised of the reasons for the review decision. The applicant would also be informed of the availability of the second review option which is an appeal lodged with the Appeals Section in the ISCs Canberra office. Applicants who are unsuccessful in this second review are again informed of the reasons and also advised of their right to refer the matter to the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

The Committee also requested advice on the amendment by the Instrument of the Trust Deed to insert a new Schedule 4A. That Schedule provides for the calculation of the Notional Employer Benefit by reference to the Consumer Price Index (CPI) published by the Statistician.
Clause 2 of Schedule 4A to the Trust Deed contains the operative reference to the CPI. The relevant provision in Clause 2 is:
"2. (1) A person's notional employer benefit is taken to have increased in a financial year (in this clause called the `relevant year'):

(a) if the all groups consumer price index number for the weighted average of the 8 capital cities published by the Statistician in respect of the March quarter of the year immediately preceding the relevant year exceeds the highest all groups consumer price index number for the weighted average of the 8 capital cities published by the Statistician in respect of the March quarter of any earlier year (except a year earlier than the year that commenced on I July 1989); and
(b) in the circumstances described in paragraph (a)—by an amount equal to the prescribed percentage of the person's notional employer benefit as at the end of the previous financial year."

Your letter referred to the Committee's 1993-94 Annual Report, in which the Committee expressed the view that, where regulations made under one Act defined a matter in relation to a register kept under another Act, "the incorporation would be valid only if it referred to the register as existing when the regulations were made".

In this context, the Committee asked for advice as to the effect of section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act on the validity of the reference in Schedule 4A to the CPI increases published by the Statistician. Section 49A would prevent the Instrument incorporating "an instrument or other writing as in force or existing from time to time".
The Attorney-General's Department has advised that Clause 2 of Schedule 4A is not affected by section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act.

The Attorney-General's Department is of the view that the result of the Statistician's activities in ascertaining and publishing the periodical variations that have occurred in the CPI cannot be characterised as "an instrument or other writing as in force or existing from time to time" or as having any parallel to a register. The Attorney-General's Department's view is that the true character of those activities seems to be the periodic recognition, by scientific (statistical) means, of observable facts and the public reporting of those facts in, essentially, an isolated notice.

The Attorney-General's Department has concluded that the fact that the Trust Deed refers to more than one CPI figure does not affect that view: that is, the figures do not link as an instrument or other writing as in force or existing from time to time.
On the basis of this advice, the reference in the Instrument to the CPI increases is considered valid.
I trust that these comments have met the Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
GARY PUNCH

TALK.START.PARA: —Various newspaper reports over the weekend were personally defamatory of me. They claimed, among other things, that `no bucket job is too mucky for Senator Baume'. They claimed that I had behaved in a way that was improper by revealing that an Independent member of the New South Wales parliament had—there is no dispute about these facts—understated his income by $102,000 and, as has been subsequently admitted by that member, had had to pay $60,000 in back taxes. In other words, there is no dispute whatsoever about the facts. I was absolutely correct. What I said was totally true.

PARA.TAB: I do not mind being accused of being truthful, but these accusations claim that I am untruthful. The expression `throwing muck' clearly suggests falsity. There was not one touch of anything other than the truth in what I said. It is important to note, however, that the newspaper reports contain a mountain of untruths and half-truths. One of the half-truths which was made by the Daily Telegraph-Mirror was that I had produced and tabled a document bearing Dr Macdonald's tax file number. It is true that I did not note that the tax file number was on that document when I tabled it, but neither did the duty minister, Senator Crowley, who examined the document for a full five minutes before giving approval for it to be tabled.

Immediately after the Senate rose, it was drawn to my attention that a tax file number was on that document. I immediately contacted the Senate Table Office and asked for that number to be excised—and Senator Gareth Evans knows that. The Senate Table Office said no, that I had to get the approval of the Clerk and must write a letter. I immediately wrote a scribbled note, I have to say, on paper which had no letterhead because I was so determined to get that error corrected. The Clerk agreed to that course of action.

I asked the Senate Table Office whether anyone had received a copy of that document, and I was informed that three journalists had. One of those journalists, in particular, I rang immediately, and she agreed to my request to excise the number. The other two journalists agreed to do likewise. I totally accept the assurances given by those journalists that no copy of this document with the tax file number would have been distributed by them.

However, the Senate Table Office advised me that two government senators had got copies of this document. If this tax file number has been distributed and published to anyone, it has been distributed and published by members of this government. That is why I resent the allegations which have been made against me. Not one of the allegations, I stress, denies in any way the accuracy, the total truth, of what I had to say.

I believe that it is my duty to advise electors in any electorate of these things but particularly to advise those in this electorate where this particular person adopted a sanctimonious approach in relation to the former Premier of New South Wales and played a key role in forcing him to resign. I thought it absolutely vital that these circumstances at least be made available so that the electors of Manly could make a proper judgment on the integrity of a man who understated his income by $104,000. As I see that a notice of motion has been placed on the Notice Paper, I will now hold over other matters I wished to raise in personal explanation until we have had the opportunity to debate this quite disgraceful notice of motion, which Senator Gareth Evans knows to be based on a total denial of the truth.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT (REFUNDS FOR CERTAIN PUBLIC INTEREST AND CHARITABLE BODIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Watson) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 to enable certain public interest and charitable bodies to claim a refund of sales tax, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Watson) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present an explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: A spate of phone calls from distressed and disillusioned officials from a number of benevolent institutions a few months back complaining of the moral bankruptcy of the Australian government through the Australian Taxation Office not refunding overpaid sales tax prompted my private senator's bill presented today. Evidently, a decree must have gone out because of the need to maximise tax receipts to hold overpaid sales tax payments in circumstances where an exempt body has overpaid sales tax. Upon inquiry, I was advised that there was no legislative mechanism to permit a credit or refund, so the ATO was entitled to keep the money.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Sales Tax Assessment (Refunds for Certain Public Interest and Charitable Bodies) Amendment Bill is to provide a legislative framework to allow certain public interest and charitable bodies to claim a refund of sales tax under sales tax law. As we all know, exempt bodies do not have to pay sales tax. Exempt bodies previously not entitled to a credit but benefiting from this bill would be, as taken from the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992, public hospitals; a hospital carried on by a non-profit body; a public benevolent institution; a public body that is established and maintained principally for the relief of unemployed persons; charitable fundraising bodies; medical research bodies; accident prevention bodies; infant-welfare bodies; bodies established in Australia solely for public purposes; a non-profit body established and maintained principally for religious, philosophical, educational, scientific or literary purposes, or for the encouragement or advancement of fine arts; armed forces support bodies; and public zoos.

In ordinary circumstances, where an amount is collected in excess of what is agreed, a refund would be regarded as a natural entitlement. The surprising thing is that I am not referring to an isolated event. Therefore, the government, having been advised some time ago of this hole in the legislation, should have rectified the defect. It is anathema for good professional tax officers having to enforce bad law or a law which produces situations of injustice or results from what I am sure must be unintended consequences. The amendments I am presenting to this Senate are therefore an equity or a justice issue. Benevolent institutions, including the list that I have just named to the Senate, can find themselves with a problem of overpaying—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not wish to interrupt Senator Watson except to say that the normal way the Senate works is to allow such a second reading speech that Senator Watson is making to be incorporated into Hansard. I do not know how much more there is for Senator Watson to complete this, but it certainly would have been my preferred option if he had sought leave. The government would have granted leave, as is always the case in relation to this. I just hope that a monumental amount of time will not be spent on this matter. DEBATE.TITLE: AIR NAVIGATION AMENDMENT (EXTENSION OF CURFEW AND LIMITATION OF AIRCRAFT MOVEMENTS) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bourne) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Air Navigation Act 1920 to extend the curfew and impose a maximum hourly rate of aircraft movements at Kingsford Smith Airport.
Motion (by Senator Bourne) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to reduce the acute distress being experienced by thousands of people living around Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport (KSA), and to put a halt to the Government's plans to increase their distress.

The bill proposes two measures—-to extend and strengthen the KSA curfew, and to freeze the rate of aircraft movements while a Commission of Inquiry is conducted under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. It amends the Air Navigation Act 1920, and through the act amends the Air Navigation (Aerodrome Curfew) Regulations.
As is well known, the curfew which operates at KSA has been eroded under strong pressure, particularly from the airline industry.

The nominal curfew hours have contracted to the present 11pm to 6am, which simply does not provide noise-affected residents with enough rest time. A seven-hour curfew is particularly inadequate to meet the sleeping patterns of children and the sick. I have heard stories of children who go to bed at 8.30pm only to be woken up two hours later, and have had many complaints from people being prematurely woken as the noise bombardment begins at 6am.

There is plenty of evidence of serious health problems arising from aircraft noise in Sydney, and the inadequacy of the curfew is a major cause of those. This bill proposes to extend the curfew by an hour—-so that it operates from 10.30pm to 6.30am and alleviates the noise burden to a significant degree. This is particularly important given that the noise abatement measures which are supposed to make life tolerable for people under the flight paths—-and there is room for doubt about that—-will not be implemented for some time.

The erosion of the curfew has also occurred in the area of exemptions. International flights are allowed to use KSA in the hour after the curfew starts and the hour before it ends. A number of freight aircraft movements are permitted throughout the curfew period, propellor aircraft have a blanket exemption, and the Minister can issue other permits if he sees fit.

The result has been that people near the southern flight paths could be forgiven for seeing this as a Clayton's curfew—-the curfew you have went you don't have a curfew. While it is true that there are fewer flights on more resident-friendly flight paths, the impact of the noise is magnified by our social and biological expectations that night is a quiet time.

This bill abolishes the Department of Transport's discretion to exempt international carriers from the curfew, and repeals the exemptions for freight jets. It turns the Clayton's curfew into a credible curfew.

This is not to say that exemptions should never be granted. Clearly if a certain type of low-noise aircraft is able to use KSA during curfew hours without causing significant distress to affected residents, then an exemption could be considered. However, our bill would limit the granting of exemptions to the Minister, and not his Department, and would give either House of Parliament the power of veto. A very convincing case would have to be made before any exemption would be allowed to stand.

The second part of the bill is a response to the Government's extraordinary proposal to increase the rate of aircraft movements from the present 55 per hour to 65 by the middle of the year, and 80 by the end, as air traffic controllers become more familiar with the new control tower.

If there is one conclusion which can be drawn from the aircraft noise debate over the last few months, it is that community reaction to the new flight paths was seriously underestimated in the Environmental Impact Statement on the parallel runway. The Australian Noise Exposure Forecast system is a useful guide to zoning around a greenfields airport site, but it is much less useful in predicting the reaction of an existing community which has had a new noise burden foisted upon it.

The weakness of the EIS is hardly surprising when you consider just how flawed and biased the process is. You can't expect the proponent of a project to write an objective assessment of the environmental impacts, but that is exactly what the EIS process requires them to do. It has always been a fraud and is long overdue for reform.

What this means is that there has not been a credible and independent assessment of the noise impacts of the Government's plans for KSA, despite the effect they will have on thousands of people. The interests of the airline industry should not be met by destroying people's home lives and avoiding due process, but that is what is happening here. If the noise problems seem bad now with 55 aircraft movements per hour, just imagine how bad they'll be at 80.

The Democrats recognise that the Minister for Transport is accelerating measures to reduce the noise. But the fact is that the full benefits are a long way off, and there is serious doubt that they will be enough. Basic fairness dictates that consideration of any further increase in the noise burden is out of the question until there has been a proper inquiry, and a new set of noise standards which meet general community acceptance are in place.

If further increases in aircraft movements can be made compatible with the new standards, then we would consider that. If not—-and in my view this is more likely—-then the cap remains in place and there is no choice but to make Badgery's Creek Sydney's primary airport.
The legislation therefore restricts the maximum rate of aircraft movements to the present level of 55. It prevents any increase unless three stringent conditions are met.

First, there must have been a Commission of Inquiry to assess the environmental impacts, including the noise impacts, of the proposed increase. A Commission of Inquiry is powerful, and it is independent. It is the highest form of environmental assessment available in Australia, and can be established by the Minister for Environment under section 11 of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.
Second, the Government must have finalised an environmental management plan, including a noise management plan, which is consistent with the Commission's findings.
Third, both Houses of Parliament must have given their approval to the proposed increase.

This establishes the proper processes which should have been implemented in the first place before the parallel runway was built instead of fast-tracking Badgery's Creek. It puts people before aircraft, and deserves the full support of the Parliament.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
