DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Pursuant to the resolution of Senate of 13 February 1991, on behalf of the President I present the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Fisheries review which was presented to Senator Herron as a Temporary Chairman of Committees on behalf of the President since the last sitting of the Senate. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, the document was authorised for publication. With the concurrence of the Senate I ask that the document be incorporated in Hansard, as is the usual practice.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PROCTEXT.PARA: 10 March 1995
Senator Bruce Childs
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure
The Senate
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Childs
I am responding on behalf of the Government to the report Fisheries Reviewed by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

I wish to congratulate both you and the Committee for the comprehensive approach taken in addressing the inquiry's terms of reference. I see from the report that you held 13 public hearings, received 41 submissions and took evidence from around 90 witnesses.

Your Committee's review is welcome in that it identified areas where Commonwealth fisheries management can be improved. Matters that I believe have been usefully identified for the attention of Government include such issues as fishing access rights, industry adjustment options, how industry members are appointed to the Australian Fisheries Management Authority's (AFMA) Management Advisory Committees, improvements in consultative arrangements with the people of Lord Howe Island, the adequacy of search warrants, the adequacy of penalties for infringements of fisheries regulations and how AFMA might improve the presentation of its financial data to make it more useful to industry and Government.

Some recommendations made by the Committee are also matters which are constantly being monitored and improved by AFMA as it develops new plans of management under the Fisheries Management Act 1991. Issues such as fairness and equity in dealing with fishermen, how best to deal with bycatch and overcatch, progress on the Offshore Constitutional Settlement arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and catch verification procedures used by processors, are matters of on-going improvement and, as such, do not require new decisions.

Some recommendations have been overtaken by events. For example, the suggestion about making conditions similar to those in the States for obtaining search warrants will now be addressed by bringing fisheries legislation into line with the Commonwealth's Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994 which came into force on 1 December 1994.

In drawing together this response, the National Fishing Industry Council, AFMA, CSIRO and State/Territory fisheries departments have provided comment on the Committee's recommendations. Ministers of departments that would be directly affected by changes to Commonwealth fisheries legislation have been consulted. I believe that the response represents a well balanced reply to your Committee's report.
The list of recommendations with comments and advice on action either underway or proposed is attached.
Yours sincerely
DAVID BEDDALL
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT
FISHERIES REVIEWED
BY THE
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON
INDUSTRY, SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE
March 1995

The report on the adequacy of Commonwealth fisheries legislation (in particular the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 and the Fisheries Management Act 1991) contains 46 recommendations. In many instances the matters raised are those where on-going review and improvement is in place as part of progressive fisheries management. Nonetheless, there are 11 recommendations where the Government agrees that new action would be of benefit to the fisheries under its jurisdiction. Below is the Government's consideration and position on each recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter 3: AFMA's approach to fisheries management

PROCTEXT.PARA: NFIC sought the inclusion of an additional objective, `the restoration of viability to the commercial fishing industry', noting that AFMA recognised the importance of achieving this in its interim corporate plan. The Committee considers that the suggestions made by NFIC have merit and recommends that they be further considered by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. (Paragraph 3.18)

The Government is strongly supportive of a viable commercial fishing industry. However, the specific inclusion in legislation of the additional objective `the restoration of viability to the commercial fishing industry' is considered unnecessary as this issue is already covered by the existing objective `maximising economic efficiency in the exploitation of fisheries resources'. As AFMA is already required to seek to `maximise economic efficiency . . . . ` AFMA is already addressing the problems of excess fishing capacity in its fisheries through the MAC process where industry is well represented. This, in turn, should lead to restoration of viability for the fishing industry.
While the recommendation is not supported, the Government believes its intent is covered.
The Committee . . . recommends that AFMA's objectives be listed in order of importance in the Act, and that the Act be amended to reflect this. (Paragraph 3.19)

It is the Government's opinion that the objectives in the 1991 fisheries legislation should be viewed as an overall package rather than as a set hierarchy. Fisheries management plans are an integrated package of measures designed to achieve long term sustainable and efficient use of resources in a manner consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. No two management plans are the same and at different times in their implementation the emphasis on certain objectives will vary. Fisheries managers need the flexibility to adapt to changing circumstances and a hierarchy of objectives could, at times, stymie this flexibility.
The recommendation is not supported.

The Committee recommends that ultimately the decision [regarding input and output controls] must be made on two principal criteria—cost and effectiveness in ensuring fisheries remain sustainable for the future. (Paragraph 3.29)

The Government acknowledges the importance of both criteria (cost and effectiveness) in determining the use of input and output controls in fisheries management. The Government notes that this view parallels much more closely the approach that AFMA has now adopted. Furthermore, AFMA is very conscious that a number of other factors need also to be considered when determining the use of input or output controls in fisheries management such as whether:
there is broad industry support;
the fishery is managed under a single jurisdiction;
there has been sufficient stock assessment to permit the setting of responsible total allowable catches (TACs);
all gear sectors (including foreign operators and recreational interests where applicable) should be included in the management arrangements;
there can be equitable allocations; and
there exists satisfactory by-catch, high grading, monitoring and surveillance measures, as well as effective enabling legislation.
AFMA is now implementing this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter Four: Property rights under the Commonwealth fisheries management act

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Committee considers it is likely that the property rights issue has the potential to involve the Commonwealth and fishers in expensive litigation for some time to come. The Committee therefore concludes that an urgent re-examination of the approach to the property rights question in the Management Act should be undertaken. It believes that had the property rights issue been approached with more regard to fairness and equity, a number of the present difficulties and much of the litigation could have been avoided. (Paragraph 4.15)

The Government fully supports the principles of fairness and equity in making decisions, particularly those that impact on the livelihood of individuals. It should be noted that all the current property rights litigation relates to licences under the Fisheries Act 1952. A decision by the full bench of the Federal Court, subsequent to the finalisation of the Committee's report, has reduced the incentive to litigate on property rights. The Federal Court ruled that fishing access rights may be withdrawn in the valid exercise of powers under fisheries legislation, without the payment of compensation. The relevant provisions of the Fisheries Management Act 1991 reflect this position.

The Government's policy statement New Directions for Commonwealth Fisheries Management in the 1990s (1989) made it clear that fish stocks are a community owned resource and, therefore, a role for government is to allocate access to fisheries resources in order to ensure that they are not over-exploited and that they are used as efficiently as possible to maximise benefits to the industry and the nation. Section 22 of the Fisheries Management Act 1991 provides the conditions under which AFMA is to establish and administer a system of statutory fishing rights in accordance with a plan of management.

Recognising the concerns of the fishing industry on this matter, the Government has re-examined, with assistance from industry representatives and AFMA, the matter of fishing access rights. Amendments to the Fisheries Management Act 1991 are to be introduced.

Given the current financial circumstances of some small operators in the SEF, the Committee recommends that AFMA, in close consultation with SETMAC, re-examine the process of allocating quota in the SEF with the objective of ensuring all participants, including long term, smaller scale operators, are dealt with in a manner which is fair and equitable. It further recommends that AFMA and SETMAC explore all options for adjustment in the SEF and adopt a flexible approach in determining the best use of the NFAP account, which may include some form of buy-out of operators holding small amounts of quota. (Paragraph 4.40)
SEF quota allocation

It would appear that some complaints by fishermen about lack of fairness and equity primarily relate to the manner in which initial quota allocations were made when output controls were introduced into this fishery in 1991. That was prior to the establishment of AFMA. It has subsequently been determined by the courts that the initial allocative mechanism was flawed. AFMA has since made substantial progress in redressing this issue. Extensive reviews of the allocation provisions in the SEF have been conducted by a number of different bodies over recent years and it is the Government's view that further reviews of the allocation provisions would result in even more instability and uncertainty in the fishery and would serve no practical purpose for the fishery overall.

AFMA is fully aware that if output controls are to be introduced in a fishery then there should be broad prior agreement with industry on the mechanism to allocate the quota in the first instance. Working within the constraint of a sustainable TAC, industry will need to be instrumental in deciding on the agreed mechanism prior to new arrangements being implemented.

AFMA is very aware that it cannot responsibly increase TACs for the SEF unless stock assessments clearly indicate that it is possible and responsible to do so. If there is no increase in TACs, increased quota allocations to some operators would need to be offset by reductions in the allocations to others. Any such action would almost certainly result in a new round of litigation.

In December 1993, prior to the release of the Committee's report, AFMA agreed to full transferability of quotas in the SEF which will assist those operators wishing to adjust their quota holdings. This decision has met with general acceptance.

It should be noted that the development of a management plan under the Fisheries Management Act 1991 requires extensive consultative processes be undertaken and that quota holders may have the quantum of statutory fishing rights granted to them under such a plan reviewed by the Statutory Fishing Rights Allocation Review Panel. AFMA is currently developing such a management plan for the SEF. This process will ensure that the management arrangements in the fishery are open to both wide public and industry consultation and to the existing review mechanisms in the 1991 legislation.
Recognising the principles of fairness and equity the Government, through AFMA, is continuing to address these issues as it develops the SEF management plan under the Fisheries Management Act 1991.
The NFAP account

In regard to the Committee's recommendation that some form of buy-out be investigated, AFMA has held discussions with representatives of the NSW Commercial Fishing Advisory Council on possible adjustment options. In addition, SETMAC has considered adjustment options for those operators who received relatively small initial allocations when management arrangements were changed from a unit system to the present quota system.
The Government is continuing to examine, with input from AFMA, SETMAC and industry meetings, all adjustment options for this fishery including the possible use of the NFAP.

The Committee reiterates that AFMA must always seek to apply the principles of fairness and equity when management decisions about fisheries are taken. The costs of litigation mean that justice can be very difficult to obtain for those operators who lack the financial resources to mount court challenges. The Committee therefore recommends that AFMA develop and implement a code of practice to be adopted with respect to their dealings with fishers. This code must incorporate the principles of fair and open dealing, just compensation when required, and industry consultation on all major decisions. (Paragraph 4.47)

The Government agrees that the principles of fairness and equity must apply to fisheries management decisions and that there is industry consultation on all major decisions. These principles are embodied in the provisions of the Commonwealth Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and the Fisheries Management Act 1991. In addition, the Government's Social Justice Strategy is built on the application of the principles of equity, equality, access and participation in such matters.

In 1992, AFMA established a code of conduct embracing the concepts of fairness and equity. The code sets out the standard of behaviour expected of AFMA staff with the objective of providing a service to the fishing industry and the community in general which is efficient, fair, impartial and honest.

While every effort is made to avoid litigation to resolve differences, it is recognised that individuals will always have the right to seek a Court decision on their particular circumstances. Court decisions, the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the distribution of an AFMA code of conduct should provide a firm basis for AFMA and industry to reach balanced agreement on management issues.

Additionally, a paper outlining the obligations and responsibilities of MAC industry members has been produced and is provided to members prior to their appointment to a MAC. All new MAC members are required to formally advise that they have read and understood the relevant sections of the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 dealing with Management Advisory Committees and the paper `MAC Industry Members—Obligations and Responsibilities'.
This recommendation is supported and has been implemented.

The Committee further recommends that where questions about the application of the principles of equity and fairness in determining access to a fishery are raised, these matters should be referred to MACs for mediation. Litigation should be used by either party only as a final resort. (Paragraph 4.48)

The Government fully supports the notion that litigation should be used only as a final resort. However, the role of a MAC is appropriately `advisory' and the MAC's function is to develop management options for the fishery. A MAC would then be expected to work towards resolving any conflicts with the objective of arriving at what could be truly seen as an agreed position that is fair and equitable, prior to making recommendations to the AFMA Board. The Government agrees that MACs are the most appropriate bodies to advise on such matters.

Nevertheless, experience has shown that situations will arise where a MAC may not be able to reach an agreed decision. Under these circumstances, AFMA is obliged to make the final decision on what it considers to be in the best interests of the fishery as a whole.
The recommendation is not supported.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter Five: A greater role for MACs

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Committee recommends that the title of MACs in the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 be changed to Management Committees to reflect their changed status. (Paragraph 5.12)
The Committee also recommends that changes be made to the
Management Act to reflect the altered status and roles of the Committees where required. (Paragraph 5.13)

The Government supports the concept of greater industry involvement in the direct management of individual fisheries. Indeed, the provisions relating to management advisory committees (sections 56 to 67 of the Fisheries Administration Act 1991) clearly envisage a gradual devolution of decision making responsibilities to individual MACs. As appropriate, Commonwealth fisheries management will evolve in this direction.

The Committee drew attention to the extent of industry involvement in the management of the Spencer Gulf prawn fishery in South Australia. However, the Spencer Gulf fishery is unique in that it is single species, is in a relatively confined area and has a small number of operators with close family and community links. It must also be recognised that even in this fishery ultimate responsibility still rests with the South Australian Department of Primary Industries and its Minister.

Most importantly, the Government is concerned about the impact that implementation of this recommendation could have with respect to AFMA's responsibilities to the Minister and to Parliament, and on the capacity of AFMA directors to fulfil their statutory obligations. Implementation of recommendations 8 and 9 would virtually create a series of `mini-AFMAs' each responsible for an individual fishery, but not directly responsible to either the Minister or Parliament. AFMA, on the other hand, would still have nominal responsibility for ensuring the objectives of the Fisheries Management Act 1991 are met and would be responsible for reporting to the Minister and Parliament, but would have only limited decision making power. Such a change would break the vital nexus between decision making and accountability.

In consultations with State and Territory governments, there was little support for these two recommendations. Indeed, some States correctly observed that it is vital that effective links are in place between jurisdictions to ensure that management of State and Commonwealth fisheries does not diverge and lead to unacceptable outcomes. The Government believes that this can best be achieved by the States working with a single Commonwealth management agency rather than with a number of Management Committees (MC).

An additional concern is that of funding for AFMA if its MACs were to take on the responsibility envisaged by this recommendation. For Government related work, MCs might need to be directly funded from the Budget. Accountability to Government of both AFMA and the new MCs would then become an issue.
Recommendations 8 and 9 are not supported.
The Committee has considered the issue of MAC membership. It recommends the following amendments to s62 of the Administration Act:
industry representatives on the Management Committees be appointed through a democratic process to be determined by the Minister;
the AFMA board's right to veto industry appointments be removed. (Paragraph 5.14)

This recommendation raises issues of social justice and, in-principle, the Government supports the notion of democratic processes and will explore all practical options for consideration. However, the Government remains aware of the need for MAC members to bring with them certain expertise as well as a requirement to represent the best interests of the fishery.
The Government will take up these issues with both AFMA and industry.

The Committee . . . recommends that AFMA be required to closely monitor the activities of the Management Committees, negotiate performance indicators with them and report back to the Parliament on the operation of the new provisions in its annual report. (Paragraph 5.16)

In view of the Government's response to recommendations 8 and 9 above, this recommendation requires no action. However, AFMA already closely monitors the performance of its MACs. Each MAC is now required to prepare a strategic plan which will include appropriate performance indicators.
No action is required on this recommendation.

The Committee recommends that AFMA establish a forum consisting of industry and scientific advisers to develop options for the logical and scientifically valid division of the SEF. As a minimum requirement, a way should be found to separate the highly specialised deep water operators from the other parts of the fishery. (Paragraph 6.27)

The future division of jurisdictional responsibility in the SEF is currently being discussed as part of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement (OCS) arrangements between the Commonwealth and the relevant States. Among other things, fish should be managed on the basis of stocks; lines on the water that subdivide stocks should be avoided. Consideration of this issue under the OCS arrangements is being undertaken in the light of the best available scientific, economic and social data in consultation with industry.

The recent freeing up of restrictions on quota transfers in the SEF is expected, over time, to have a major impact on rationalising the fishery. Those with big boats better suited to deep water operation are expected to aggregate quota for deep water species and possibly to sell quota for other species. Smaller boat operators are expected to do the opposite. This market driven rationalisation will help produce a more effective and efficient division of the fishery than could be obtained by administrative decision alone.
The intent of this recommendation is accepted. However, in this case OCS arrangements and quota negotiability are the Government's preferred options.
The Committee . . . recommends that all Commonwealth licensed vessels, regardless of history, be excluded from the twelve mile zone [of Lord Howe Island]. (Paragraph 6.43)

AFMA originally proposed a complete closure of 12 nml radius of Lord Howe Island and Balls Pyramid to all operators. AFMA wrote to all holders of line Fishing Permits with access to the area, NSW Fisheries, and NSW Commercial Fishing Advisory Council on 1 April 1993 seeking comments on the proposal. Responses were received from individual fishermen, NSW Fisheries, the CFAC and the National Fishing Industry Council pointing out that a number of operators had `traditionally' fished in the waters of the proposed closure and that their circumstances should be considered when implementing such a closure.

AFMA considered there was a sound case for continued access by line operators who had a documented history of fishing in the area in the previous three years. Only one fisherman fell into this category and he continues to operate in the exclusion area. All evidence regarding the catch taken from inside the exclusion area suggests that this operator is fishing a virgin stock and that there is no threat to sustainability of stocks by allowing this operation to continue.

The Government is of the view that to terminate this licence, or to subject it to special conditions, could be a denial of natural justice. Action to restrict this single operator's access could precipitate expensive litigation.
Under these circumstances, the recommendation is not supported.

It is also unclear as to whether Balls Pyramid is included in the twelve mile zone declared by AFMA. The Committee therefore recommends that the zone be extended to include an area twelve miles around Balls Pyramid. (Paragraph 6.44)
This recommendation has been implemented.

The Committee further recommends that jurisdiction of this zone be vested in the Lord Howe Island Board. A condition of this transfer of responsibility is that the Board limit fishing in the zone to the needs of the island and not allow the export of fish to the mainland as is currently the case. The Board should also be empowered to ensure fishing is carried out in a sustainable manner. (Paragraph 6.45)

The Government does not agree that jurisdiction for the exclusion area be transferred to the Lord Howe Island Board. The Board does not have the infrastructure, suitably trained staff, facilities or funds available to administer the exclusion area around Lord Howe Island and Balls Pyramid. In some cases, the Commonwealth has engaged State or Territory Governments to carry out these functions on the Commonwealth's behalf but only where those governments were willing, and have at their disposal adequate resources and infrastructure, to carry out these responsibilities.

The fishing industry has made the suggestion that a formal consultative arrangement might be established for this area with representation by Lord Howe Island people. There is merit in this idea and AFMA has been asked to consider this option.
While the specific recommendation is not supported, other options to improve consultations are being considered.

The Committee further recommends that AFMA establish contacts with the Lord Howe Island Board with the intention of establishing a system for notification of violations of the protected zone. (Paragraph 6.46)
This recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

The finalisation of jurisdictional arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States is an important condition for the establishment of sustainable fisheries management. The Committee considers AFMA should regard this as a high priority and recommends that it devote maximum effort to finalising the matter. (Paragraph 6.47)

The Government fully supports this recommendation and has devoted considerable resources towards rationalising fisheries jurisdictional arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy (which has carriage of State/Commonwealth inter-governmental negotiations), with full cooperation and assistance from AFMA, has been working towards resolving outstanding issues as quickly as possible.

It should be noted that considerable progress on OCS has been made since the Senate hearings. Some of the specific concerns mentioned in the report have been resolved through further discussions on the practicalities and effects of the Commonwealth's proposed `species based' OCS Agreements.

`In-principle' agreement has been reached between Commonwealth and southern State fisheries Ministers on revised OCS arrangements. The details will be developed by Commonwealth and State officials in consultation with industry representatives. Revised OCS arrangements were agreed with northern States (Qld, NT and WA) and are now in place.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

The Committee has not investigated whether the conditions for obtaining a warrant are similar in all states. However, it is essential that enforcement officers be provided with adequate powers. The Committee recommends that the Management Act be amended to enable enforcement officers to obtain warrants under similar conditions to those which prevail under State legislation. If necessary, conditions applicable to each State should be included in the amendment. (Paragraph 7.13)

Recent developments in Commonwealth law include the coming into force on 1 December 1994 of the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994 (`the SWAP Act'). The Act prescribes the search and seizure powers that govern police officers investigating the majority of Commonwealth offences and sets out clear guidelines on when and how warrants are to be granted. The SWAP Act is now the benchmark of the Commonwealth's search and seizure policy.

It would now be inappropriate for a Commonwealth Act, such as the Fisheries Management Act 1991, to incorporate State principles since this could lead to identical offences that occurred in different States being treated differently. The Commonwealth's policy objective is to bring all Commonwealth legislation that grant powers of arrest, search and seizure into line with the SWAP Act.

The warrant provisions of the Fisheries Management Act 1991 will be amended so that they are in line with the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994 . The Attorney-General's Department will be consulted in this exercise.

The Committee recommends that, in consultation with industry, AFMA conduct a review of the adequacy of penalties. The objectives of this review should be to ensure penalties are consistent and appropriate. One option which should be considered is the development of a schedule describing a detailed scale of offences and penalties. (Paragraph 7.15)

The Government supports this recommendation and AFMA has commenced the review. To encourage consistency Australia-wide, the States and the Northern Territory will be consulted in the review, as will the Attorney-General's Department. The Commonwealth has guidelines on penalties and these will be taken into account during the review.

The Committee notes that AFMA is currently developing a formal development and training program for its staff and recommends that this program be extended to ensure State fisheries officers have access to adequate training on the Commonwealth legislation. (Paragraph 7.20)

The Government supports the suggestion that State officers continue to receive adequate training on Commonwealth fisheries legislation so that they can carry out their functions in full. The Government notes, however, that when AFMA contracts the States to undertake surveillance programs, the States have a responsibility to see that their fisheries officers are trained adequately and can deliver the services specified in the contract. AFMA officers attend State conducted training workshops in order to provide advice on Commonwealth legislation and surveillance policy. If the Commonwealth is to provide additional training for State officials, arrangements for recovering the cost of doing so may need to be addressed.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

The Committee recommends that AFMA set a deadline for the notification of State officers of changes and developments similar to the system it already has in place for dealing with correspondence. (Paragraph 7.21)
The recommendation is supported and AFMA is implementing an appropriate system of notification.

The Committee recommends that amendments be made to the Management Act to enable the fish receiver permit system to operate independently of whether a management plan is in place. The Committee further recommends that AFMA be required to conduct a cost benefit analysis of this system in consultation with the appropriate MAC before implementing this system for each fishery. (Paragraph 7.26)

The Government fully supports the recommendation and an amendment to the Fisheries Management Act 1991 has now been passed by Parliament to extend the fish receiver permit to fisheries where there is no management plan in place. This will overcome some of the difficulties in monitoring and enforcement of output controls in fisheries managed by a system of permits under the existing legislation. It will allow AFMA to enforce the requirement of receivers to provide AFMA with verified catch information.

The introduction of a system of fish receiver permits will be done in consultation with relevant MACs. A permit system will need to be efficient and include some consideration of the trade-off between costs and benefits. Conducting a formal cost-benefit analysis may not be appropriate in every case.
Consultations with State and Territory fisheries agencies on verification systems in their jurisdictions will be undertaken.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

[The Committee] recommends AFMA investigate whether a system could be implemented whereby the amount of detail required in logbooks be reduced as a trade-off for the use of catch verification procedures by processors. (Paragraph 7.27)

The Government supports `in-principle' this recommendation but notes that at all times appropriate, adequate and timely provision of data is a prerequisite for sustainable resource management. There is an on-going need to periodically review all data gathering for its relevance and cost of collection. AFMA is currently reviewing its total data collection system with a view to removing duplication and the collection of unnecessary information, so as to maximise data collection efficiency, whilst at the same time minimising the costs of collecting that data. The integrity of data collection systems, however, will not be compromised.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

The Committee has not taken legal advice on how the status of paper trails within the legal system can be improved. However, it recognises this as a potentially significant weakness in fisheries enforcement provisions and recommends that AFMA seek advice on how the problem may be best addressed. (Paragraph 7.28)

The Government accepts the intent of this recommendation. Extending the fish receiver permit system to fisheries without plans of management is believed to also address this issue. Therefore, the issue will be pursued in conjunction with recommendation 22.
The recommendation is supported and AFMA will seek this advice.

The Committee seeks to reduce the overall costs of compliance by measures such as the mandatory fitting of location transponders. The Committee recommends that AFMA consult with the Management Committees concerning the desirability of requiring transponders to be fitted. In investigating this measure, AFMA should ensure that the cost of equipment is minimised through, for example, co-ordinated bulk purchase. (Paragraph 7.32)

The fitting of transponders is an issue considered by MACs. The Government is strongly in favour of transponders, particularly in fisheries where closures and/or regional quotas form part of the management measures in place. Whether this measure alone will significantly reduce compliance costs in the short term is questionable. However, if it is combined with other compliance measures such as the broadening of fish receiver permits, it may prevent an increase in current compliance costs. Transponders are an aid to more traditional methods of surveillance such as aerial and at-sea surveillance.

Transponders have now been fitted to all orange roughy boats. In addition, the amended fish receiver permit provisions will enter into force in the SEF on 1 April 1995. These arrangements should improve the cost-effectiveness of surveillance and compliance.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.
The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries direct AQIS to negotiate, as a matter of priority, the development of an export certification system. (Paragraph 7.35)
This recommendation relates primarily to the scope for Commonwealth export controls to curb the extent of abalone theft.

Abalone is a prescribed product under export control legislation, with clearance for export by AQIS based on compliance with a range of safety and hygiene related requirements, as well as compliance with other relevant Commonwealth and State law. AQIS is currently carrying out a comprehensive review of shortcomings and loopholes in the existing control approaches. The review covers all aspects of export control from receipt of raw material into the export chain to the product's final clearance for export. It includes the development of a `paper trail' monitoring system, in liaison with State authorities, to preserve the integrity of product in the export chain and improve safeguards preventing introduction into the export chain of product taken in breach of State legislation. The review also embraces an approach initiated through the Office of Regulation Review targeting the same area for attention.
This recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

The abalone issue raises the wider issue of the need for Commonwealth and State co-operation on enforcement issues generally. There are a number of high value species which may be readily smuggled across State borders to evade catch restrictions. . . .The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy initiate an investigation into the possible scope of this problem and methods through which it may be addressed in co-operation with other state governments. (Paragraph 7.36)
The former Australian and New Zealand Fisheries and Aquaculture Council established a National Task Force to address the problem of illegal fish sales with abalone a priority for consideration.

The work outlined in recommendation 26 above is now being progressed by the National Task Force. AQIS is represented on this Task Force, together with fish law enforcement officers from the States and Territories.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.
The Committee recommends that regulations be introduced to prohibit the dumping of commercially marketable species. (Paragraph 7.40)

The Committee further recommends that regulations be introduced to permit bycatch to be declared as such, and sold through normal commercial channels. This notification should preferably be by way of radio notification of a registered fish receiver (such as a co-op) prior to landing or by the furnishing of a return to the receiver or a fisheries officer immediately on returning to port. The proceeds of sales should then be placed in a trust fund to be established and controlled by each MAC for that purpose and subsequently used solely to fund research projects within that fishery. (Paragraph 7.41)
The Committee recommends overcatch provisions similar to those recommended for bycatch be developed and implemented. (Paragraph 7.42)

The Committee further recommends that where quota is overcaught during the last trip of the season, the extent to which the quota is overcaught should be deducted from the following years' quota allocation. (Paragraph 7.43)

The Committee recognises that this recommendation may be viewed by some as a possible method of evading catch restrictions, particularly if there is a perception that the bycatch provisions can be used as a fallback position to escape prosecution when a catch is subjected to inspection. This is not the Committee's intention. It therefore further recommends that stringent penalties be applied for failure to declare bycatch, including forfeiture of quota and gear. (Paragraph 7.44)

Recommendations 28 to 32 all relate to the management of bycatch and overcatch. The Government is fully aware of the problems and complexity of issues surrounding these matters and concurs with the Committee that both bycatch and overcatch must be minimised. To this end the Government sees merit in encouraging operators to land all marketable fish where this does not contravene State and/or Commonwealth law.

Developing options to resolve these issues is best left to fisheries managers, fisheries scientists, fisheries economists and the industry itself. To this extent, AFMA and its MACs are thoroughly examining all possible options, including those suggested in recommendations 28 to 32, with a view to improving the management arrangements.

AFMA is consulting with industry through the MAC process on how to reduce the incidence of dumping and high grading. It is seeking to provide more flexibility to operators to account for bycatch and over catch without undermining the integrity of the quota management system. In 1994 AFMA implemented, on a trial basis, arrangements to deduct up to 10 percent of an operator's quota to take account of overcatch from the previous season. Overcatch by an operator as a result of the last trip of the year, as noted by the Committee, would be taken into account under this arrangement, providing that the extent of the year's overcatch was no greater than 10 per cent of the operator's quota. The arrangement has been renewed for 1995 but at the 20 percent level of variation. On bycatch and overcatch in general, the Government supports, in-principle, the collection of all data but notes that enforcement of such a provision would prove extremely expensive and, be well nigh impossible. Cooperative measures with industry are being sought.
The intent of these recommendations is supported and the matters raised are being followed up by the Government.
The Committee recommends that:
where a vessel and/or catch is seized under s84(1)(b) of the Management Act, written notice of the grounds for the seizure be forwarded to the vessel owners within seven days;
This recommendation is supported and an amendment to the Act has now been passed by Parliament.
the circumstances under which a vessel may be seized and the conditions under which it may be released be reviewed;

This recommendation is supported. However, careful consideration must be given to all circumstances before a vessel is seized. The factors taken into account before a decision is made to seize include:
the severity of the offence;
whether, on the evidence available, it is likely the offence will be committed again unless seizure occurs;
the need to obtain material for evidentiary purposes; and
whether a successful conviction may lead to forfeiture of the vessel.
Any review of the conditions under which a vessel may be released must balance the needs of the owner and the ability to satisfy an order of forfeiture.

mechanisms for the disposal of seized catch be reviewed with the objective of preventing loss of income for both the fisher (in the event that charges are subsequently withdrawn or dismissed) or the Commonwealth (in the event that prosecutions are successful). (Paragraph 7.53)

This recommendation is supported. With a perishable product like fish it is important to act quickly when deciding on disposal action. When storage of the catch is considered impractical the established practice has been to sell it. When selling the catch utmost care is taken to ensure a maximum return is obtained. Consideration is given to the condition of the catch, availability of processors willing to purchase the catch, location of those purchasers and the price offered to ensure prices are maximised.
The intent of the actions suggested in this recommendation are supported. AFMA will be asked to review these matters and consult with the Attorney-General's Department.

The aim of the review is to identify industry and Government obligations in the cost of fisheries management measured against the objective of user-pays and the principle of cost recovery. The Committee is concerned that industry is not represented directly as a member of the review group. Given that consultation and communication are always cited as vital to effective fisheries management it is hard to understand why industry has been excluded from the process. Accordingly the Committee recommends that an industry representative be appointed as a matter of priority. (Paragraph 8.10)
The Government has implemented this recommendation. Representatives of the National Fishing Industry Council (NFIC) attended meetings and NFIC provided additional comment on the final report.

The Committee recommends that AFMA look much more critically at the presentation of its financial information and consult more than has been the case to date about how useful it is to industry and how it could be improved. For its part industry must insist on accurate useful information and work closely with AFMA to obtain it. (Paragraph 8.31)
This recommendation is supported and AFMA will continue working closely with its clients on improving the presentation of financial information to both industry and Government.

The Committee recommends that the FRDC consult with the prawn industry to confirm the level of support for the proposal [for a levy to assist promotional activities] and develop recommendations for government as to the most appropriate method of implementing it. (Paragraph 8.40)

Following discussions with industry, the Government announced in July 1994 that it was willing to raise industry funds to assist promotion of Australian sea caught prawns in overseas markets. Legislation was introduced into Parliament in late 1994 and is expected to become law during the first half of 1995. The FRDC was included in consultations.

While the Committee acknowledges that the Government's undertaking to industry referred to overall costs, the Committee recommends that AFMA review the levies of the SEF and SSF to ensure they do not exceed 1990/91 levels in real terms. (Paragraph 8.46).

Management costs must reflect the true costs of implementing the appropriate arrangements. This recommendation is not supported since there is no reason why levies in a fishery should remain static given the changing circumstances of its resources and the degree of compliance from fishers. It should be noted that the industry contributes, by way of levies, an amount equivalent to less than 3.5% of the gross value of the fishery. Levies payable in these and other AFMA managed fisheries were reviewed as part of the 1993-94 budget process with the Government's commitment on containing management costs in mind.
The recommendation is not supported

Useful information is needed by fishers and MACs if they are to make effective management decisions. Until the budget preparation stage in 1993/94 this detailed financial information had not been available. While it is being produced and distributed, it is still not in a form that is readily absorbed by industry. To overcome this situation, the Committee recommends that AFMA look much more critically at the presentation of its financial information, with regard to its usefulness to industry and how it can be improved. (Paragraph 8.47)

AFMA is working with its MACs to provide financial information in the most useful form. Given the progress made in this area since it was established, AFMA is confident that it will be able to satisfy the needs of both industry and public accountability generally.
The recommendation is supported (similar to 35 above).

NFIC is supportive of the changed direction of CSIRO's research and the level of communication with fishers. It is NFIC's view that to break this effort up and centralise it would be to jeopardise the gains made in the last few years and would take away access to the other support facilities that CSIRO researchers are able to draw upon. The Committee supports this view and recommends against a change in research agency structure at this stage. (Paragraph 9.10)

The issue of the most appropriate structure for Commonwealth marine research organisations was the subject of the McKinnon report Review of Marine Research Organisations (1993). In its response to the McKinnon report the Government did not change marine research structures.
The recommendation is supported.

The Committee recommends that FRDC's concerns about the wording of their legislation be reviewed taking account of the difficulties experienced by applicants in understanding the legislation. The Committee believes it should be possible to simplify the wording of the legislation to put it into `plain English'. FRDC should support this approach by providing supplementary documentation that clearly and simply explains its role and the way the funding process works. (Paragraph 9.13)

The Government agrees that legislation should be expressed as clearly as possible and advises that this matter will be examined during any future review of the FRDC. The FRDC has since adopted an approach whereby it provides supplementary documentation to research funding applicants.
The recommendation is supported and this matter will be examined during any future review of the FRDC.

The Committee shares the concern about the need for long term stock assessment which it regards as being fundamental to fisheries management. The Committee recommends that this issue be taken up not only by FRDC but also by AFMA to ensure that it achieves the appropriate priority. (Paragraph 9.16)

The Government strongly supports this recommendation. For each major fishery, AFMA has established fisheries assessment groups, made up of fishermen and researchers (both biologists and economists). These groups look specifically at stock assessment needs. They report to their MAC, in most fisheries through the MAC Research Sub-committee. The fisheries assessment groups will complement the more detailed research work already being undertaken by Commonwealth agencies which is supported by Commonwealth and industry funding.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

The Committee believes there is a need to recognise the prominent part that aquaculture will play in adding value to Australia's fisheries. The Committee is supportive of the efforts of the FRDC in this area through its funding commitment and recommends that it work closely with the states to ensure co-ordination of funding and efforts. (Paragraph 9.22)

The Government supports this recommendation and notes that aquaculture is one of four research programs administered by the FRDC. The FRDC already works closely with the States on aquaculture issues through the Fisheries Research Advisory Bodies (FRAB) that it has established in each State and the Northern Territory. In addition, the FRDC has explored with the aquaculture Cooperative Research Centre (CRC) ways in which the CRC can link into the FRAB process. Like the FRDC projects, CRC research projects will better meet the needs of industry and minimise duplication.
The aquaculture industry, like the wild capture sector of the fishing industry, contributes financially to the FRDC.

Recognising the potential for aquaculture to play in adding value to fish and fish products, in June 1994 the Government launched the National Strategy on Aquaculture in Australia. The strategy was prepared by the Standing Committee on Fisheries and Aquaculture with contributions from industry and academia. Close industry involvement in research and development is one of the key planks in the strategy.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

The Committee recommends that a more formalised consultation process between industry and those responsible for decisions about research funding should be established. The FRDC make extensive use of state research advisory boards and the MACs to gather information about industry research needs as well as to provide a filter for research proposals. AFMA should work with the FRDC to facilitate this process. (Paragraph 9.29)

Since its establishment, AFMA has put considerable effort into consultation between industry and those responsible for decisions about research funding and has appointed a research member to each MAC it has established. It is the responsibility of this member to convene a Research Sub-committee, with appropriate industry and research membership. This Sub-committee is responsible for recommending research priorities.

AFMA has established its own Research Committee, with appropriate Board and staff membership. This Committee is responsible for ensuring that the MAC Research Sub-committees are operating effectively and for developing overall AFMA research priorities between and across fisheries.

AFMA has also been working closely with the FRDC to ensure that its work is coordinated. AFMA is recognised by the FRDC as its Fisheries Research Advisory Body (FRAB) for Commonwealth managed fisheries. It must, however, be recognised that AFMA controls very limited research funding directly and is almost entirely dependent upon the FRDC and the Fisheries Resources Research Fund (FRRF) to ensure that its research needs are met.
The recommendation is supported and is being implemented.

The Committee recommends that the FRRF administration be removed from the control of DPIE and be allocated directly to ABARE, BRS and AFMA according to a formula to be determined. Formalising this arrangement will provide a certainty of funding to ABARE and BRS so that they can put in place ongoing research programs instead of what were referred to as the current ad hoc arrangements. For its part AFMA must have funds available to it to devote to public interest issues in the fisheries it controls and which cannot be funded from other sources. (Paragraph. 32)
Revised arrangement for administering the FRRF have been introduced following a separate review of rural research arrangements.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter Ten: Australia's international fisheries obligations

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Parliament proceed forthwith the Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 to ensure Australia's laws reflect the legal regime accepted in international law and contained in UNCLOS as quickly as practicable. (Paragraph 10.18)

The Maritime Legislation Amendment Act 1994 entered into force on 16 November 1994. Australia ratified the Convention (UNCLOS) prior to its entry into force. The Act brings Australian domestic legislation into line with the legal regime provided for in UNCLOS. This includes the declaration of an exclusive economic zone within which Australia may explore, exploit, conserve and manage living and non-living natural resources.
The recommendation is supported and has been implemented.

The Committee recommends that all Commonwealth fishery authorities should consult with the wider industry to identify and discuss potential international fishing problems, consider alternatives and negotiate agreed courses of action. The key to this recommendation is the transparency of the process; industry must be able to see that consultation is the means to resolve issues not to lose rights, privileges or past practices. (Paragraph 10.27)

The Government agrees with this recommendation. The need to consult with the wider industry to identify and discuss potential international fisheries problems will be brought to the attention of all Commonwealth fisheries agencies. At the same time, the States will be consulted where it is appropriate to do so.
The recommendation is supported. The Government will notify all appropriate agencies accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It is almost a year to the day since this report was presented to the Senate. From my short time in this place, three years, it would seem to me that a year is an extraordinarily long time for a government to respond to a report from a Senate standing committee, particularly a report as important as this report into the adequacy of the fisheries legislation, entitled Fisheries reviewed. In the letter to Senator Childs, who was chairman of the committee at the time this inquiry was conducted, the Minister for Resources highlights the amount of time that was taken in compiling this report and the fact that evidence was taken at 13 public hearings from around 90 witnesses. Senator Coulter was a part of that inquiry for some of the time.

PARA.TAB: It was a very important inquiry which covered a large range of issues. We as a committee finally came up with unanimous recommendations as to what we felt should take place in the fishing industry. The recommendations covered all sorts of matters, such as the management advisory committees, the resources, the stocks, and how the fishing industry could best be administered. We made some very important recommendations in the report Fisheries reviewed. Having taken 12 months almost to the day for the government to respond to that report, I was very concerned to find the following amongst the responses to the various recommendations. In recommendation 10 the committee considered the issue of the management advisory committee membership. At the end it says that the government will take up these issues with both the AFMA and the industry. After 12 months of the report having been lodged in the Senate I would have hoped that the government would have done more than just consider taking up these issues; I would have hoped it would have already taken them up.

The committee also spent considerable time dealing with some of the specific problems that confront Lord Howe Island. I was disappointed to note that in the government's response some of the recommendations which were unanimous by the committee were not supported by the government, particularly in relation to the complete closure around places such as Balls Pyramid and Lord Howe Island in general. That was recommended for the protection of the fish stocks in those areas on behalf of the people on Lord Howe Island who particularly rely on fishing for their survival and as the source for much of the food for the tourist operations that Lord Howe Island is so well known for. So I am disappointed that in relation to many of those recommendations the government has not supported the people on Lord Howe Island.

Although the government says recommendation 17, which deals with offshore arrangements and jurisdictional arrangements, is being supported and implemented, it seems to me there is certainly a long way to go. Recommendation 24 talks about legal advice with regard to paper trails and how we can somehow improve the situation within the industry. We have recommended that AFMA seek advice on how the problem may be addressed. The government's response is that the recommendation is supported and the government will seek advice on this important issue. It now being 12 months after the report was adopted by the Senate, I would have thought that it is time for the government to be doing more than just talking about seeking advice. I would have hoped that that advice had already been sought and the recommendations put into place.

I do not want to take up much of the Senate's time today, but I would just like to say that I am disappointed with this response. I know that it has taken 12 months, almost to the day, for the government to respond to a report that has a significant number of recommendations. People in the fishing industry have been very concerned because some of the recommendations concerned major issues to do with management advisory committees, with total allowable catch quotas and with jurisdictional matters.

While I am pleased that the government has responded to many of the recommendations and has put them in place, I think some of the more difficult issues have been left aside. I hope that, in relation to the recommendations where we see the government has responded `we will seek advice', `it is being implemented' or `at some stage in the future, it may implement the recommendation', the government will very quickly act on the recommendations that are in that report for the benefit of the people whom we were trying to make sure are looked after: those involved in the fishing industry, which is so important to this nation of ours.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to follow on from what Senator Ferguson has said in relation to the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Fisheries reviewed. There is no doubt that we are managing the fish stocks of Australia very poorly indeed, and there is no doubt that that is part of a pattern of poor management throughout the world.

PARA.TAB: In recent years, the fish garnered from the oceans have declined. Many of the fish stocks are in a very parlous state indeed. When the legislation to which this report refers first came before the Senate, the committee to which Senator Ferguson referred reviewed a package of legislation which set up AFMA in the first place. As a result of the very extensive committee deliberations, if I recall correctly, some 83 or 86 amendments got into that package of legislation. The working of the legislation was then reviewed, and it is the government's response to that review that we are now looking at.

The situation is still, as I indicated earlier, very unsatisfactory. It seems as though a few fisheries in Australia are being managed on a sustainable basis, but many of the fisheries certainly are a long way from that. In addition to that, we recently laid claim to the 200 nautical miles around Australia. The day that that was announced Minister Cook spoke in over-optimistic terms about the ability to exploit the northern tuna across Australia, yet we had CSIRO scientists telling us that we knew virtually nothing about the fish stocks, about the life cycle of those fish, about their migratory habits and so on. We have a government that is hellbent on repeating the mistakes of the past without adequately doing research. CSIRO went on to point out that it needed some $100 million in additional funding to carry out research work adequately.

In recent days I have advertised for a two-day a week position in my office. One of the applicants for that position is a former CSIRO scientist and an expert on fisheries research—a man with three pages of publications to his name—who has remained unemployed for 12 years. We have a number of these highly qualified people around Australia who could help us in this work, and yet we find the government is very stingy with the resource backing required to carry out this research work—research work on which the proper management of our fisheries would be based.

Recently I looked at the amount of money Australia is spending on research generally. Australia is spending 1.3 per cent of GDP compared with 2.6 per cent for the United States of America. Even South Korea is spending five per cent of GDP on research. In view of the fact that the budget is coming up, the plea I make to the government is that scientific research generally is an area that needs a great deal more support and the fishing area specifically needs a great deal more research effort, particularly with respect to the ignorance regarding the 200 nautical miles around Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—In accordance with provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present on behalf of the President the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 24 of 1994-95—Follow-up audit—Northern Land Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will recall that in 1993 as a result of action that I instigated in the Senate estimates process an Auditor-General's report was called for and commissioned by the minister and subsequently tabled in parliament in December 1993. That audit report was entitled Report No. 20 of 1993-94: Efficiency audit—Northern Land Council. It referred specifically to various matters relating to the Northern Land Council. Report No. 20, and again I remind the Senate it was tabled in December 1993, made some 52 recommendations relating to various aspects of the financial operations of the Northern Land Council—52 recommendations of a very serious and complex nature.

PARA.TAB: The report that we have before us today, some 15 or 16 months later, is the subsequent and required follow-up audit that was agreed would be undertaken after 12 months. This report concerns me. I notice on the last page of the report, page 33, there is an appendix which sets out the status of the various recommendations. As I mentioned, there were 52 recommendations. One has obviously dropped off in the counting due to arrangements within a financial year. But I notice from the schedule on page 33 that action has been completed and obviously met with satisfactory recommendations with regard to 24 of the recommendations, further action is still required with regard to 22 of the recommendations and action has not yet commenced on five of the recommendations. So some 27 recommendations of the original 52 are still outstanding and require attention.

The Auditor-General's office makes note of the significant action that has been taken by the Northern Land Council with regard to a number of issues. I suppose that is important. It is important to put that on the record, but I remind the Senate that it is in respect of only 24 of the original 52 recommendations that that credit has been given.

I still consider that the action of the Northern Land Council has not been dealt with with sufficient urgency. I do not believe the minister has involved himself sufficiently in the areas that are still of concern and about which the Auditor-General's office is still making some quite serious allegations and requests for further attention.

Whilst these audit reports are often written in the language of appeasement, we need to go very much into the detail of them. Whilst you can read the key findings and the general summary points and it would appear on a first glance that they are satisfactory, that is not so. As I said, five of the recommendations have not been actioned and some 22 of them require further action.

Let us look specifically at some of the issues that do require particular and further attention. It is important that we not let slip the necessary pressure that is needed on groups and organisations such as the Northern Land Council. I do not wish to appear to be vindictive in any way, but what we need to remember here is that the funds that flow to the Northern Land Council are moneys in trust. The funds are derived from consolidated revenue, from the raising of royalty equivalents, and they are then earmarked for the administrative action of the land councils. Very often the land councils have to lucky dip into those royalty trust funds in order to top up their administration. This denies Aboriginal people other benefits.

The issues where follow-up is required relate to the administration of the royalty trust accounts, the advances to council members, the use of fringe benefits tax arrangements for staff, the use and engagement of consultants, the control of expenditure and the section 64 funding and distribution of surpluses.

The administration of royalty trust accounts is an issue about which I consider the minister has long been totally derelict in the discharge of his requirements under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. It is now some 16 months later and we are still seeing the Auditor-General comment on issues that require detailed further assessment. I would certainly encourage anyone who is looking at this matter to go to the detailed parts of this report and look at the continuing issues where the recommendation is that a review of the royalty payment procedures should be undertaken to ensure that they are complete.

The other matter in this section I wish to talk about is the use of fringe benefits arrangements for staff. Some senators may recall that back in 1993 when I raised this issue I was certainly pursuing the special arrangements that had been put in place for the previous director of the Northern Land Council, Mr Mick Dodson, who is now the Social Justice Commissioner for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs for the Labor government. A very special, generous arrangement was put in place and we have never seen the full details of that arrangement. This report highlights that those arrangements had not yet been properly dealt with.

The fact that the Department of Industrial Relations has indicated that the application to senior staff was in breach of the Public Service Union (Central and Northern Land Councils) Award of 1990 is, to me, still a sore point. Mr Dodson has a lot to answer for because of the ineptitude of the administration of the land council during his period as director, which resulted in all of these 52 major recommendations being made, and also because of his dereliction of duty with regard to the administration of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account, of which he was a primary adviser during the entire period that has caused a lot of reviews in that particular area.

I am very concerned that the special fringe benefits arrangements have not yet been concluded. That is one of the issues the Auditor-General is now calling into question. It in turn must call into question Mr Dodson's capability, capacity and qualification to go on acting as the Social Justice Commissioner until such time as these matters have been properly concluded.

Naturally, the issues relating to control of expenditure worry me, as do those that relate to the funding and distribution of surpluses. With regard to the general management, there are comments with regard to outstanding issues relating to leave fares, debt recovery processes, the use of fuel cards and motor vehicles. These are all significant because of the example organisations such as land councils must give to so many other organisations in the whole area of the Aboriginal portfolio.

If a parent body or an umbrella organisation such as the Northern Land Council continues to receive the criticism and rebuke of the Auditor-General and if it cannot get its books in order or its accounts properly administered within a period of some 16 months, then we do need to look very carefully at these areas. In fact, it must be a matter about which Mr Tickner, as the responsible minister, must take full responsibility.

This is a very concerning report. I am concerned that some 16 months later further issues are arising. Of course, there is no mention of what happens now. There should be a subsequent review. I do not believe that the Auditor-General's office can in any way think this is the final report on the matter. The fact that 27 of 52 recommendations have not been satisfactorily answered demands that the Auditor-General continue to take a close monitoring role in this particular area—whether it is a review of the minister's responsibility and the activities of the parent body, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, or whether it is with regard to the express issues that relate to the Northern Land Council.

I am certainly well aware that the Northern Land Council is still engaged in a number of very controversial arrangements in the Northern Territory, particularly with regard to the royalty area. It is engaged in a major Federal Court action at the moment with the Gagudju Association. Because of those particular issues, there is no way the Northern Land Council can continue to be considered in any way a satisfactory organisation until these matters are properly concluded. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Carr, I present additional information received by the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee during its consideration of the additional estimates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports: Report No. 1 of 1995, Refurbishment of Scarborough House and construction of Commonwealth offices, Phillip, ACT; and report No. 2 of 1995, Redevelopment of housing for service families at Land Warfare Centre, Canungra, Queensland. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: The report relating to the refurbishment of Scarborough House in the construction of Commonwealth offices at Phillip, ACT, is the committee's first report for 1995. The objective of this proposal, which is sponsored by Australian Estate Management, is to provide modern office accommodation for the Australian Industrial Property Organisation. Senators may be more familiar with its former title of the Patent Designs and Trademarks Office.

PARA.TAB: AEM is proposing an extensive refurbishment and fitout of Scarborough House's 14 office floors, ground floor, basement, roof and facade, and is proposing minor works to the building surrounds. Scarborough House will be upgraded to a standard commensurate with current commercial office building standards. The proposed annex building will consist of a new two-wing, five-level commercial standard office building with central atrium and associated landscaping. The committee has recommended that the project proceed at an estimated outturn cost of $50.38 million at July 1994 prices.

The objectives of AEM, as the sponsoring agency, are to provide accommodation to meet the needs of AIPO; to protect the Commonwealth's investment in Scarborough House by maintaining its income capacity; and to reduce the Commonwealth's overall property costs through a well managed portfolio of owned office buildings. Scarborough House has not had a major upgrade of services, structure or finishes since it was constructed in 1970. The committee was advised by AEM at the public hearing that a condition audit of Scarborough House indicated that it is now well below acceptable, modern, commercial office standards, particularly in the area of occupational health and safety requirements and is considered to be at the end of its current commercial life.

In order to ensure the building retains its value as an asset of the Commonwealth, AEM believes that an extensive refurbishment is now required. AIPO has occupied the entire building since 1971. Various options for the redevelopment of Scarborough House, with a view to satisfying AIPO's accommodation requirements, have been investigated over recent years. AIPO's accommodation requirements had identified the need for a significant increase in space and the need to co-locate in the Woden office centre precinct. AIPO believes that the fragmentation of its office accommodation results in inefficiencies and increased costs, including time wasted in personnel movement, delivery costs and transport costs.

The committee was advised that a range of options were developed and investigated both to satisfy AIPO's accommodation requirements and to provide the Commonwealth with a satisfactory financial investment. This attitude fits in with our normal process. The committee is satisfied that the proposal which is the subject of this first report for 1995 represents an effective accommodation solution at an affordable cost for AIPO, will provide value for money for the Commonwealth as it extends the useful life of an existing asset and will provide an additional Commonwealth owned office building to meet a long-term need.

The second report which I have tabled recommends redevelopment of housing for service families at the Land Warfare Centre at Canungra, Queensland, at an estimated cost of $7.86 million. Families at Canungra are presently living in timber frame houses clad with asbestos sheeting. These pre-1960 style houses are substandard and contribute to personnel and family problems. At the public hearing, the Tenant Consultative Group advised the committee that the morale of families currently occupying these houses is at its lowest ebb. The committee inspected this accommodation and agreed that a need exists to provide suitable housing for those defence personnel and their families. Again, it is in line with the attitude of upgrading housing for defence personnel generally.

The Defence Housing Authority proposes to remove 47 houses in the Boike Road and Corcoran Crescent precincts. One existing house will be upgraded, and 26 houses built in the Corcoran Crescent precinct. Twenty-nine houses will be constructed in the Boike Road precinct. The houses in Corcoran Crescent will be replaced with larger houses on bigger blocks of land. The larger blocks extend beyond the existing lot boundaries but do not encroach on the surrounding bushland. Two-storey houses will be built on the smaller blocks. This will provide a variety of housing in the area.

In the public hearing at Canungra, the Tenant Consultative Group advised the committee that it is satisfied with the consultative process with the Defence Housing Authority, which has always been willing to listen to its views. The houses will be fitted with earth leakage circuit breakers and smoke detectors. The Defence Housing Authority has advised the committee that it has a retrofit program for the installation of earth leakage circuit breakers and smoke detectors in all of its houses already constructed. The committee commends the Defence Housing Authority on this decision. The committee believes that the proposal will provide defence personnel and their families with good quality housing consistent with community standards. I commend the reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning I informally talked to the opposition, the Australian Democrats and the Greens in a meeting convened about our approach to the draft Senate legislative program for this, the last week of the sittings. At that meeting, I outlined the sorts of constraints that we face in this last week. A number of suggestions have been canvassed, including the possibility of forgoing general business this week and of maximising utilisation of lunch hours so that that time can be used, if not for non-controversial legislation, then for second reading speeches.

PARA.TAB: We looked at the possibility of the Senate sitting a little earlier tomorrow—between the hours of 12.30 p.m. and 2.00 p.m.—to deal with second reading speeches. That is a matter that we might advise on at a later stage. Those sitting hours would mirror those of the House of Representatives. Question time would be at 2.00 p.m. with prayers at 12.30. I await advice from the opposition on its approach to that. The Senate might deal with that matter at a later stage.

It seems to me that the maximum opportunity for ensuring that we have our best shot at the much truncated and revised legislative program lies in our being as flexible as we can with our sitting hours. It is for that reason that I propose we agree to the motion standing in Senator Crowley's name that we meet through to the hour of 10.30 p.m. tonight and also on Tuesday and Thursday night of this week.

I am hopeful that, with the cooperation of all senators and with the continued good management of the Senate, this revised legislative program will be dealt with in its entirety in the course of this sitting week. I point out to the Senate that a very substantial number of bills have been removed from the legislative program. It had been the government's intention to deal with them.
