I ask for the support of all senators in this very sensible approach to good management and to dealing with the pressure of work before us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a question of good management. In this session of parliament, there has been no management at all. That, in fact, is the problem. As a result of that lack of management, we come to the last week of the sittings and see that the government finds—as is so often the case—that its bills have stacked up, and it does not have time to complete its program. So it comes to other senators and asks whether they will agree to extending the program and the sitting times of the Senate on three of the sitting days this week.

PARA.TAB: We are prepared to be more than reasonable in other respects. I think that anyone who looks at the time taken by the opposition during this period of the parliament will see that, in matters of public importance and the like, we have probably introduced fewer debates than I can remember. That should have very much facilitated the government's timetable.

We are still prepared to be cooperative. We are prepared to concede our Thursday afternoon general business this week, which the government can now take up with its legislative program, but we are not prepared to agree to the extension for the three nights that have been suggested—tonight, Tuesday and Thursday—because someone has to make an attempt to keep this government honest. Once upon a time the Australian Democrats used to boast that that was their function. But they abandoned that some time after the departure of Senator Chipp.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have heard this message before.

—They have. Since then, the Australian Democrats have slotted very firmly into the Labor Party camp. Basically, if the government asks them for an extension of sittings for three days of this week, they will simply give it the nod. They are very closely aligned to the Australian Labor Party these days. I keep warning them about it. It is why they are slipping so badly in the polls. People can now not see a distinction between the Australian Democrats and the ALP; that is how firmly they have become enmeshed. It is not in their best interests, but they seem to not want to take that advice from me, generously given though it is.
—You should try to keep a straight face.
—One only has to look at the results election after election. There is no rationale—
—What has that got to do with this motion?

—It has to do with the fact that in this chamber only the coalition is prepared to try to keep the government to a program. The government has a responsibility to bring to this place its legislative program in an orderly form so that the Senate might have a reasonable time to debate each and every one of its bills. We are happy to do that; it is our responsibility. But, on the other hand, the government is not prepared to manage its program in that way. So, again, we have seen a stacking of bills during the last week.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that we did not agree to these new sitting times of the Senate. This decision was again imposed on us by others in this chamber—the government, the Australian Democrats and at least one other group—in opposition to us. We were told that, under these sitting hours, the government, with reasonable management, would be able to meet its program without having to extend the sittings. Now that it has come to the test for the second time, it has again failed.

The government knows that at the end of the session it can simply demand extra sitting time and get it, unless parties within the Senate are prepared to stand up to the government and say, `You have been elected to govern. It is now your responsibility to manage the program of this place efficiently and properly.' That is why I will not agree to the government's proposal today. It has failed in its planning. It is now coming to us, on the basis of that failure, and saying, `Notwithstanding our errors, facilitate our program.' Once we agree to that, it knows that on each and every occasion it can demand the same thing. It is about time it put some effort into programming.

As I said the other day when this matter was raised, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) has had other priorities in this session. He has had a lot of trouble with the environment portfolio. But if he was unable to manage the government business, he should have passed that responsibility over to somebody else. We would then not be in the mess that we are in at the moment.

We are sick and tired of the fact that constantly this Senate, under the leadership of the Australian Labor Party and, unfortunately, the votes of particularly the Australian Democrats, has been reducing the options and capability of the opposition and minority parties to play a full part. For example, time allocated for dealing with matters of public importance has been halved. The adjournment debate has been reduced. Speaking times for individual senators have been reduced. We thought that the Australian Democrats would have fought for the opportunity to contribute to these issues in this chamber and do what they were elected to do. The Australian Democrats have gone to water at the request of the government. Senators have had their opportunities curtailed. That has been at a loss to the democratic process.

This Senate is the one real chamber of debate within the federal parliamentary system in Australia. With each step that is taken by the government, in cohort with the Australian Democrats, to reduce that capacity, it is at a loss that will not be recovered. We never find the government bringing before this chamber proposals to extend the opportunity for contributions by individual senators. Every proposal that is brought here is designed to reduce that capability.

The government says it needs more time to get through its legislative program. Even with that extra time, at the end of the session it finds that it cannot meet its commitments. So it comes to the Senate and says, `We now need extra time. You should agree.' The Australian Democrats nod. They say, `We will agree to whatever the ALP wants.' But we will not be treated in that way.

In a modest way, we know that we will lose. We will not again have the numbers. But we will at least attempt to keep this government honest for the short time that it will remain in office. Presuming that there will not be an election until next year, the minister will have two extra chances to put a bit of effort into the program and get it right. Perhaps we will not be engaging in a debate like this one. But the chances of that, based on the Labor Party's record, will be next to nil. The government should get the program within the hours that it set for the Senate and for which it got the agreement of the minor parties. It should not seek to impose these extra times at the end of the session. We will vote against this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I must thank Senator Hill for such a low level of abuse in that speech. He did not even raise his voice. I am amazed. He usually gets to screaming at about this point. I was interested to see how long it would take Senator Hill to get to his favourite theme in procedural matters, which is how evil the Australian Democrats are. He always gets to it pretty close to the beginning of his speech. It was within two minutes this time. It may be a new record. He then spent the next five or six minutes elaborating on his theme.

PARA.TAB: One of Senator Hill's favourite points in these themes is how the business of the Senate is extended beyond the sitting hours that are set down in the standing orders. According to him, the government does grubby little deals with the Democrats. If we look at a few really interesting statistics, perhaps he will change his mind about that. In 1994, we extended for 14 nights. There were two divisions where the opposition was upset about this. In 1993, we extended for 17 nights, and there were three divisions where the opposition was upset about this. In 1992, we extended for 24 nights, and there were seven divisions—a much higher number of divisions—where the opposition was upset about this. This leaves an awful lot of extensions where the opposition was not upset about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you put the hours on the record too?
—I am quite happy to.
—Are the hours irrelevant?
—No. The hours may or may not be irrelevant. It does not matter what this extension was for. Was this—
—Doesn't matter what the hours were?
—Just stop it! Opposition senators obviously do not like it very much, so I might tell them three or four times. I have half an hour; I might tell them 10 or 20 times. The question is—
—Please don't!

—Senator Faulkner says, `Please don't.' I will not. I will only do it once. The question is: what are the numbers in here when these extensions are agreed to? In the vast majority of cases, the answer is that the opposition votes with the government. What the Democrats think is irrelevant. The numbers show that the opposition agrees with the government that the time should be extended. That is what happens on most occasions. So the argument that the Democrats do this all the time is not true. The opposition is the fourth faction of the Labor Party. One can see that in divisions, because the opposition tends to vote with the Labor Party more than the Democrats vote with the Labor Party. Never mind. It is very sad, but that is the way that things go in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion, the Democrats believe that there are good reasons for most of the legislation that the government wants to finish this sittings. I am looking forward tomorrow to going through that legislation in the meeting that the Manager of Government Business has set up with the opposition, the Democrats and the independents to see what time we can expect to have available to go through those bills and how long he expects each bill to take.

We also believe that there is a glitch in the system which prevents us having an orderly program. The opposition, the Democrats, the independents or the Greens can send a bill off to a Friday committee for consideration and then that bill does not turn up on the notice paper when the government expected it to. That is not the fault of the government, it is because somebody has decided that a particular bill needs more scrutiny—and that is fair enough. That produces a glitch in the system and means that bills pile up towards the end of the sittings.
That is something we have to look at when we examine the way the new system works. Many opposition senators were in complete and utter agreement with the proposal to establish this new system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't hear any complaints about it now.

—Those of us who were in the chamber when we debated the proposal to change the hours and order of business were very interested to see who was speaking in favour of it and who was speaking against it. Many opposition senators spoke in favour of it, and rightly so. We will be looking at the hours and order of business.

PARA.TAB: We have to look at the way committee references can change the order of business. I am not really sure that there is an awful lot we can do about it, but I think we should all think about it and see whether there is a way to fix that glitch in the system. Meanwhile, we want to see most of the bills that the government wants finished before the end of the sittings—we have cut the list in half and we think that what it has is about right, but I will debate that with the minister, the opposition, the independents and the Greens tomorrow—go through.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens will be supporting this motion at this time, but only on the understanding that the Greens will not be supporting any further extension of time beyond the 10.30 p.m. extension on Monday, Tuesday and Thursday. We have said that if the Senate needs, say, 10 minutes to complete a bill then we would consider that on its merits. We do not believe that there should be any extension of time beyond that which is proposed in this motion.

PARA.TAB: We are unable to support the intrusion on our time at 12.30 p.m. tomorrow—if it is in fact being debated in this motion; I believe it may be coming up later—because it is too late for us to alter our plans. We believe that all speeches at the second reading stage are of value and we do not want to reduce the value that this chamber places on any part of the scrutiny of legislation. That is the first reason for not extending the times any further, regardless.

Our second reason is that we believe that the discussions between the opposition, the Democrats, the Greens, Senator Harradine, Senator Devereux and Senator Faulkner regarding the streamlining and cutting down of the list of bills we are expected to complete in the extended hours to a more realistic level should continue. We understand that those discussions will continue.

The third reason for us reluctantly supporting this motion is that we believe that the government should thoroughly review its method of processing its legislation to reduce the quantity of legislation that is being brought into this place and prioritise it better. Finally, we believe that the Procedures Committee should undertake a detailed study of the present Senate timetable and produce a new plan which all parties agree to and allocates adequate time to the business that the Senate is considering.

On that basis, we indicate our support. Again, we give fair warning that this is not going to happen sittings after sittings. We believe that this is a signal to thoroughly review the timetable and the way in which the Senate is being forced to address government business. We believe we should limit the scrutiny that these important pieces of legislation require in order to fit them into the time available and weeks available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some grave concerns about the proposal currently before the chamber and, in particular, the suggestion that the starting time tomorrow be 12.30 p.m. That means we would go through the lunch break tomorrow. If the government says that all of these pieces of legislation are important, it is a contradiction in terms to suggest that the debate on the legislation take place when 99 per cent of senators are otherwise engaged or at appointments which, in many cases, do not involve lunch.
—It is only second reading speeches.

—They are important matters. Are you suggesting that just because they are speeches at the second reading stage that others should not hear and attempt to understand why certain senators are in favour of the legislation and certain senators are against the legislation?
—I have just noticed how many people are normally sitting in here when they are on.
—So have I. (Quorum formed) It has been pointed out to me that this motion does not incorporate the proposal to meet at 12.30 tomorrow. Therefore, I am probably out of order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—If you are going to talk about meeting at 12.30 tomorrow, you are out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that I am out of order. I think the Senate as a whole must be very concerned about the list of bills that confronts us. In my view, a number of pieces of legislation should not be regarded as so very urgent as to be incorporated into the list for discussion this week. One of those is the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4).

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators would know, that piece of legislation attempts to overturn the principles contained in a decision of the Federal Court which granted refugee status to a married couple. The woman was eight months pregnant when she arrived in Australia; she later gave birth to the child. They had a well-established fear of persecution if they were returned to China—the persecution being compulsory sterilisation. The couple established that to everyone's satisfaction; there was no question about the fact that they would be forcibly sterilised.

Under the refugee convention, you have to establish not only that you have a fear which is well founded—bringing in the objective as well as the subjective nature of that fear—but also that it would be because of a convention reason: namely, because of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a particular social group. You can be absolutely certain that you are going to face persecution if you return to your persecutors but, unless you can jump that second hurdle, you are not eligible for refugee status. The judge held that the first four reasons were not relevant. Therefore, he decided that the couple were members of a particular social group—namely, parents with one child who were identified and targeted by China's fertility control policy, which they resisted.

This bill which the government wants to pass would mean that those persons would not be able to jump that hurdle. In other words, this bill in effect says to the courts and the independent refugee tribunal that, no matter what suffering and persecution people will face if they are returned to the PRC, they will not be able to jump that second hurdle because, in determining whether or not the refugee is a member of a particular social group, the fertility control policies of the PRC must be disregarded. In effect, the legislation will deny refugee status to an asylum seeker who has a well-founded fear of sterilisation or coerced abortion under China's fertility control policy if returned to China.

The government has appealed that decision to the full bench of the Federal Court. What I want to know—and this is relevant to this debate—is why the government wants to have that debate here. The only reason why the government wants to have the debate here—and I have this on very good authority—is that the government's legal advisers think it will lose the appeal to the full bench of the Federal Court.

I ask those senators with legal training who are in the chamber to consider what they are being asked to do. They are being asked to do the government's dirty work. The government will not, according to its legal advisers, be successful in its appeal to the full bench of the Federal Court. If I can develop support for my position, I will not be a party to giving the government by legislation what the courts will not give it in this very important matter which impinges upon the human rights of individuals.

If we did that, it would mean that Australia would be party to cruel, inhumane and degrading treatment of defenceless human beings, and I believe that would disqualify Australia from being a civilised country. I think people should understand very well what is happening on this matter. I urge honourable senators to have regard to, examine and not rely on the government's suggestion that it will establish a particular social group on a pre-existing social group. All of the legal advice that has come to me says that that will not enable persons in the situation before the court to jump the second hurdle. The government says that the minister has a non-compellable discretion. In my view, that would derogate from our obligations under an international convention—namely, the refugee convention.

I ask honourable senators to think about those matters, as they are very important. I ask the government to consider whether or not it now believes that this is a bill which is so urgent as to be part of this list of bills that we must get through this week. Because this legislation is opposed by people such as the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Amnesty International, the Law Council of Australia, various women's groups, refugee support groups, the Australian Catholic bishops and a whole range of religious organisations, I believe that it is incumbent upon this chamber to scrutinise this legislation minutely.

If the government thinks it is going to get that legislation through in five minutes, it has another think coming. The minister had better be very prepared before he comes into this chamber because I can see that the committee stage of that bill will be lengthy indeed. One of the principle functions of the Senate chamber is to protect the rights of minorities and to protect human rights and due process.

I again appeal to the lawyers in this chamber to ask themselves whether or not it is appropriate for us to have this piece of legislation fronted up to us because it is an attempt to overturn the principles of a Federal Court decision which the government is appealing to the full bench of the High Court. Why are we going to deal with it now? There has been no urgency suggested to us. There has been no case made out at all. Under those circumstances, I do not propose to vote for any extensions of time at this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very disappointed in the speech that Senator Hill made. It was one of his typical speeches trying to give a very Liberal Party glossed up analysis of what is happening in the Senate chamber. There was no mention at all of the time wasting of which the opposition parties have become absolute experts over the years.
—There is no basis for your saying that whatever.

—Well, senator, we have to look at the facts of the matter, which are that MPIs, urgency motions and suspensions of standing orders have cost an inordinate amount of time. One of the problems with what I believe was a very useful reform of the routine of business of this chamber is that the period that is dedicated for government business is not in fact dedicated for government business. There is an opportunity for all these other ruses and manipulations to be utilised. It inevitably cuts into the government's legislative program and it is very destructive.
—That's the Keating approach, isn't it?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! Senator Hill you are out of order. You should not interject when you are sitting out of your place.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want a bit of democracy.

—This is so typical of the sort of disorderly conduct that we are used to from Senator Hill. Your carping criticisms ought to be looked at from the perspective that it is very rare for the opposition to come forward with a positive idea about how to reform the Senate's legislative program, how to reform the routine of business, how we can perhaps better operate, how our procedures can be revamped. The opposition never puts forward a positive idea in relation to these sorts of matters.

PARA.TAB: Your approach is always a very mindless one. I suppose after so many years entrenched on the opposition benches you lose perspective of looking at these issues from what it might be like to be an alternative government. You have an oppositionist mentality. You do not come to these debates from the perspective of an alternative government at all, and quite rightly so in one sense because I suspect that that is probably the political reality.

When the government has put forward reform after reform after reform all you can do is be carping, negative critics of those very important reforms on sitting hours, the routine of business, the committee system and the length of second reading speeches. How many ideas have come forward from the opposition? None in the time that I have been manager of government business, not one. It is pretty miserable and very hypocritical for the opposition to come in here and make the sort of contribution that we have heard from Senator Hill.

The government is taking seriously its responsibility for good management of its own legislative program, with all the difficulties it faces in the Senate. My harshest critic cannot say that there has not always been every attempt to include the opposition, the minor parties and Independents in the good management of this chamber. There has been consultation. There has been a policy of inclusion. I have tried in both a formal and informal way to talk these sorts of issues through and the motion before you is a very good example of that same process working on this particular occasion.

I am quite confident that the Senate will reject the ritualistic contribution that has been made by Senator Hill yet again. Really, the thing to do with Senator Hill's speeches about procedural matters in the chamber is for Senator Hill to make one speech per session—they are always the same—and either keep distributing the Hansard copies or cassettes or video cassettes, if you like, of the same speech. They are very repetitive, senator. They are now very boring and I think you just have to come up with some new material. It is quite pathetic. You really have to come up with some new material or everyone will go to sleep. You have really been off your game since the Boothby preselection, I can tell you. I am sure the Senate will see the good sense of the motion that I have put forward.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Faulkner's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator MacGibbon did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Zakharov).

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 22 March.

DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994AUDIT (TRANSITIONAL AND MISCELLANEOUS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the amendment to clause 14 has been co-sponsored by both Senator Short and Senator Spindler. My reading of the numbers would indicate that this will pass, but I would like the opportunity to put on the record the government's opposition to that amendment.

—I do not want to hold the committee up. I think this clause has already been debated; Senator Gibson was handling it last week. Senator Crowley, can you tell me whether the government has actually given the committee the reason why it is opposing the clause? If it has, then I will read the record of last week but, if it has not, I think the committee deserves at least a brief explanation of why you are opposing the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Senator Cook will be returning here post haste. It may be that he can assist you more directly than I can. While we are waiting for Senator Cook, I will refer to his comments on page 16 of the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee Hansard of 3 March 1995. Senator Cook said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are really five reasons why we think performance audits in GBEs, understandably and reasonably, should not be conducted by the Auditor-General. All of them have a quite practical, real world aspect to them.

PARA.TAB: The first is that they do represent a peculiar add-on cost to a government business enterprise that is operating in the private sector under the disciplines of private sector regulation and private sector competition. As a consequence, we add a handicap to the saddlebags of the GBE.

The second point is the question of how we measure the performance of a government business enterprise in this sense. The best an audit of this sort can do is provide a snapshot of what is the case at that time. Measurement of the performance of a GBE is something else again. I do not think those audits can provide a basis for measurement of performance. Trading outcomes, return on capital and the amount of return to the Commonwealth are other matters—as well as market share and so on—that a GBE might have. I do not know whether the audit office is in a position to provide anything useful on that.

Thirdly, it gives a free kick to the competitors of the GBE in the sense that they do not have to go through that process—but the GBE does. I think that is a wrong weighting. The fourth point I make is that parliament has the means at its disposal, anyway, to ensure that the GBEs handle themselves properly. It does that, where it sees fit, by instituting an inquiry. I cite, for example, ANL.

It was the view of the minister for shipping, Laurie Brereton, that the Auditor-General should be called in to do an audit of ANL. Without going to the issues of the ANL, the Senate in its wisdom chose to conduct an inquiry and forwent the opportunity of the executive wing of government's invitation to the Auditor-General. In that sense, the Senate chose to override and inquire. I do not judge it in terms of what was appropriate; all I say is that it is an example of the parliament conducting a complete review of a particular entity for reasons that parliament saw as being of proper and appropriate concern.

It demonstrates that parliament does do these things and does have them under its purview. There is also the national performance monitoring committee, which is a body set up between the federal and state governments and which monitors all GBEs in the public sectors in the Commonwealth and in the state and territory jurisdictions. A monitoring performance on those GBEs is shared constitutionally now. To add an extra burden to that is inappropriate in my submission. I said there were five reasons; I have given you four. I have rolled the cost question into the add-on question of the extra time and effort a GBE might have to engage in to conduct such an audit.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope those reasons why the government does not support this amendment assist you, Senator Short.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the minister that the offer in relation to the Australian National Line was very limited. It was the offer of a full performance audit only to be available at the point at which Australian National Line was sold. It was worth nothing whatsoever in terms of accountability and scrutiny of the public or the parliament. That is why the Greens, amongst other people, chose to support an inquiry rather than the very limited offer. That is exactly why it is necessary for the parliament to have the ability to at least call for the Auditor-General to make full audits of these without having to wait for the permission of the minister or sometimes for the political reasons why permission has not been received from the minister.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 15.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 15, page 5 subclause (2), lines 1 to 5, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:

"(2) The Auditor-General may at any time conduct a performance audit of a Commonwealth company that is a GBE (other than a GBE accepted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit as a GBE with significant private sector financial ownership) or any of its subsidiaries.".

This amendment to clause 15 is the same amendment as Democrats amendment No. 3. This amendment is similar to the previous amendment relating to Commonwealth authorities that we have just agreed to. However, this clause applies to Commonwealth companies which are GBEs. Again, it is about ensuring that the Auditor-General has an unfettered mandate to carry out performance audits of taxpayer funded bodies.

PARA.TAB: The difference between this amendment and the previous one is that this amendment contains a provision to restrict the Auditor-General's mandate by decision of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit to exempt such government business enterprises which have `significant private sector financial ownership'. We consider it appropriate and proper that where GBEs are also partially privately owned, are under independent management and are accountable to all shareholders—not just to the Commonwealth—there ought to be scope for exemption. But the decision as to whether or not there should be an exemption ought to be determined by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit. I do not think I need to say anything else about that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with the previous amendment, the Australian Democrats not only support this amendment but also jointly move it with the opposition. This has been arranged, and I would appreciate it if this were so recorded.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arguments for this amendment are similar to those for the amendment to clause 14. I will not repeat them, except to say that it is necessary to establish a strong mandate for the Auditor-General. This is absolutely vital and consistent with best practice in the states and the Commonwealth. The only difference between our amendment and the original amendment of the opposition was that we replaced the word `involvement' with the word `ownership'. This was to ensure that GBEs with high debts were not able to be precluded from efficiency auditing. In our view, unless the GBE is subject to shareholder scrutiny through the Stock Exchange, it should be subject to parliamentary scrutiny through the Auditor-General. The opposition has accepted that revision to the amendment. That is why we are moving it together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why an opposition which is a coalition of conservative parties who distrust and do not support the idea of public enterprise would wish to install this sort of amendment. What I cannot understand is why the Australian Democrats or the Greens, if they are lured into being attracted to this by what has been said—we have not heard from the Greens yet—would support this amendment.

PARA.TAB: This amendment makes it very difficult for public enterprise to compete fairly with private enterprise. We hear in this chamber from time to time arguments that, in fact, private enterprise is disadvantaged in competing with public enterprise for a host of reasons. The government supports the concept of competitive neutrality; that is to say, we should level the playing field between private and public sector so that they can compete fairly with one another and, therefore, see in particular provinces of industry who is the most effective at delivering a service.

I am one who fervently believes that there is a place—and a very important key place—in an economy like Australia's for public enterprise. But we ought not saddle public enterprises with provisions that do not apply to the private sector and which put them at a competitive disadvantage—that is to say, neutrality does not apply; we put there not a plus sign or an equals sign but a minus sign and ensure disadvantage to the public sector.

I say that for these reasons. Firstly, we are talking about public companies. No company belonging to the private sector conducts and publishes an audit of this sort enabling all the other firms competing with it to see what its internal workings are. Companies belonging to the private sector do not do that because they would regard most of the information contained in such a document as commercial-in-confidence—that is, in confidence to themselves. But here we are proposing to do that; that is, by a performance audit, to broadcast to all the competitors of public enterprise what the internal performance is—something that they do not do.

Secondly, there is a cost factor here. We are imposing on public enterprise a cost which does not and will not apply to private enterprise. We are asking them to shoulder a higher burden than they would otherwise have and, thus, put another hurdle or handicap in front of them. We believe that these ought to be seen for what they are: performance audits are an add-on that we impose in the public sector. But to take it all the way through to publicly owned companies competing with privately owned companies is a different kettle of fish to applying it to departments of the government.

If the parliament were to continue to put hurdles in the way of public enterprise, who would that advantage? It would not advantage the public. It would not necessarily mean that there is going to be a truly competitive framework here. It advantages, unfairly, the private sector.

It is not necessarily popular to argue in favour of public enterprise. If we look at the burden of argument in the media and, indeed, the scope of argument mounted in this place, frequently it is all about breaking down public monopoly or breaking down the ability of the public sector to compete. But what this amendment does is try to extend a principle appropriate, in the government's view, to departments and agencies of the government but not appropriate where the field of competition is open and joined by the private sector versus the public sector. The first point I would make is that this is a tilting of the playing field against the interests of fair competition on a competitive neutrality basis; and it is a tilting of the playing field against the public sector overall.

The second point would be the unpredictable cost overlay to a GBE in assisting the office in responding to all of the demands. An audit of the books, which of course we support, is one thing—the accounts are laid out in a way in which that would be streamlined for the auditor, from a public sector point of view—but an audit of performance requires the collection of data from a wide cross-section of subsections within that enterprise, and that constitutes a real cost. So I think that also has to be seen in that cost factor context. Publishing the information or making the information public gives a free kick to the private sector competitors, and I think that is unfair.

I look again at Senator Short's amendment to clause 15, page 5, lines one to five. It is worth while just looking at the terms of this amendment to underline the contention I have put. The last couple of lines do reveal the problem. The amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General may at any time conduct a performance audit of a Commonwealth company that is a GBE (other than a GBE accepted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit as a GBE with significant private sector financial ownership)—
so `significant private sector financial ownership' is excluded, but what is included is—
or any of its subsidiaries.

So that is a GBE not only itself but any subsidiaries it helps form. Often in those subsidiaries there may be a private sector participation which would also have to be audited on a performance audit basis.

PARA.TAB: The principles I think this committee should balance in this discussion are the principles about whether or not the activities of these organisations are open and transparent and our financial and administrative control of those organisations sufficient. But, where competition applies, we have to approach an analysis of balancing that type of objective against the real world of competition. In doing so, I think we have to have regard to not hobbling public sector companies with unnecessary obligations, such as the sharing of shareholders information on a public level which would put them at a competitive disadvantage.

For those reasons I ask the committee whether it would not mind revisiting the fundamental reasons as to why support has been indicated for this amendment. I think, in balancing here the principles of open transparency and competition, we may be—in fact, we will be—doing a massive disservice to public service enterprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook has made a couple of statements which I think are necessary to mention here. Senator Cook said that it is not popular to argue for public enterprise. It might not be popular in this chamber inasmuch as the majority, the government and the opposition, do not like public enterprise that cannot be sold off as quickly as possible. But I wonder whether making money is the only reason that government business enterprises exist. We in the Greens would like to think that there is some public interest reason for government business enterprises existing. If there is not, there sure ought to be.

PARA.TAB: If it were just a matter of making money, Australian Defence Industries would not exist because we prop them up—and I presume that is done because the government somehow assumes that there is some public interest involved with propping up Australian Defence Industries. The principles of free competition seem to be extraordinary; they seem to override everything.

I am afraid that what I see here is the government being so long in this particular position that it hears itself speaking, it hears the opposition speaking and it hears perhaps the press gallery speaking—and it thinks that is the rest of the world. But I do not think it is the rest of the world. I think the majority of people in Australia actually do think there is a public interest component to government business enterprise, and that the government ought to be listening more carefully to the public when they talk about the need for the public interest element of government business enterprise to be looked at more carefully and to be more accountable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what the minister is saying but I cannot quite agree with him. I think there are competing interests. While the commercial-in-confidence argument has some merit, I think we need to weigh that off against public accountability. After all, in these enterprises the public, the Australian community, are essentially the shareholders. We should also remember that when we talked about WA Inc. and the State Bank of South Australia, the publication of information was resisted on the grounds of commercial confidentiality, and it might have been better if some of the facts had become known a little earlier.

PARA.TAB: It is my understanding also that the Auditor-General's report, in the first instance, is provided to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit. Therefore, an opportunity exists to provide to that committee some aspects of the Auditor-General's report in confidence; and that, if an argument is accepted and there is a valid ground, these aspects need not be disclosed or made publicly available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the time of the committee too much, but I just want to briefly respond to the minister. There is one word changed to the jointly sponsored amendment by the coalition and the Democrats and I think this might have been made clear before the minister got into the chamber. As I understand it, by agreement the other day, in relation to the words `significant private sector financial ownership', the word `ownership' has been changed to `involvement'.

PARA.TAB: So there has not been an amendment circulated to that amendment. But, as I understand it, it was discussed in the chamber and agreed to. In other words, the coalition's amendment 4 to clause 15 reads as shown, except that in the last line of the amendment the words `financial ownership' should be `financial involvement'. As Senator Spindler explained a few moments ago, the reason for that was to take account of a situation where an organisation may have a heavy debt situation. Am I not correct, Senator Spindler?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the word `involvement' was replaced with `ownership'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not privy, obviously, to any discussions between the Democrats and the coalition. But if we were to persist with the word `involvement', I would have even greater concern. What does `involvement' in those circumstances mean? The participation of a company in a joint venture with a private sector company? Significant borrowings from the private sector? Does that constitute `involvement'? Since these words are open for judicial interpretation, we cannot be sure what the limits of them are. I could say now that that is not what we intend, if the chamber does not think that is what is intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice was incorrect and I take it back. I was not party to the actual discussions. My understanding was that the word `ownership' had been changed to `involvement'; instead, `involvement' has been changed to `ownership'. I am sorry I confused the committee in the first instance.

PARA.TAB: In response to the minister's arguments against this amendment, I draw his attention to report No. 331, which is the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the bills as originally proposed. Without reading it all, I want to draw particular attention to paragraphs 4.33 through to 4.39 and the subsequent recommendations. Laid out in that report very clearly are quotes from a range of experts—such as the Auditor-General, Professor Finn, from the Australian National University, and some of the major accounting bodies—supporting the reasons that lie behind the jointly sponsored amendment by the coalition and the Democrats.

As I said, I do not want to read them all out. I will take one which is put forward by the accounting bodies. They argue that, while GBEs may be accountable to their minister under this proposal, they are not accountable to their shareholders, which are the public. They state:

SPEECH.PARA: Entities that use or manage public resources must be held accountable to the public. Unlike shareholders of a company in the private sector, the ultimate owner of a GBE, being the public, cannot withdraw their funds at any time if dissatisfied with management's performance. Therefore an alternative mechanism to protect the public interest is required. One such mechanism is an audit by the Auditor-General . . .

The remaining couple of pages support that proposition. The only other point I make in response to the minister's comments is that a significant difference between a GBE and a purely private sector company is that GBEs have an implicit guarantee via the government if they are essentially in government ownership. The guarantor in that case is the Australian taxpayer and that adds further weight to the reasons why we believe this proposed amendment is appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to say a couple of things to finalise the debate. I draw the chamber's attention, given that Senator Short was the last speaker, to the Herald-Sun of 2 March 1995. This is not my favourite newspaper and it is not one I am given to comment from at any length. But I have not conveniently selected it for any reason other than it carries a report on a major overhaul of the Auditor-General's office in Victoria and the position of the Victorian state government in dealing with that report. This article points to a matter that I know is the case. A recommendation of this sort came before the Kennett government. Despite that government's quite strong private sector and conservative credentials, that government rejected this part of the report. I know the argument I can anticipate from Senator Short about this, but what is good for Jeff Kennett may not be good for a future coalition government—although it ought to give pause to the coalition that the most stridently pro-conservative figure in Australia at the present time finds that this is not a satisfactory amendment and does, to some extent, defend the position of public enterprise. The article, under the heading `State rejects auditor plans', states:

SPEECH.PARA: A further recommendation to enshrine the Auditor-General's access to documents from departments including Premier and Cabinet, Treasury—
I can understand all of that from a conservative figure—
and State Owned Enterprises—
which is what we are debating here—
was also rejected.
It goes on:
The proposed changes were recommended in a report by the Coalition dominated Parliamentary Public Accounts and Estimates Committee.
And so on it goes. For the record, it is interesting to note that even Jeff Kennett finds this an intrusion on public enterprise, one presumes from his rejection of it.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with a couple of other things that have been said. Senator Margetts has picked up my remarks about the unpopularity in political debate in Australia of defending the role of public enterprises. I was simply making those remarks to say that, unpopular as it might be at certain times, nonetheless this government defends that role. We do not see public enterprise as necessarily something just to sell off.

The key issue for us is that they operate efficiently and, therefore, a degree of commercialisation may be necessary or, in some cases, it may be necessary to create a competitive environment. But monopolies are not what you will get cost efficiencies and savings for consumers out of as a general principle and therefore we have moved as we have. But the idea of public enterprise, I can assure the chamber, is alive and well in the Labor Party. If you agree with that, then why put extra hurdles in its way and derogate from the principle of competitive neutrality? The issue for this chamber for both the Democrats and the Greens is that these amendments will do that and so how does that serve the wider purpose and the wider good? I cannot see that it does.

If the argument is that it does because it leads to greater accountability, what would be more greatly accountable that this chamber does not already have access to? It has access to the audited accounts of these organisations. It has access to the annual reports of these organisations. It has powers to call and inquire as to what happens in these organisations. From time to time it sets up inquiries into particular GBEs. The inquiry into the ANL Ltd is a case in point. The minister, Laurie Brereton, proposed inviting the Auditor-General to undertake an investigation of the ANL. That seemed to be an appropriate act for a minister to take, but the Senate declined that approach. The Senate preferred to conduct its own review of the company's activities. That is a preference of the Senate.

The point I make is not the politics of whether the Brereton inquiry should have gone ahead or the Senate inquiry should have taken place. That is an argument we have already had. The point is that this is scrutiny. This is scrutiny which comes to this chamber. What beyond that do you need to do to ensure accountability, bearing in mind that this is not a clear case of black and white accountability or nothing? This is a case of that type of access and accountability versus the overriding principle of putting hurdles or obstructions in the way of public enterprise. On that basis I earnestly request that you reconsider the position that seems to be evolving here.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister said that monopolies are not efficient. I guess I would have to agree in general cases, but we just signed on to the Uruguay Round of GATT, which makes it very difficult for Australia or any other country to fight against monopoly takeovers of our own industries. I wonder how that fits into the government's current position in relation to monopolies. We can have entire industries like our banana industry in Queensland taken over by a monopoly buyer from another country. If that is not efficient, that is what the government is doing as part of its policy on trade. So if it works for private enterprise, I guess we have the ability at least to scrutinise what is happening with the monopolies under public enterprise to make sure they are operating in our interest.

PARA.TAB: I remind the minister again that it was a very limited offer by minister Brereton, who said that it was conditional on not being released until after the sale of ANL—which is not what people in the public were asking for at that time—that if we waited until an audit was taking place it would not be released until after any sales of Australian National Lines. That was not an offer of scrutiny and accountability. It was a very limited offer, one might also say even a blackmail of the process.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause 15, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 16.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens' amendment has been circulated. I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 16, page 5, subclause (4) definition of `Commonwealth public sector', lines 27 and 28, omit "(other than GBEs)" (twice occurring).

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment would allow the Auditor-General to conduct general performance audits of all the Commonwealth public sector. By deleting the exemption of the GBEs, the Auditor-General would be able to conduct an audit of a particular aspect of the operations of the whole or part of the Commonwealth public sector, which is not limited to the operations of only one agency, body or person. We believe there is no good reason why GBEs should be exempt from such audits. Obviously we have concurred with some of the measures that support this in the discussion prior to this point.

PARA.TAB: While these enterprises remain owned by the Commonwealth, they should be open to the auditors of the Commonwealth. In the event that they are sold off, then these enterprises' direct accountability to the people of Australia will cease. But until then, they should be open to the people's audit. I take on board the references that Senator Spindler made to the unfortunate instances we have had where those kinds of public funded enterprises have been defective in terms of the scrutiny that taxpayers have had to the use of taxpayers' funds.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: We are opposed to this amendment. This is almost son of the last amendment, an almost consequential part of the last amendment. In order to save time, all of the arguments that I have mentioned last time please assume appear in Hansard this time. We are amending subclause 4 of section 16, Commonwealth public sector. This is a definitional clause. As I understand the amendment, it is to omit `other than GBEs', which occurs twice in this section, so that it embraces everything, including GBEs. We have just had this discussion. Again, there might be in the Commonwealth public sector an audit which looks at how efficiently Commonwealth public sector organisations handle their energy bill. One can understand why that might be something for the government. In a competitive situation in the private sector one has to look at that as certainly an imperative, but whether parliament would want to try and then use an audit for the purposes of trying to direct a particular policy application on that subject, or in the use of credit cards or in some other thing like that, which gives a competitive disadvantage to that company, is another thing entirely. So for all the arguments I have put we are opposed to this amendment.

—Subject to clarifying one point, which I want to do with the minister, the coalition will be supporting this amendment. I understand from what Senator Cook says—I will not go over all the arguments either—that the amendment has a similar effect to the two preceding amendments. That also is our understanding. On that basis and for the reasons that we have outlined in the previous two amendments, we will be supporting the Greens' proposal.
—To put the Democrats' position on record, we will be supporting the amendment for reasons previously stated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of what has been said, what this amendment does not do is provide an exception for partly privatised GBEs like the Commonwealth Bank, which I think we included in the other amendment. It would therefore upset the principle we have just adopted. The other amendments had Joint Committee of Public Accounts involvement. This amendment does not envisage that either. So I guess it is not strictly true—I may have misled Senator Short—to say that this is son of the last amendment. It is in the kin of the last amendment but it is certainly not a direct descendant of the last amendment. Because of those flaws in it, and in addition to what I have already said, I do not think it should pass.

—I would like to clarify that. I would hate the committee to be misled on this either by me or by the minister. My understanding is that because we are correcting a definition, as the minister pointed out earlier, it does not alter the effect of the amendments that we have already agreed to. The Greens have signified their assent to that. So I cannot see that it would wipe out that exemption. It would be misleading to presume that they were in conflict.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to mislead the Senate either, but my advice is that these are two different classes of audit. For that reason, what I have said is true.

—I seek a clarification from the minister. Could he explain to me very carefully how the changes that are proposed in this amendment will prevent the previous amendments including that particular exemption that they have required? I do not understand how that would operate. It is quite clear that a more general definition is put to which a further qualifier is placed by the previous amendments that we voted for. I think the minister needs to explain the mechanism by which the two amendments we have just passed would conflict with this present one, because I do not understand that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with clause 16. The heading of clause 16 is `General performance audit'. The definition that occurs in subclause (4) relates to a definition of the Commonwealth public sector in so far as general performance audits are concerned.

PARA.TAB: What we were talking about in the last raft of amendments were performance audits of the public sector. Therefore, a performance audit is done of the performance of a particular GBE. We are talking here about general performance audits—the performance across the public sector, say, of energy efficiency moves, the use of credit cards or the clocking on and clocking off times of all people who work in this section—some sort of general survey of what happens here. This amendment would mean that the exception from those audits of partly privatised GBEs would not be made. The requirement of these audits to have a JCPA involvement would not arise as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the general performance audits, is the information identified? If a general performance audit is being done across the public sector, is it necessary for a particular enterprise to be identified, or could it be part of a general performance audit so that we could say how the public sector is performing without identifying particular elements of that audit?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is for the Auditor-General to interpret the way to do this. All I have to go on is what his practice is: identifying the organisations involved. The purpose of it is certainly to take a general survey of the behaviour in relation to a particular issue across the public sector, but it is also to compare the application of these things from agency to agency. I understand that the practice of the Auditor-General is to do that. One could understand how he would be of that view, given the broadness of this definition. That is the reason why we are concerned about it.

—I can see the point that the minister is making in the sense that, if we take the Greens' amendment as is, there will be some inconsistency between this clause and the amendments we just made. I have just discussed this with Senator Chamarette and Senator Spindler. One way of getting around this would be to make the three clauses—clauses 14, 15 and 16—consistent. Instead of having the amendment of Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts to simply delete `other than GBEs', we could leave in the words `other than GBEs' but add the words `accepted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit as a GBE with significant private sector financial ownership'.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether that would accord with the views of the Greens and the Australian Democrats. I understand that it might. I think that would retain the intent of the amendment put forward by the Greens whilst ensuring consistency with what we have done in the other two clauses. I put that forward, but I would appreciate any comment from Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette as to whether they would accept that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short mentioned `financial ownership'. I think the previous amendments did not contain the word `financial'. It might be useful to have the wording exactly the same.
—The previous ones do have `financial'.
—Do they? I thought they said `significant private sector ownership'.

—In terms of the general vision that I think we should be aiming for—I think that is something the government tends to lack—there have been times where we have said in the last few months that part of the problem is that we do not have a vision that the government is aiming for. Whether it is perhaps improved energy efficiency, cutting down greenhouse gases or improving environmental performance, we obviously need to have the ability to compare one government entity with another, particularly if it is a government business enterprise. Quite frankly, if a government business enterprise is decreasing its energy bills, one thing we would like the private sector to copy is better performance in areas like that where the private sector simply is not performing as well as it should be.

PARA.TAB: We want to have the ability to have these kinds of analyses done across government business enterprises. It would not be necessary if the private sector were doing all of those things that we were hoping it would do. We want to make sure that the caveats which are put in this kind of amendment do not mean that the public accounts committee cannot see that there may be some areas like energy efficiency where it might be seen to be in everybody's interest that, if the government is or is not doing well or there are more savings to be made in terms of energy efficiency, these kinds of comparative studies be done and that private sector perhaps copy the good things that the public enterprises are doing. We want to make sure that whatever we agree to in this instance does not stop us from being able to compare what public enterprises are doing to make sure that government policy perhaps is being carried out by even government business enterprises.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to Senator Short, my understanding is that we would be happy to include the wording he proposed. I think the Australian Democrats have also agreed to it, subject to sorting out whether the wording is satisfactory.
—Senator Short was right.

—On that basis, I am not sure at what stage we are. I think we have actually moved the amendment, but I am happy to allow my amendment to go ahead amended, if that is what Senator Short would like to happen. I am happy for Senator Short to move an amendment to my amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of that discussion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That Senator Chamarette's proposed amendment be amended to read as follows:

Clause 16, page 5, subclause (4), definition of "Commonwealth public sector", lines 27 and 28, after "GBEs" (twice occurring), insert "accepted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit as GBEs with significant private sector financial ownership".

SPEECH.PARA: I think those words make this clause entirely consistent with the wording of amended clauses 14 and 15.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Amendment, as amended, agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 17.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 17, page 5, after proposed subclause (3), insert the following subclause:

"(3A) A person to whom the Auditor-General gives a copy of a report under this section must not disclose the information contained in the report in any manner other than as may be necessary in the consideration of the report or the preparation of comments on the report.

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 10 penalty units.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is necessary to protect the confidentiality of audit reports. These reports are the property of the Auditor-General and should not be disclosed or released without his consent. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its report No. 331 made a similar recommendation—recommendation 24. This amendment essentially reflects that recommendation from report No. 331, with which the coalition agrees.

TALK.START.PARA: —To put the Australian Democrats' position on record, the amendment reflects recommendation 24 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, as Senator Short said, and the Democrats will be supporting the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that this does introduce a further duplication into the bill. I would be enlightened if Senator Short could tell me the difference between his amendment and what is already in the bill, save for the fact that in the bill the maximum penalty is imprisonment for two years and in the amendment the penalty is 10 penalty units. It seems to me that, other than going softer on the subject, there is no difference at all.

PARA.TAB: I was referring to clause 33(3) of the bill. I know that this amendment refers to clause 17, but clause 33 comes after the heading `Division 2—Confidentiality of information' and under the immediate heading `Confidentiality of information', which goes to the point of the confidentiality we are talking about. It seems to me that subclause (3) of clause 33 sets out very simply that confidentiality must be observed and that information must not be disclosed except with the consent of the Attorney-General, and then there is a penalty. Amending clause 17 seems to me to do the same thing, other than lightening the penalty. I just wonder why Senator Short thinks that is important.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Short does not mind, I do not mind setting out why the Greens concur with this change, and then we can seek a view from Senator Short. From my point of view, the very phrase the minister used just now is a really good reason for the wording to be changed from `Maximum penalty: Imprisonment for 2 years' to the formula of penalty units.

PARA.TAB: The Greens' view is that we should not use prison penalties in the way they are used in plenty of the legislation that comes through this place when it is in direct conflict with the view that most states adopt that imprisonment is a penalty of last resort. It is quite clearly being placed here, as the minister reflected, to put on a show of power and of criminal sanction.

There is some implication that replacing it by penalty units is a softening. It is not a softening, in my understanding of it. It is just a different terminology and it prevents this kind of heavy-handed approach being used when imprisonment is a penalty of last resort, and should be. In my view, the use of imprisonment is only for the protection of the community from violence of an extreme form, and also for the protection of a person from any harm or danger.

To put in words that do not hold that penalty in reality but that are just inserted to provide some kind of image of that is wrong. I think it is much more appropriate to have some kind of penalty in there. I do not oppose penalties, but to put in prison penalties every time some kind of sanction is to be applied makes something that is very serious—that is, the imprisonment of human beings—into some kind of tool of intimidation that can be applied throughout all legislation when it has no place, really, outside the Crimes Act.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause 17, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 18 to 26—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 27.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 27, page 8, at end of clause, add the following subclause:
"(2) Subsection (1) does not apply to any law relating to the powers, privileges and immunities of a House of the Parliament, its members or committees.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment, along with a couple of others we will be moving, is necessary to prevent this section from being construed as overriding parliamentary immunities. It is designed to make this question unequivocal. These provisions are not intended by the parliament to override its powers, privileges and immunities. I will also be moving amendments to clauses 28 and 34 for the same reason.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure whether the government sees a problem in this or not, whether it was in fact intended by the government to override parliamentary immunities or not, so I ask the minister whether he sees this proposal as a concern. If he does see it as a concern, then I am at a bit of a loss as to why, and I would seek clarification from him on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats share these concerns and are therefore disposed to supporting the amendment, which we see as a clarifying amendment. I also express the hope that this clause will not derogate from the existing powers of the Auditor-General to investigate politicians. The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) might comment on that. Perhaps Senator Short might wish to comment on that as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . does not apply to any law relating to the powers, privileges and immunities of either or both Houses of the parliament, its members or committees.

The very thing that this chamber was complaining about with respect to the National Media Liaison Service was that here we had a body that slipped between the cracks and thus escaped scrutiny. We now say, and we say unitedly with the government leading this chorus, that that should not happen and that everyone should be open and audited. If this amendment were to pass, we would be saying that everyone should be open and audited but for the powers, privileges and immunities of the houses of parliament, its members and its committees.

PARA.TAB: My question is: if we are going to be open and audit everything, why don't we audit everything? That means that the houses of parliament, its members and its committees should be open to be audited. I do not resile from that. Why should this chamber adopt this amendment? This would be held up by commentators as us saying, `One law applies to us and a different law applies to everybody else.' I do not think it is in our interests to be open to that type of jibe. There is enough criticism of politicians as it is without adding real substance to some of that fairly insubstantial criticism.

As far as my understanding of how this amendment applies is concerned, if it were in the mind of the auditor, for example, to conduct an audit of the electorate accounts of members of parliament, we would be saying that that is off limits. Again, it would be us saying that there is one law for us and a different law for everyone else. The government's position is: let us all have the same law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is anything I want to add to what I said initially; namely, in our view this amendment is necessary to prevent this section of the act from being construed as overriding parliamentary immunities. I ask the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) again whether it was deliberately intended that the government proposed to have the act override the normal parliamentary immunities. If so, why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is for the reasons that I gave a moment ago. We intended that the act be construed so that the normal parliamentary immunities, as Senator Short has termed it, are open to be audited in a proper public process. One of the reasons for that lies in Audit Report No. 17 1994-95—National Media Liaison Service—A Loophole in Accountability? At paragraphs 1.6 and 1.7 of the Auditor-General's comments on the National Media Liaison Service, a couple of comments are made which are probably relevant to this debate. In paragraph 1.6, the Auditor-General is moved to say:

PARA.TAB: The Parliament, through both the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts and the Standing Committee on Finance and Administration, has expressed the view that—

SPEECH.PARA: I put weight on the next words—
all Commonwealth undertakings, of whatever legal form, should be audited by the Commonwealth Auditor-General
In paragraph 1.7, he is moved to say:

PARA.TAB: All those who play a role in administrative decision making exercise public power and that action, especially where public money is involved, should be open to public scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to enlarge. It is for those reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I must say that I do not understand what the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) is saying. I hope he does. Certainly, I did not understand it. I would be flabbergasted if the minister was saying that somehow or other we ought to be overriding the normal parliamentary immunities that apply. The implications of that on the whole processes of the parliament, the operations of members of parliament and the operations of the essential committees of the parliament, would be placed in the gravest of jeopardy.

PARA.TAB: That would remove from the processes of parliament and from parliamentary consideration one of the essential components of the role of the parliament, its members and committees. I am sure the minister does not mean that. He could not possibly mean that. Therefore, I wonder whether there has been a bit of a communication problem in what he is trying to say to the chamber. If that is the implication, then I am even more resolved, as is the coalition, to press the amendment.

I refer to two letters. The first, dated 8 March, is from the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, and is addressed to my colleague Senator Gibson. The second, dated 9 March, is from the Clerk Assistant, Mr O'Keefe, and is addressed to the Deputy President of the Senate. It relates to this issue. It relates not just to this clause but also to clauses 28 and 34. I seek leave to table those two letters.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am invited again to clarify the point that I have been at pains to enunciate. Let me do so. I thought it came quite clearly from the quotations that I read that the Auditor-General should be able to audit all agencies or functions of the Commonwealth that consume public money. That is the point. In so far as this parliament and its committees consume public money, that is information relevant to the shareholders, in the broadest concept of that word—the taxpayers. They are entitled to have that audited and presented.

PARA.TAB: This amendment by Senator Short, as I read it, would prevent that from occurring. I am not here venturing into the wider debate about immunities or particular privileges of individual members of parliament. The truth is that we do consume taxpayers' money. Taxpayers are entitled to have an audited account of what happens. The Commonwealth Auditor-General is the right person to do that. That is the government's position on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of comments to make on that. I am delighted to hear the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) now talking about the right of the Auditor-General and the parliament to expect full accountability from the government. That is absolutely what we have been on about in this whole debate. I am glad to hear the minister say that, because it is quite contrary to the government's position when it opposed the earlier amendments to do just that. What Senator Cook now says about this is absolutely at odds with the government's approach in terms of the coalition's earlier amendments, particularly those relating to the Financial Management and Accountability Bill. The government went absolutely the other way on that.

PARA.TAB: The normal operations of the departments of the parliament are subject to the full scrutiny of the Auditor-General under the normal operations of the Audit Act. This amendment does not in any way derogate from that. It ensures that, in particular, those who give evidence in camera before parliamentary committees have the normal parliamentary immunities accorded to them and remain so. Surely he is not suggesting that that longstanding, essential underpinning provision of the operations of the parliament should be changed in this context.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to the debate. I would like to draw the same distinction that Senator Short drew just then between the operation and accountability of committees for the transactions that they engage in as distinct from the wording of this amendment, which simply reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . does not apply to any law relating to the powers, privileges and immunities of a House of the Parliament, its members or committees.

As I read it—perhaps the minister could comment on it—it does not preclude the Auditor-General from looking at, for instance, the expenditure, and the way that the money was expended, of a parliamentary committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government still opposes this amendment. In our view, it is not necessary. It comes down to the Auditor-General dealing with the principle of those who consume public money being audited. I will defend myself from the mild calumny ventured against me opposite. When I spoke earlier, I was talking about public companies. The money which they consume and use is not taxpayer money. It is money garnered from their commercial activities. The principle here is that those who use and expend money should be properly audited. This proposed amendment to clause 27(2) confuses the issue unnecessarily so. The government will oppose it.

—I will not prolong this. I repeat that, as I understand it, this amendment has nothing to do with moneys expended by the parliament or its committees in the operation of their business.
