They will continue to be subject to the provisions of the Audit Act. We are talking about a protection of the immunities that are contained exclusively in the Parliamentary Privileges Act. It has nothing to do with money. I think there might have been some misunderstanding.
—Well, why put it in at all, then?

—Because there is a feeling that it ought to be absolutely clear there is no suggestion that this proposed section can be construed as overriding parliamentary immunities. It is to make that absolutely clear. If it were not the government's intent to override parliamentary immunities in the first place, I frankly cannot see why it would have any opposition to this clause. On the other hand, if it were weakening the existing situation in relation to parliamentary immunities, it adds weight to the reasons put forward by the coalition for its amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must be misreading the intention of the government in proposed section 27. As I see it, clause 27 says that the operation of proposed sections 29 and 30 is not limited by any other law except to the extent that the other law expressly excludes the operation of proposed sections 29 and 30. Firstly, I will go to proposed section 29, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General may, by written notice, direct a person to do all or any of the following:
(a)to provide the Auditor-General with any information that the Auditor-General requires;
(b)to attend and give evidence before the Auditor-General or an authorised official;
(c)to produce to the Auditor-General any documents in the custody or under the control of the person.

Frankly, if that is going to the issues that are being raised by Senator Short, Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette, we are facing a conflict. We are able to operate in this chamber through the responsible use of our powers, privileges and immunities. Some of them involve, as has been indicated by Senator Short, for example, in camera evidence. Is the government suggesting that clause 29 enables the Auditor-General to require that sort of information? Is that the case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer starts by going back to the role of the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General audits matters relating to expenditure. It seems to me that the case being made now creates a few fears about whether an Auditor-General will wish to extend that power and do other things that may be improperly beyond his power.

PARA.TAB: I do not think that is a fair comparison, if that is the comparison that is being made. In the end, it comes down to this: the government's view is that this amendment is not necessary. It clutters up an Auditor-General's act by including something that is obviously beyond what is apparently the Auditor-General's power. Therefore, it ought not be included.

The rejoinder is this: why include it if it is harmless? I argue that the purpose of legislation is not to be an agenda for all things. The purpose of legislation is to put things necessarily in their appropriate place. We had a debate here last week about including a couple of `feel good' ideas, because we wanted to express them. One could imagine putting in a bill feelings and qualifications which unnecessarily duplicate and complicate that bill when simplicity and clarity are the guiding drafting rules that we apply here. We are having a relaxed debate. The question at the bottom of the pile is: why include it when it is not necessary? In our submission, it is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to restate the position. This amendment guards against unintended consequences. Since it is very clearly drawn and relates to powers, privileges and immunities, it does not, on that understanding, interfere with the auditing of financial expenditure, accounts or operations of committees. The Australian Democrats will be supporting it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause 27, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 28.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 28, page 8, paragraph (b), line 13, omit "22 or".

This amendment relates to essentially the same issue as the last amendment. It seeks to remove the reference to clause 22 in clause 28 which limits the information gathering powers of the Auditor-General. Clause 22 deals with the extra reports by the Auditor-General to the parliament. As it stands, the legislation would deny the Auditor-General the ability to use his extensive information gathering powers in preparing such reports for the parliament. It is certainly unacceptable to the coalition that he would be denied that ability other than taking into account the protection of parliamentary immunity issue that we have just debated. One interpretation of clause 28 could be that it limits the Auditor-General's ability to properly respond to, for example, an order of the Senate. That would be unfortunate to say the least.

PARA.TAB: This is a clarifying amendment. It sets out to make it clear that the parliament is really not prepared to accept such a possibility. To use Senator Spindler's words, it is designed to prevent what might be an unintended consequence. There may be more to it than that. It may be more than an unintended consequence depending on the government's intention.

If the government was not proposing to deny the Auditor-General that information gathering power then we are looking at making sure that that unintended consequence does not result. If, on the other hand, the government is trying to limit in some way the Auditor-General's ability to use his information gathering powers in preparing such reports for the parliament, then I would be interested to hear the government's reasons for attempting to so limit the Auditor-General's powers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Page 12 of the explanatory memorandum to the Auditor-General Bill under the heading `Clause 28—Purpose for which information gathering powers may be used' states:

SPEECH.PARA: The information-gathering and access powers granted to the Auditor-General are available for all functions of the Auditor-General except . . .
At the second dot point it states:

Preparation of extra reports to the Parliament (clause 22) or Ministers (clause 23)—it is not intended the Auditor-General have compulsive powers to gather information to prepare such reports as this information will generally arise through the course of conducting audits which would be additional to any audit reports prepared by the Auditor-General.

That is the clearest explanation of why both clause 22 and clause 23 are referred to under this section of the bill. It is not intended that the Auditor-General have compulsive powers to gather information to prepare such reports, as this information may generally arise.

PARA.TAB: This amendment to clause 28 omits clause 22. Clause 22 of the bill relates to the extra reports to parliament. The Auditor-General should have information gathering powers which enable him to acquire this information without exception. This amendment would take away the exception. We believe the exception should not be taken away and should not apply to his voluntary information gathering powers.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause 28, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 29 to 32—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 33.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be proceeding with their amendment to clause 33.

PARA.TAB: Clause agreed to.
Clause 34.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 34, page 10 paragraph (1)(b), lines 33 to 36, omit the paragraph.

This amendment seeks to ensure that the Auditor-General is not unnecessarily precluded from the publication of reports. Clause 34 was the cause of much controversy in the JCPA hearings and has been reworded to reflect the existing law. However, as the New South Wales Auditor-General, Tony Harris, pointed out in evidence to the committee, the clause is still very restrictive on reporting.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats' amendment seeks to transfer the determination of public interest from the hands of the Attorney-General—after all, he is a politician who is part of the government—to the hands of the Auditor-General. I would expect that in the ordinary course of events the Auditor-General would in any case seek the advice of the Attorney-General's Department on whether some reports should be released. However, by leaving the final decision to the Auditor-General we ensure that reports are not kept from public view by a certificate issued by a government seeking to cover up some unsavoury decision making.

The provision in 48F of the Audit Act, which is now reproduced in clause 34, was only introduced in 1979. It has no counterpart, that I am aware of, in the state audit acts. There are two foreshadowed amendments to this clause. The amendment proposed by the opposition is a little less severe than ours and our alternative amendment is a little less severe than the opposition's amendment. If this amendment is not supported—and I certainly believe it should be supported—I will be prepared to support one of the lesser amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I had moved Democrats amendment No. 5 and concluded my remarks. The Australian Democrats believe that the decision to release reports should not be in the hands of the Attorney-General but in the hands of the Auditor-General. This is the purpose of our amendment, and I commend it to the committee.

—The Democrats amendment No. 5 to clause 34 is a somewhat alternative approach to that being proposed by the coalition for dealing with the issue of the non-inclusion of sensitive information in public reports of the Auditor-General. This amendment would remove subclause (1)(b), whereby the Attorney-General may issue a certificate to the Auditor-General preventing the disclosure of certain information contained in a report considered to be contrary to the public interest as defined in subclause (2).

PARA.TAB: The coalition fully supports the proposition that the Attorney-General should not have a cart blanche, unaccountable ability to prevent disclosure of whatever information he considered contrary to the public interest. Nevertheless, we accept that the Attorney should have some ability on behalf of the executive to prevent disclosure under certain circumstances. There will be times—hopefully very few—when the Auditor-General and the Attorney-General have slightly different perceptions on what is or is not in the public interest.

We have some amendments to propose to this clause and this, to us, would be a more desirable way of approaching the matter than that of the Democrats. We will not support the Democrats' amendment. Depending on the outcome of that, we will pursue our own amendments to address the sentiments and concerns here. I understand that Senator Spindler said before the suspension for dinner that, if the Democrats' amendment does not get up, the Democrats will be broadly supportive of the coalition's amendments, but let us take it one step at a time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw Senator Short's attention to the fact that the Australian Democrats have an alternative amendment, which is amendment No. 5A. Perhaps Senator Short could consider that. I think that could be regarded as being slightly stronger than the present drafting of the coalition's amendment. After the committee has dealt with amendment No. 5—and it would appear that it will not be passed—I might test the coalition's view on Democrats' amendment No. 5A.

—From our point of view, and I think there was some agreement on this, we would prefer it if we looked at our two amendments and then the Democrats' amendment 5A. If we could do it that way, it may help the debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever the negotiations that are being recorded in Hansard between Senator Spindler and Senator Short to work out a common position, I have to deliver the bad news to both senators on behalf of the government: we will oppose the amendments of both the Democrats and the coalition in whatever form they come up. We do this for a number of very important and quite fundamental reasons.

PARA.TAB: Clause 34 deals with sensitive information not being included in public reports. Set out under 34(2) are reasons (a) to (f) as to the nature of those considerations. To illustrate the reasons, their importance and the weight that they should bare in the deliberations of this chamber, let me quote clause 34(2)(a). It says that nothing should be revealed `if it would prejudice the security, defence or international relations of the Commonwealth'. I will just pause at that point.

Before the suspension for dinner, I heard Senator Spindler argue that the states do not have a section in their audit acts which corresponds with this section. To the best of my knowledge, that is true, but the reason why the states do not is obvious: that is, the states do not have an international relations, defence or security function. The Commonwealth, under the constitution, performs these functions. Therefore, in the role of the auditor in the states, the issue of informational sensitivity does not arise. As a consequence, one can easily understand why state legislation does not address itself to the problem of sensitive information becoming available.

The other point that needs to be made is that this clause of the bill finds an existing home already in the act. We are not seeking by this amending bill to change the provisions under which we currently operate. It is interesting that no-one has adduced a reason in this debate as to why clause 34 should be altered. Although it has been in existence in one form or another for a very long time—in fact, since the founding of the Federation—no argument has been adduced in any way to say that it is defective.

One would have thought that the threshold point would be to say that there are reasons why what has been a longstanding fundamental principle of Auditor-General law has changed. That has not happened. In the absence of an explanation, one must conclude—as I think on the evidence one would conclude—that, with respect, there is no reason other than what lurks in the back of senators' minds as to what might occur. But we have to deal with what does occur. One can invent all sorts of conspiracies and scenarios, but none of those would appear, on the empirical evidence, to be appropriate in this case.

The other point I would make is that, given that there is a foreshadowed amendment, if this bill were to transfer into law, perhaps the Joint Committee of Public Accounts should be the committee that is consulted. The difficulty with that is that this is a public accounts committee of the parliament. How could we expect such a committee to understand the sensitivities of `security, defence or international relations of the Commonwealth'? Its function is to understand the audit process and, while there may be members of the committee who have a broader knowledge than that—and I do not deny that—the purpose of the committee is not to understand those quite sensitive issues. The government believes that to expect the committee to understand these matters would clothe it with a power to make assessments, aggrandise it well beyond its scope and ask it to perform a function that it is not equipped to perform. If that amendment comes forward, we would reject it as well.

That leaves me with the issue of the Auditor-General and the Attorney-General. The argument being put here is that the Attorney-General is, after all, another politician and that the Attorney-General having a say on these matters is inappropriate. The Auditor-General should have an unfettered reign and be able to roam across the landscape without the Attorney-General saying to him or her at any particular point, `Please, in the interests of national security, don't go beyond this point.'

The Attorney-General cannot be depicted as simply another politician. The Attorney-General has sworn an oath of office as the first law officer of the Commonwealth of Australia and, as a consequence, has weighty responsibilities imposed on him or her and part of those responsibilities go to the issue of national security. The Attorney-General is appropriately aware of national security concerns. It may well be that so too is the Auditor-General, but it can never be contended that the Auditor-General would know more about the subject of national security and indeed know of the sensitivities of particular material better than the Attorney-General would.

The Attorney-General will always have the job of knowing that information and maintaining a bird's-eye view across the whole front of government activities and therefore know how particular information taken in isolation from the main body of information or intelligence relates to that whole body. Here there could be a mistake of lack of knowledge not of motive. Motivated by the best will in the world, the Auditor-General may wish to have an excursion into a particular area which, in isolation, appears benign enough but with an intelligence overview threatens the national security of the Commonwealth of Australia. The Auditor-General could not be expected to know that; the Attorney-General could be expected to know that, and that is why the Attorney-General should be the person here who issues the instruction.

I would argue firstly and principally to those opposite, who offer to be an alternative government here in Australia, that they like us, the government, have to have a primary concern when approaching this clause about issues of national security, defence or international relations of the Commonwealth. They have to have a primary concern, too, about all other paragraphs in subclause (2), right the way down and including paragraph (f) for which they have foreshadowed an amendment.

A government in office exercising the weighty powers and responsibilities of government must deport itself in a way in which it has regard to all of those factors. The same—and I do not say this disparagingly—is not true of either the Greens or the Democrats, neither of whom have members in the House of Representatives and at this point, foreseeably, might I say, do not appear likely to form a government in Australia.

I do not think Senator Margetts has spoken so I do not want to necessarily prejudice what she might say, but I can certainly understand why Senator Spindler might take a slightly different view, removed from the obligations of forming and managing a government. I cannot, for the sake of this clause, understand why a coalition would. Those opposite certainly must have a different view of the weighty responsibilities of government, maybe that goes to the fact that they have been out of it a long time and forgotten or never learnt.

Nonetheless, here I urge pause and consideration about what is being done because those reasons are significant. Sensitive information is defined as including information which would prejudice the security, defence or international relations of the Commonwealth; would involve the disclosure of deliberations or decision of the cabinet or a committee of the cabinet; would prejudice relations between the Commonwealth and the state; would divulge any information or matter that was communicated in confidence by the Commonwealth to a state or by a state to the Commonwealth; would unfairly prejudice the commercial interest of any body or person; for any other reason that could form the basis of a claim by the Crown in a judicial proceeding that the information should not be disclosed.

All of those are substantial reasons that attach to the authority of government and the efficacy of government. For those reasons, we oppose the amendments in whatever form is finally concluded between Senator Spindler and Senator Short and, ergo, to the amendment that the coalition has foreshadowed to clause 34(2)(f).

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to briefly respond to Senator Cook. The essential difference between the government and the coalition is that we believe the parliament has a responsibility in areas where you do not believe it has a responsibility. We do not believe that the executive should have the untrammelled right to determine the interests of this nation as if the elected representatives who form the parliament do not exist. That is the essential difference.

PARA.TAB: Your party does not believe in the accountability of the parliament to the people. Your government, over the last 12 years, has shown time and time again that it is prepared to use executive power to stamp on the rights of the democratically elected people of this nation. That is not a proposition with which we will have any truck at all. It is for that reason that we are opposed to the clause as drafted in the bill.

Having said that, though, we do have problems with the Democrat amendment to clause 34 because the Democrat amendment gives no right, as I read it, for the executive to have a role at all in this process. The Democrat amendment omits entirely clause 34(1)(b) which contains the reference to the Attorney-General. That is why, understanding some of the points that Senator Cook has made, we feel in these circumstances, and given the nature of the information that one is talking about, that to give the executive no role is to take the process too far. Equally, we are totally opposed to the government's proposition which says that the parliament has no role in this process at all.

This package of audit bills that we are referring to are all about accountability, transparency, the role of the parliament on the one hand and the executive on the other and the relationship, to an essentially important degree, between the Auditor-General and the parliament. The government does not want to build that relationship which we think is essential.

If Senator Spindler's amendment, as seems likely, is lost, we will propose an amendment to provide a bit of a halfway house, I guess, in the sense that the role of the parliament must be reflected and respected in the bill in this aspect. At the same time, this clause deals with matters in which we do think the executive does have some legitimate role as well. Of course it does in matters that relate to this.

There is a way in which both the parliament and the executive can be involved in this. We think to deny the right of either the parliament or the executive to participate is wrong. That is why we will be going down the path that we have outlined. On behalf of the coalition, I totally reject the proposition that is inherent in Senator Cook's statement and in the bill that the parliament ought to have no role in this aspect. That is what the bill means at the moment. Equally, as I have said, we have some problems with saying that the executive should have no role. We think there should be a very responsible, accountable, transparent, democratic compromise between those two.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 34, page 10, paragraph (1)(b), line 33, after "the Attorney-General", insert ", after consulting with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit,".

This means that the Auditor-General must not include particular information in a public report if he or she, the Auditor-General, is `of the opinion that disclosure of the information would be contrary to the public interest for any of the reasons set out in subsection (2)'. Of course, paragraph (a) gives the lie, I must say, to much of what Senator Cook said in his last contribution. Clause 34(1)(b) states:
The Auditor-General must not include particular information in a public report if the Attorney-General
—and then we would insert the words `after consulting with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit'—

has issued a certificate to the Auditor-General stating that, in the opinion of the Attorney-General, disclosure of the information would be contrary to the public interest for any of the reasons set out in subsection (2).

I think I have already explained fairly adequately the reasons for that proposal. What we want to see is a role for the parliament in the form of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit in this aspect. To have a situation where there is no role for the parliament is, for the reasons I have said before, to give exclusive power in this domain to the executive at the cost of the parliament and, therefore, at the cost of the democratic pro cess.

PARA.TAB: We want to have this package of bills reflecting the critically important role of the parliament in the processes involved in the whole of the audit function and the role of the Auditor-General and the relationship between the Auditor-General and the parliament and, therefore, the Auditor-General and the people, because the parliament is the representative of the people. It is for those reasons that I have moved revised additional amendment No. 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —As previously indicated, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the coalition's amendment. It is not as strong as the alternative that we proposed prior to Senator Short moving this one, but it does establish a link of accountability back to the parliament, where it should be. It certainly enables this particular committee to assess whether or not the Attorney-General has, in fact, discharged his duties adequately.

PARA.TAB: I foreshadow that I will be moving a further amendment, shown as 5A, which requires that a certificate be laid before each house of parliament within five sitting days when that consultation has taken place and the Attorney-General has issued the certificate, so that we tie back the accountability to parliament in a very clear fashion. It is in the expectation, I hope, of support from the coalition that we will be supporting this amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 34, page 11, paragraph (2)(f), lines 9 to 11, omit the paragraph.
Subclause (2) sets out the reasons why the Auditor-General must not include particular information in the public report, and paragraph (f) states:
any other reason that could form the basis for a claim by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth in a judicial proceeding that the information should not be disclosed.

The reason for proposing that amendment is that the clause is simply too broad a definition to prevent the publishing of a report. The subclause was specifically raised at the committee meetings on these bills on 3 March. Various witnesses, but in particular Professor Finn, were highly critical of the immensely broad scope contained in this provision. I will not go over again the arguments that Professor Finn made—and I think they were reflected in the comments of other witnesses during what was a very helpful committee debate—other than to repeat that it is an extraordinarily broad set of reasons. We think that paragraph (f) is far too broad a reason which could be used unduly to prevent the publication of information in a public report and, for that reason, we believe it should be omitted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated in my earlier remarks that we are opposed to the coalition's revised additional amendment No. 3 and, for the record, say that, if this amendment were to be carried, then unintended consequences by this Senate are invited. That is the first reason why we are opposed to this amendment. This clause does cover other reasons that we cannot foresee. The risk in writing legislation is that, when you start to itemise reasons, you limit your consideration only to those reasons you have itemised.

PARA.TAB: We are saying that this legislation is deliberately drawn broadly, but it is defined down to it having to prejudice the basis for a claim by the Crown in the right of the Commonwealth in a judicial proceeding. If there is some reason we cannot envisage as a chamber that does that, that is in itself good reason to act and it is not unlimited, as is the contention. But if you remove that, then consequences we cannot imagine—and we are frequently given evidence every day of the week that we do not necessarily see all of the implications of everything that happens—can proceed. That would seem to me to not be in the honest intention of what this chamber has been debating.

The second reason, of course, is that, in judicial actions of the Commonwealth, to remove this provision is to inhibit the ability of the Commonwealth to act fairly. If information which is critical to the Commonwealth winning a legal action is broadcast in public in a way in which that information is undermined, then so is the right of the Commonwealth. Maybe the alternative government wants that to occur, but I cannot foresee that, if those opposite were ever to occupy the treasury benches, that would be true. I record that we are opposed to the amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 34, page 11, after subsection (2), insert the following subsection:
"(2A) A certificate issued under paragraph (1)(b) must be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days after the day it is issued by the Attorney-General.".

The intent of this amendment is very clear from its straightforward wording. We seek to tie back the accountability process to where it belongs, and that is to this Parliament. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was hoping to have Senator Cook's response to the amendment before committing the coalition one way or the other. In principle, we have no problem with Senator Spindler's amendment on behalf of the Democrats. It would seem to us to constitute a doubling up on the requirement of the Attorney to consult with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit before issuing such a certificate. That is, it would provide a second link, as I understand it, to the parliament. We are not sure that that second link is actually necessary, but at the same time we do not oppose the measure, as such. So I was hoping that we might have a response by the government to the proposition other than just a no. As I say, our inclination is to support the Democrat amendment unless we can be convinced of the validity of reasons for not doing so, other than the doubling up aspect that I mentioned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: The doubling up aspect is one of the elements that I would contend, and I think Senator Short has rightfully drawn attention to that. But the main argument that we would advance on this occasion is to say that, in reference to all of those subclauses, (a) to (f), there are quite strong and heavy reasons why information critical to the good conduct of Australia should not become unintendedly available in the public domain. They are security, defence and international relations.

PARA.TAB: I have no problem with the amendment in general. But in particular cases there may well be a very good reason why the Attorney's advice ought not be laid on the table in the parliament because the advice or the decision itself would point to an area of national security or defence or international relations or one of the other provisions under subclauses (b) to (e) of this bill, and that would unnecessarily open this country to security risks or to maladministration in government. For those reasons, we oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the minister, what we are laying before parliament is the certificate issued by the minister, rather than the reasons for issuing the certificate. It seems to me that the concerns of the minister are therefore unfounded and I would suggest that, once again, the accountability process to parliament is the important issue at stake here.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 34, page 11, at the end of subclause (3), add "and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit".

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short, I understood that the arrangement had been made with the opposition that we would be moving an amendment which is substantially very close to yours.

—Senator Spindler, as you will see from the sheet of revised additional amendments, we have two amendments. There is an either/or amendment. I wish to move the first of those two. If that failed, then amendment No. 5 and your amendment would be considered together, I think.

PARA.TAB: The amendment is in line with the earlier amendments that we have been recently discussing to provide a link to the parliament, again via the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, of information not included in a public report by virtue of being considered contrary to the public interest. We have, as I have said, an alternative amendment No. 5, which is the same as Democrat amendment No. 6, but we hope that the chamber will prefer our amendment No. 4 because we think it is superior in certain respects to the other two amendments.

It is a superior option, we think, because it provides the parliamentary link to the entire Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit rather than just the chairman, as in the alternative, who is likely, of course, to be a government member. We believe that the link with the committee as a whole, which is a more representative committee, of course, than just the chairman, does improve the accountability and the breadth of the role of the parliament and the link to the parliament.

This amendment also, of course, forms the second part of the link contained in the recently passed revised additional amendment No. 2 to this clause which required the Attorney to consult with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit before issuing a certificate. Under that amendment the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit is made aware of the suppression of information, and under this amendment the committee is privileged to see such suppressed information if it is provided to the executive.

It is for those reasons we move amendment No. 4. We believe that it fits in more appropriately with the amendments that have already been produced and that it fulfils more and gives more scope for the parliamentary role which is intended by the bills as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to clarify the situation, the Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. If I had moved the Democrats amendment first, I would have sought leave to amend it by excising the `and chairman' words. So, to save time, I will not move our amendment but simply support this amendment of the coalition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the same time, on the same theme, the government is opposed to this amendment. I have set out my reasons as to why we are opposed to the role that this Senate wishes to impose on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit; it is a role which makes the auditor beholden to the committee rather than enshrining the auditor as genuinely independent. This is an attempt now to build that committee into something even more powerful than that. I have given my reasons before in detail; I hypothecate those reasons to this argument now.

PARA.TAB: However, in addition to those reasons, there are further good reasons as to why we ought not proceed with this amendment we are now looking at, since it goes to the whole of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit in whatever form it is constituted now or in the future. That is to say, any matters of national security, any matters of the defence of the Commonwealth—any matters pertaining to all those things set down in (a) to (f)—can go before every member of this committee. We expect, in the real life circumstances, that all those secrets will be kept and guarded.

This is extraordinary. I would be pleased to know at some time, not necessarily tonight, whether the full implications of this amendment are understood by the shadow Attorney-General, the shadow foreign affairs minister, the shadow defence minister and the Leader of the Opposition, and how they would view those implications in connection with the responsibilities they would have, if ever elected. I would be amazed if, from that perspective, they ever supported the intent of these.

The `Leakers Guide to the Galaxy' has as rule one: send a note to some key person and copy it to a dozen others who have a peripheral interest in the subject and, if it then gets out, the field of suspects is so wide no-one knows who did it. This is to use that principle and enshrine it in legislation about the Auditor-General. I think it is just madness.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Cook may have misunderstood the purpose or impact of this. We are not talking about the Auditor-General providing information to all members of the committee on the content of the matters contained in 34(2); we are not talking about him or the committee having access to the fine detail of all the security matters, and so on, that the minister is talking about.

PARA.TAB: What we are talking about are the reports of the Auditor-General on the financial aspects of the conduct of these agencies, or whatever they might be. It is essentially a financial report that we are talking about. We are not talking about reports that go into the specific content of public policy issues, be they security, defence, international relations, or the like.

I think the minister, with respect, has misunderstood, really, the purport of the amendment. Whilst I understand the points that the minister is making, I think that they are essentially irrelevant to the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to unnecessarily prolong this, but a simple reading of subclause (3) implies that where the Auditor-General decides not to prepare a report or to omit particular information from a public report, then the reasons for that will go to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit. That is what it means. What does he do; does he not tell it of what he has omitted, just that he has omitted something and leave it up to the imagination of those on the committee? Surely, a committee such as this will want to know more. Surely the principle of transparency will then be upheld. I just think those opposite are opening Pandora's box. But I have put my views as strongly as I can.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the coalition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 34, page 11, subclause (4), definition of "public report", lines 20 and 21, omit "tabled in either House of the Parliament", substitute "published".

The purpose of amendment 6 is to clarify the definition of `public report' to ensure that orders of the Senate or such other reports to the parliament are not able to be stifled by the Attorney-General issuing a certificate denying publication. It follows from the advice that I tabled earlier, the letters to Senator Gibson and to the Deputy President from the clerk about possible infringements on the Parliament's powers, et cetera, under this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I do not know, again, whether the government intended this to be the case—and I would welcome advice from the minister on this. But the parliament is making it clear that it will not accept the infringement on the parliament's powers that, as drafted, are contained in the legislation. Again, it might be a matter of unintended consequence. I hope that is all it is. But, whether it is or not, I would look forward to the minister's explanation of this and the reasons for the wording as contained. The proposed definitional changes that the coalition is putting forward will still maintain the main intent of this section, without at the same time raising any possible concern about their impact on the Parliament's powers.

So, to that extent, as I said, it is an amendment to clarify the definition of `public report'. I hope that what we are clarifying is an intent that the government actually did have. I would have some very considerable concerns if the government's intent had been otherwise. But I will look forward to hearing from the minister on that aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also have concerns about the possible restriction that this clause may place on the Senate's return to order power. At this stage we are disposed to support the coalition's amendment. I will be interested also to hear the minister's comments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not support the amendment. All of our advice is that the expression appearing in subsection (4) does all of the appropriate things that have been argued for by Senator Short—but that is the proper and appropriate legal way of putting it.

PARA.TAB: The second point I would make is that we do know, as a matter of usage, what the tabling of a report involves in this place and the fact that that becomes public in the proper way. We do not know what the word `published' might mean, and that word is inserted here in substitute. It appears to me that it does invite unintended consequences that may well not be intended by those who are moving this amendment but that, in themselves, will be inappropriate or improper. So we think usage here does suggest that the draftsman's advice to us on this is the appropriate course to follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Minister Cook for his comments but they do nothing to change my attitude towards the matter. I would like to read into the record an excerpt from a letter dated 8 March 1995, written by the Clerk of the Senate to my colleague Senator Gibson. The letter was in response to a letter from Senator Gibson requesting advice on the effect of clause 34 of the bill on the ability of the Auditor-General to respond to a resolution of the Senate requiring the Auditor-General to produce documents or reports. I will not read the whole letter, although it is all very interesting and informative. In relation to clause 34, the Clerk says:

SPEECH.PARA: My view is that clause 34, read in conjunction with clause 22, properly interpreted, would not prevent the Auditor-General responding to a resolution of the Senate for the production of documents or reports.
He goes on to give reasons for that view. Later, he says:

I have little doubt that, if called upon to advise on the matter, the government's legal advisers would claim that the issue of a certificate by the Attorney-General under clause 34 would prevent the Auditor-General from responding to a Senate resolution requiring the production of documents or reports. They would do so on the basis that the definition of "public report" in clause 34 would indicate an intention on the part of the Parliament in enacting the bill to restrict parliamentary powers and immunities.

I therefore think that the matter should be put beyond doubt by some suitable amendment of clause 34 to the effect that the clause would not prevent the Auditor-General responding to a requirement of a House of the Parliament or a parliamentary committee.

We had some discussion on that previously in relation to an earlier amendment, but it is pertinent to this clause and to coalition amendment No. 6, which we are now considering. It is important to have that view on the record, although it is contained in the material tabled earlier.

Clause 37.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 37, page 11, at the end of the clause, add the following subclause:

"(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of any other Act, regulation, determination, order, instrument or enactment, the Auditor-General may employ persons to work in the Audit Office on such terms and conditions as the Auditor-General thinks fit, provided that at the time they are agreed such terms and conditions are consistent with the industrial relations policy of the Government.".

This amendment follows a recommendation of the Public Accounts Committee that the Auditor-General should be able to employ staff under terms and conditions that the Auditor-General thinks fit, provided that, at the time they are agreed, such terms and conditions are consistent with the industrial relations policy of the government. In other words, the government sets the general framework.

PARA.TAB: The audit office is a very small entity—only 250-odd people or so—within the total public service, and there is great difficulty recruiting people with the skills required to make that office work efficiently. The Public Accounts Committee took evidence from state Auditors-General and from the UK's Comptroller-General and Auditor-General. Essentially, the advice was that if the Auditor-General were able to employ staff under conditions set by the Auditor-General, the office would be able to perform a better service than it currently can.

The Public Accounts Committee recommended strongly that such a measure be implemented. There are other examples within the public service—the Federal Airports Corporation, the Federal Police—of organisations with the freedom to act like this. As I said, we are talking about a very small office relative to larger departments within the government, such as Defence and Social Security. We believe that the clause, as worded, protects people through the government's industrial relations policy, allowing for appeal rights, leave entitlements, merit appeal, procedures for unfair dismissal and equal pay for equal work.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats, unfortunately, will be opposing this amendment. I say `unfortunately' because I recognise that the audit office has had some difficulty in retaining very senior staff. However, to deal with that problem by legislation would create a difficulty because it would require the unravelling of the whole application of the Public Service Act to the audit office, including provisions relating to appeal rights, appointment procedures and employment conditions. To do that through legislation would require a massive reproduction of the relevant provisions and extensive consultation with employees.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats are aware that there has been some industrial disputation in the ANAO in recent years. The passing of this amendment, with the best of intentions, would probably severely exacerbate that situation. However, we would urge the government to recognise the recruitment problem that the ANAO has at its top levels and delegate appropriate flexibility to enable it to attract and retain experienced staff.

It is my understanding that there is no restraint in the current public service legislation precluding the establishment of a separate pay category of auditor to allow for competitive salaries. Such a case already exists for medical and dental officers and lawyers. In most states, separate pay grades for auditors are already in place. That is one reason the states do not seem to suffer the same market detraction problem as the ANAO.

I would seek a commitment from the government that the attraction and retention problems in the ANAO be fully investigated and that moves be made to establish an appropriate market-related pay rate for auditors. If it proves that such a scale is not possible under the public service legislation, I foreshadow that we will seek to amend the public service legislation to achieve such a category when the public service reform legislation comes before the Senate next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government too opposes this amendment. Reading this amendment to clause 37 under the heading `staff', one is struck by the similarities to clause 24 of this bill headed `contracting outsiders to assist with audits', which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General, on behalf of the Commonwealth, may engage any person under contract to assist in the performance of any Auditor-General function.

I do not wish to prolong this debate. I cannot see any difference being proposed here to what the provision of clause 27 is, given that the change that now occurs in the coalition amendment, as opposed to an earlier foreshadowed amendment, is that the Auditor-General will be bound by this amendment, if carried, to observe the terms and conditions of the industrial relations policy of the government. Of course he should. But that means that it directly corresponds, as I read it, to an existing clause already passed by the chamber and, therefore, is redundant.

PARA.TAB: In answer to what Senator Spindler has said, the Auditor-General's salary, as I recall, is subject to determination by the Remuneration Tribunal and, therefore, by adoption by the government. That is the office of the Auditor-General himself. So are judges of the High Court, of the Federal Court and of all the other courts of the Commonwealth, and so are decisions of parliamentary remuneration. Parliamentarians have an abysmal record of rejecting decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal, but be that on our own heads. We have a religious conviction about adopting the recommendations for all other officers. If someone such as the Auditor-General is unhappy about that and we are to move to some other form of remuneration determination, what are the guidelines here? And why is the Auditor-General any different from independent officers such as judges?

You have to have a procedure. The procedure is tried and true and workable and effective. It does not stop any of us whose salaries are determined by an arbitral authority disagreeing with the judgments made by that arbitral authority, but the right of the umpire to act here has to be upheld. That is what we do.

I think there is an obligation on the committee not to carry this amendment because it corresponds with an existing provision we have already adopted and adds nothing to the bill. If it adds something to the bill, which is not obvious to me as I stand here, then it puts the Auditor-General outside of the strictures that apply in staff hiring and firing. None of that foregoing is meant to be construed in any way that one is not concerned about retention rates. But the retention rates of staff of the Auditor-General, of the senior officers of the Treasury, of senior scientific officers of the Commonwealth and so on are all a matter for the Commonwealth's concern. What is important about the Auditor-General is his function. The skills that he requires to perform that function are readily available in the market. Those skills are not unique; the function is. To our mind it is appropriate that this amendment not be carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —To assist in the debate I put on the record that the Greens will be opposing this amendment. It has certain attractions. We realise that the conditions under which the Auditor-General operates are different from a number of other departments in that because of the range of areas which the Auditor-General is working in it is necessary from time to time to bring in people with particular expertise because it is simply not possible to carry all of those people with those skills at all times in the department. However, perhaps because the wording of this amendment is so broad it leaves a very wide interpretation, and whilst we might understand that it means that the Auditor-General may see fit to offer a higher rate of terms and conditions to attract certain salaries it might also, with a change of government, without any change in the award system be operated on a lower rate. That is perhaps the problem with this in general. The problem is that it is too broad in the way it is written and therefore we cannot agree to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, thank you for your explanation earlier. We still believe that the amendment we have moved is appropriate for the Audit Office. It gives additional flexibility to the Audit Office and, in your words, if it adds very little, what is the problem? We believe it does add some additional flexibility and so we continue to press ahead with the amendment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Independent Auditor and Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit

SPEECH.PARA: "39A. The Independent Auditor must have regard to the audit priorities advised by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit in accordance with paragraph 8(1)(i) of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951.".

This amendment in essence makes the instruction to the independent auditor in this bill entirely consistent with the due regard that the Auditor-General has to have in accordance with the amendments which were passed earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

SPEECH.PARA: "39A. The Independent Auditor must have regard to the audit priorities advised by the Joint Committee . . .
The Democrats feel that that might be tying the independent auditor too much.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —When this amendment came up with regard to the auditor, I put down the government's objections to that amendment in cinemascope and in technicolour with subtitles. The same arguments apply here. I will not go through them again, but they are delivered with the same passion and conviction. I oppose the amendment.
—Now that the opposition has moved to amend its amendment, the Australian Democrats will be supporting it.

Clause 51.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 51, page 14, after subclause (1), insert the following subclause:
"(1A) Regulations referred to in subsection (1) must not take effect before the time within which they may be disallowed by each House of the Parliament has expired."

This amendment seeks to ensure that the regulations which allow the modification of the application of the Auditor-General Bill to security and intelligence organisations are debated by parliament. This is an important principle. This bill is about the financial accountability and reporting of government agencies to parliament. Only parliament should be able to decide the extent to which organisations should be precluded on security and intelligence grounds.

PARA.TAB: I add that it is the view of the Australian Democrats that such organisations should never be excluded from auditing, but rather the exclusion should refer only to public reporting or the audit results where such reports would be contrary to the public interest. From that point of view, given the existence of clause 34, I wonder about the need for any regulations at all under clause 51—but perhaps that is a debate we will have on another day.

I am aware that this clause goes further than the general disallowance power of the parliament and under the present law this chamber could disallow such a regulation, but that regulation could have been in place for some time. By making it clear with this amendment that a regulation cannot take effect until approved by the parliament, we are going further than allowing for retrospective disallowance. This recognises that any exemptions from the important financial accountability provisions of this piece of legislation are a very serious matter and one to which parliament should give very serious attention. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the opposition supports Senator Spindler's amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is opposed by the government for the reasons I gave in relation to a previous like amendment; the reasons are again hypothecated for this argument with the same force and conviction. It seems that the coalition and the Democrats are bent on putting official secrets at risk or on putting the operations of security and intelligence services at risk. We do not propose to subscribe to that.

Clause 51, as amended, agreed to.

Schedule 1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 16, subitem 1(2), omit the subitem, substitute the following subitem:
"(2) Before making a recommendation to the Governor-General, the Minister must consult the Finance Minister and obtain the approval of the following in respect of the proposed appoint ment:

TAB.TAB: (a)the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives or his or her nominee; and
(b)the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit.".

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of this amendment is to change the procedure for the appointment of the Auditor-General. The bill states that the minister must consult with a nominee of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the chair of the audit committee of parliament, if such a committee exists.

PARA.TAB: The Public Accounts Committee took a lot of evidence on this. There was a firm recommendation in report No. 331 that it would be better for the parliament—again, we are talking here about the primacy of the parliament—for the Auditor-General to be appointed by the parliament and not by the executive.

The amendment basically says that, before making a recommendation to the Governor-General, the minister must consult with the finance minister and obtain the approval of the following in respect of the proposed appointment: the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit.

The thinking there is that if the appointment of the Auditor-General has the agreement of the alternative government in the other place as well as of senators from this chamber via the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, then it really has a commitment from the whole parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. We prefer the somewhat stronger wording of Australian Democrats amendment No. 8. We trust that the coalition and Senator Margetts will see fit to support that. Before we go any further, I ask the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) to comment on whether the government intends to use whatever procedure is decided on tonight, even if it is not in force by the time the government wants to appoint the new Auditor-General. Does the government intend to use the procedure that is decided by this chamber in this legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support this amendment and we made that clear at the inquiry. We set out good, solid reasons at the inquiry for why it is an improper procedure—one that conflicts with the constitutional requirements of the executive and that can render the appointment of an Auditor-General totally unworkable.

PARA.TAB: The act provides that the Auditor-General, in the event of a vacancy, should be appointed as soon as possible. One can imagine a procedure where a Leader of the Opposition might capriciously withhold agreement in order to make a political point. Thus, the ability of the parliament to proceed with the appointment of the Auditor-General is delayed and, in fact, thwarted. That is not in the interests of the Commonwealth.

The constitutional requirement is for an Auditor-General to be appointed as soon as practical. The constitutional obligation is for the government to do that. This bill provides that whoever is the government of the day will consult with the opposition parties, in order to at least make them aware of it, but not surrender the constitutional rights of the executive. I think this amendment would drag the whole thing into a politicisation process that is unwelcome and unwanted.

I further think this arises from a misconception that the Auditor-General is the property of the parliament. The Auditor-General is not the property of the executive either. He is independent. The procedures for the appointment of independent-type statutory positions is clear. It is the same procedure that applies to the High Court and to the other courts of the Commonwealth. It seems to me that this sort of procedure is at odds with all of that. I cannot understand why an opposition that expects to be government would want to embrace this procedure if it were in government.
To answer Senator Spindler's question, the government will comply with the law as it stands at the time a vacancy for the Auditor-General applies. To do anything less than that would be improper.

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe strongly that the parliament has primacy in this matter and that the appointment of the Auditor-General is for parliament to decide and not for the executive alone. We are, if you like, following the UK model. In the UK, following the 1983 act there, both the opposition and the government commit to the appointment of the new Auditor-General there.

PARA.TAB: There is no point me going over it again, but the opposition believes strongly that this is the right thing to do for the parliament. It would be intolerable for an opposition to hinder this process and endeavour to play politics with it. Doing that would bring nothing but odium on that opposition. I do not believe that is a practical impediment and we will be pushing ahead.

I say to Senator Spindler that we believe this procedure is more appropriate for the parliament than the one he has proposed, which is in essence the New South Wales state procedure. The problem with that is that, as it requires approval of a committee, once a nomination has been made and goes before the committee it is very difficult for the committee to knock the person back. I think it is better for that negotiation to take place privately, before it goes before a committee. That is the reason we prefer—I urge the Greens and Senator Harradine to support this—our amendment in the appointment of the Auditor-General.

That the amendment (Senator Gibson's) be agreed to:

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8.Schedule 1, page 16, subitem 1(2), omit the subitem, substitute the following subitems:
"(2) A person is not to be appointed as Auditor General until:

TAB.TAB: (a)a proposal that the person be appointed has been referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit under section 8A of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951; and

(b)either the period that the Committee has under that section to veto the proposed appointment has ended without the Committee having vetoed the proposed appointment or the Committee notifies the Minister that it has decided not to veto the proposed appointment.".

SPEECH.PARA: "(2A) A person may be proposed for appointment on more than one occasion.".

Democrats amendment No. 8 seeks to achieve objectives similar to those of the amendment moved by Senator Gibson on behalf of the coalition. We prefer, rather than to consult the Leader of the Opposition in the lower house, provisions which refer the matter of the appointment of the Auditor-General to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit. We believe that to be a better procedure.

PARA.TAB: We do not accept the minister's contention that the appointment of the Auditor is the prerogative of the executive. We believe that the position is extremely important in our democratic system of government, and we believe that it is an appointment in which the parliament should play a role. We have, therefore, moved this amendment. We add that a person may be proposed for appointment on more than one occasion to enable the process to proceed and not to be bogged down. I commend the amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Spindler that, given that we lost our previous amendment, we are really supporting now what you are intending to do. My query is whether or not we should be moving to have at least a two-thirds majority of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit mentioned in this bill, rather than in the transition bill, which is the next one coming along.
—I inform Senator Gibson that it is my understanding that the two-thirds majority provision will appear in the amendment to the following bill that we will look at.
—Why do we not make an amendment in the Audit Act so that it is clear in the Audit Act as well as in the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill?
—This amendment refers to section 8A of the Public Accounts Committee Act. I understand that that achieves the purpose.
—Would it not be more appropriate to spell out in this bill how the Auditor-General is appointed rather than in the other one? After all, this is the Auditor-General Bill.
—If Senator Gibson prefers to move an amendment to my amendment, I would be prepared to consider it. I am quite happy to proceed on this basis and amend it later.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit

SPEECH.PARA: `5.(1) As soon as practicable after the commencement of the first session of each Parliament, a joint committee of 16 members of the Parliament, to be known as the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, is to be appointed according to the practice of the Parliament with reference to the appointment of members to serve on joint select committees of both Houses of the Parliament.

`(3) If there are minority groups or independents in the Parliament, one member of the Committee is to be a member of the Parliament nominated by such minority groups or independents.

"736B. Subsection 8(1):
Omit the subsection, substitute:
`8.(1) Subject to subsection (2), the duties of the Committee are:

TAB.TAB: (a)to examine the accounts of the receipts and expenditure of the Commonwealth including the financial statements transmitted to the Auditor-General under subsections 50(1) and 56(2) of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1994; and
(b)to examine the financial affairs of authorities of the Commonwealth to which this Act applies and of inter-governmental bodies to which this Act applies; and
