The Opposition and the Australian Democrats have agreed that this major amendment concerning the setting up of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit and its terms of reference should be moved jointly. I wish to advise the committee that the coalition has dropped the last amendment on the back of the list of amendments circulated in Senator Short's name headed `Sectional committees', which was to do with a subcommittee of nine members. The amendment is now identical to the Democrats' amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As on some previous occasions, the Australian Democrats not only support the amendment that has been prepared by the coalition and the Democrats but also desire that it be moved jointly. We request that that be recorded accordingly.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendment moved jointly by the opposition and the Australian Democrats. It still means that they have the numbers in the committee. The reason the government opposes this amendment, which seeks to expand the size and operation of the present Joint Committee of Public Accounts, is that not only will there be too big a workload but also if it becomes a committee dealing with the operation of the Auditor-General we believe in the end the Auditor-General will be at risk of becoming a creature of the parliamentary committee system.

PARA.TAB: It has always been a principle of the Westminster system going back more than 100 years that the Auditor-General be separate from the executive—and everyone agrees with that—and also away from the interference of members of parliament. The Auditor-General reports to parliament on what he or she finds and the parliament debates that. The Auditor-General can only be removed in our constitution and our legislation by a resolution of both houses of parliament. This guarantees the independence of the Auditor-General.

If this amendment was adopted we believe that the Auditor-General would become affected by the operation of the committee, the committee would see that the Auditor-General was reporting to it and not the parliament in its entirety and the Auditor-General would come before the committee on many occasions. It is natural that he would be expected to come before the committee and be subject to cross-examination and required to seek advice. Therefore, the separation between the operation of the Auditor-General and his staff and parliament would start to diminish.

We think that that is a risk that should not be allowed to occur. We believe that the complete separation of the Auditor-General from the executive and from the daily workings of the parliament is a very good principle that ought to be continued. The Auditor-General's reports are extensively debated in this place and no-one wants to diminish that practice, but his reports should be dealt with at arms length from the parliamentary process. He tables his reports and the parliament can then choose to debate, argue, amend and criticise them accordingly.

When the Auditor-General comes before the committee, as he obviously will, an intimacy will develop between the members of the committee and the Auditor-General which we believe would be unhealthy. While the Auditor-General may be conducting an investigation into a government department according to the act, I think senators and members of the House of Representatives would find it too tempting to make comments to the Auditor-General, seek his view about how a particular investigation was going, attempt to influence the way that investigation was going or, at the very least, make political capital and raise an issue. This could affect the perception of the independence of that investigation.

We strongly oppose this recommendation. We are not opposed to proper parliamentary supervision, and we think that is there at the moment. Whether you are in opposition or in government, the principal issue here is the relationship between the Auditor-General and the parliament under our system. This is not an amendment that should be embarked upon lightly. I am not suggesting that the opposition and the Democrats are putting it up lightly, but there are some fundamental issues here, and we ask the Senate to oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Schacht for his comments. The present Public Accounts Committee has a lot of dealings with the Auditor-General right now. So to say that there will be much change in that regard is simply not true. As described in report 331 of the committee, various witnesses at the public hearings pointed out that it would be better to have the Auditor-General's office reporting to a committee which has built up expertise on the running of the audit office over some years, and that committee, rather than a separate committee, should meet as the audit committee of parliament with specific duties as laid out in the amendments. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommended to that effect, and I remind Senator Schacht that there is a majority of government members on that committee.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, in order that the appointment and consideration of the audit office is given some weight by the minor parties—such as the Democrats—the number of members on the Public Accounts Committee was amended from 15 to 16. There is no point in going through the ins and outs of that argument at this hour. It is all set out in report 331. I reiterate that we move the amendment jointly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the amendment moved by the Democrats about the Joint Committee of Public Accounts been adopted by the opposition when the two amendments are put together? You are taking the Democrats amendment on the establishment of the audit committee and adding in the audit provisions to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. So the Democrats amendment and Senator Short's amendment are now combined together, is that correct?
—Our latest amendment and the Democrats original amendment are now word identical.
—Is that right?
—Yes, it is. Item (h) in the Democrats original group of amendments was dropped.

—I see. The one which was dropped was (h), which said `to report to the parliament each year on the annual budget estimates of the Australian National Audit Office'. Is that right? It cannot be, because it is in the list that I have got here.
—That is the old (g).
—So `to consider a proposal under section 8A' has been deleted?
—That has been deleted.
—Further to my comment about the impact on the independence of the Auditor-General, the amendment that both the Democrats and the opposition support says:

TAB.TAB: (i)to advise the Auditor-General on the audit priorities of the Parliament; and
(j)to advise the Independent Auditor of the ANAO on the audit priorities of the Parliament in respect of audits of the ANAO; and

(k)to report to both Houses of the Parliament on any matters arising out of the Committee's consideration of ANAO resources, reports of the Independent Auditor on operations of the ANAO, or other matters relating to the performance of the Auditor-General's functions which the Committee considers should be drawn to the attention of the Parliament; and
(l)to prepare a report each year for presentation to both Houses of the Parliament on the exercise of its functions; and
(m)to review the operations of the ANAO—

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (m) is what the committee would do. In the first paragraphs I read out—certainly (i), (j) and (k) and maybe (l)—it is quite clear that the committee will have an influence over the priorities of the Auditor-General when he is conducting his inquiries. As I understand it, that does not apply at the moment to any of the parliamentary standing committees.

PARA.TAB: We believe that this is the beginning of going down the slippery dip on the independence of the Auditor-General. If the Auditor-General refuses the comment, direction or advice from the committee, does the committee then move a motion condemning the Auditor-General? What happens then? Does the Auditor-General just ignore it? I think that is all a bit pointless. If he ignores it, over a period of time he will be criticised in this place and in the House of Representatives by those members of the committee who made their view known that his priority was to investigate departments A, B and C, various GBEs and so on.

Let us face it: the temptation for whoever is in opposition—whether it is Labor, which may be many years off, Democrats or Liberals—to have a fishing expedition and raise an issue by saying to the Auditor-General, `I've heard some scuttlebutt about a particular department. Let's go after them,' will occur from time to time. We believe that that will add a politicisation to the process that will not be good for the committee, and I do not think it will be very good for the Auditor-General.

On behalf of the government, I warn the opposition and the Democrats that this amendment will have the consequence—and I do not think the opposition and the Democrats are aware of this—of politicising the process. It will create pressure on the Auditor-General to respond to a party political view about where he should be conducting his investigations. That is for whoever who is in opposition. You would be a mug to be in opposition and not have a go when you think there is an area that you can make political capital out of. I do not think the Auditor-General should be put in that position.

I think the parliament now has a more than adequate ability to comment publicly in both houses about what it thinks the role of the Auditor-General ought be. We have more than enough opportunities to ask the Auditor-General to appear before joint committees, Senate committees and House of Representatives committees. Last year and the year before the opposition had the Auditor-General before the estimates committee over the rent he was paying at Centenary House in Canberra. That is a legitimate issue, whatever you think of the argument, and it is right that people can raise it.

That shows that there will be a temptation on whoever is in opposition. I am not being partisan about this. If we were in opposition, an opposition senator or member would be tempted to tell the Auditor-General to investigate a particular issue. We would do this because we could make political capital out of it. Therefore, those amendments indicate to us that there is a concern that the process would lead to unnecessary pressure on the independence of the Auditor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the minister's concern but I do not share it. I think this is a question of whether the parliament has a role in advising the Auditor-General. There is no compulsion here; it is not mandatory and, in a sense, this is a re-run of the debate we had last time this package was before the chamber. We are suggesting the Auditor-General be advised by the committee that the committee express its preferences but the Auditor-General does not have to accept them. The minister says that, if the Auditor-General decides not to accept some of the suggestions, some of the advice, proffered by the committee, it will politicise the process.

PARA.TAB: I would suggest to the minister that it is part of our parliamentary process to have these issues debated up front. The Auditor-General can advise the committee and through the committee the Auditor-General can advise parliament as to the reasons why he or she has not accepted particular advice proffered by the committee. The Democrats would much rather have that debate out in the open on the floor of the chamber, or parliament generally, rather than have the circuitous process that is now taking place.

The suggestion to establish the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit dates back quite some time to the recommendations that were made by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. We believe that it is time this particular mechanism was put in place. We do not share the minister's concern. We believe that these matters should be aired in public and that parliament is the proper arena for that to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Spindler's view on this matter. I would remind the minister that the items he was talking about are in fact duties of the committee, not the Auditor-General.
—But as duties of the committee they affect the relationship of the committee to the Auditor-General.

—With giving advice, that is true. I just remind you of an amendment which we moved to the previous bill that we passed earlier, the Auditor-General Bill. The amendment was to add a new clause 8A which stated that the Auditor-General should, as far as is practicable, have regard to the audit priorities advised by the committee. That is all we are doing. So I do not think there is a serious problem as you have outlined. We will push ahead with the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The difference is that this committee is going to not only suggest which areas it thinks are of priority but also review the activities of the Auditor-General. When you combine suggesting as well as reviewing activities, you are developing a relationship that has influence on the Auditor-General's performance.

PARA.TAB: As I say, I suspect in the first year or so it will be hunky-dory. But after a few years, once familiarity develops and some hot political issue arises, you will find there will be a politicisation of that role. People will take the review activities of the proposed committee and its right to advise the Auditor-General together to put pressure on the Auditor-General by saying, `If you don't do this review as we're suggesting, then we will criticise you in our annual report to parliament when we review your performance.'

That pressure can develop. As I say, in the first couple of years I suspect it will be reasonably amenable, but as soon as there is an issue someone in opposition—this is not the present opposition, just generally—will say, `Okay, we're going to use this to heat some issue up' and will say to the Auditor-General, `We'll have a go at you.' If the Auditor-General has not followed through, he will be accused of making a political decision to not follow the committee's instruction or advice. Secondly, someone in opposition will say, `We'll put that in our annual review back to parliament and have another go at you.' That is political pressure which is a potential and it would be unfortunate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your comments. I just remind you that as things stand right now the government has by far the majority of numbers on the Public Accounts Committee; it has nine out of 15. Even with the amendment as proposed here of increasing the members by one, the government would still have the numbers. An opposition trying to play politics—
—There are things called minority reports.
—Yes, I know. Anyway, I hear your point.

SPEECH.PARA: `8A.(1) The Minister is to refer a proposal to appoint a person as:

This amendment gives the committee a role in the appointment of the Auditor-General. The arguments in favour of that particular amendment duplicate those that were discussed in the amendment to schedule 1 of the audit bill and I shall not repeat them. I commend the amendment to the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose this amendment. I am advised that earlier on Senator Cook gave reasons on behalf of the government as to why we oppose this amendment about the power of veto for the proposed appointment of the Auditor-General.

—I note what the minister is saying. The Australian Democrats believe that this is important. The appointment of the Auditor-General is an exceedingly important procedure. We believe that parliament, through the committee, should have a role in it. I commend the amendment to the chamber.
—The coalition supports the Democrat amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Now I have had a chance to read the amendment myself I can see why Senator Cook strongly opposed it. Anyone in opposition for a period of time could say, `Well, we are probably not going to be in government for a while. How can we take some power for ourselves in opposition over what has been traditionally a government appointment process by the executive?' We have had this process now for 94 years in Australia. What we have here is a proposal for the appointment to be vetoed if it is not supported by at least two-thirds of all the members of the committee, which basically means the two major parties on the committee have to agree.

PARA.TAB: I will bet two bob to the Sydney Harbour Bridge that, if Senator Gibson were on this side of the chamber in government, he would not have a bar of this amendment because, when you are in government, the executive has the power to make these appointments. I have to say I have not heard any general criticism that has been sustained about the quality of the people who have been appointed to the Auditor-General's position over 94 years, so you cannot criticise the calibre of the people who have been appointed. I suppose from time to time all auditors-general have given the government harder times than they have given the opposition—the Auditor-General's reports are always a feast for opposition and are more of a famine for government.

Therefore, we strongly oppose this amendment. We believe that the position of the Auditor-General ought to be appointed by the executive. The two-thirds majority basically means, effectively, that the opposition, not the Democrats, has the veto over this appointment ad infinitum. We do not believe that this ought to stand, and we oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We went through this before. The essence of what the coalition and the Democrats are saying is that the audit committee of parliament should be appointed by parliament and should answer to parliament, and that the Auditor-General should be appointed basically by the parliament—the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit is the representative of the parliament—rather than the executive making appointment. The important principle is that this is an across-the-board—
—You wouldn't be saying that if you were the government, Senator.

—I think we would, actually, because I think this is very important for the future of the parliament. It is something new here, but it is not new elsewhere. As I said earlier, we are just following what happens in the UK, where the act was changed in 1983. The Auditor-General there is appointed by both sides of politics, and we want to make sure that that happens here. What we have proposed here would ensure, if you like, that all the main players in the parliament—the government, the alternative government in the other chamber, and senators here, as appointed to the public accounts committee—would have a hand in the appointments. We think that is very important for the parliament and for the future of the parliament. I support the amendment.

—The minister has put his finger on the basic shift that is being attempted in these amendments to the bill, and the shift is simply from sole control by the executive government to control by parliament. That clearly is the objective that we are pursuing; that clearly is, I would submit to the minister, a desirable objective. I believe that the government should recognise that and support it.

—I have just one brief comment from the point of view of the Greens (WA). There are times—and I think we are beginning to see one now—when a government has been in office for such a long time that it begins to be sloppy and begins to be a little less mindful of the Auditor-General. At times, one feels that, if there were to be an appointment of the Auditor-General, there would be a great temptation for the government to find somebody who would perhaps not give it such a hard time. So I think, as the role of the Auditor-General is to be an independent arbiter—
—I don't think you could say that of any of the auditors-general in the last 12 years.

—No, perhaps that could not be said about any of the auditors-general over the last 12 years, but we are now looking at audit not just in terms of financial audit but in terms of performance audit. We are actually finding questions like: is the government doing what it says it is going to do? The question is not just, `Has it spent money wisely?' but, `Is it doing what it says it is doing?' I am sure that at times this gets up the government's nose.
—That is the efficiency audit, Senator.

—Yes, and I think, as you well know, Minister, this is the Auditor-General's role as well. Therefore, the Greens would be in favour of an Auditor-General who had bipartisan support so that we could make sure that governments who perhaps have been in office for a long period of time do not get a little slack and do not get a little tetchy at being audited in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to make a few comments about a speech by Ms Eva Cox, co-convenor of the Women's Economic Think Tank who spoke in Canberra a couple of weeks ago to celebrate International Women's Day, an event which attracted quite some media attention. I want to draw to the attention of the Senate some of the things that she said in the course of that speech which I think are noteworthy.

PARA.TAB: She made the point that, in her view, mothers at home should stop asking the government for money and stop making women who work feel guilty. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . once your kid is 12 months old . . . you should be able to spend some time away from them, even before. Its good for the kids, its good for the adults—
She claimed that the government spent $6 billion to support women at home compared with only $600 million on child care. She also said:
. . . the people who benefit from having a woman at home is the man, not the community, not necessarily the children.

I found those comments unbelievable, extraordinary and, in many ways, very sad. I think that is the emotion that many people felt when they heard what Ms Cox was saying. The hostility that Ms Cox clearly has towards mothers who sacrifice an income to care for their children at home really is quite sad and something that is an ugly development in the whole question of feminist politics. What Ms Cox and her ilk are really doing is almost declaring war from their point of view on women who stay at home with their children. Really, if you examine what she said in her speech, most of her comments were either wrong, misleading or unfair, or a combination of all those factors.

PARA.TAB: It was pretty clear to me that what Ms Cox was on about was an attack on the campaign by Mrs Carole Carroll of Adelaide who has formed an organisation called Choice for Families and has lead a campaign nationwide to draw this nation's attention to the fact that mothers at home with young children have received very unfair treatment from this government. Of course, Mrs Carroll and Ms Cox faced each other on A Current Affair as a result of Ms Cox's speech.

My point tonight is to make it clear that, in my view, the government itself is largely responsible for the bitterness and division between women in the full-time work force and women who are caring for their children at home and the government must take responsibility for what I regard as a very sad development among women in Australia.

As the Senate would know, Mrs Carroll's campaign, which has received nationwide attention and nationwide support, resulted from the inequity in government policy, particularly in relation to the home child-care allowance and the child-care cash rebate. As most senators would be aware, the child-care cash rebate paid to mothers who are in the full-time work force with children in child care has no income test at all. You can, as a woman, earn hundreds of thousands of dollars a year and receive the benefit, and it is paid at double the rate of the home child-care allowance for a mother of two. Of course, for a mother of two, the home child-care allowance has a very severe income test. So it is clearly unfair to mothers who sacrifice an income to care for their children at home on those two grounds.

In response to Ms Cox, it must be pointed out that, despite Ms Cox's claims, Mrs Carroll and her supporters have not asked for more money from the government. All they are asking for is just and fair and equitable distribution of the funding that the government currently provides for women who have young children. It should be pointed out to Ms Cox that the government's very own National Council for the International Year of the Family recognised the significant problems that have arisen as a result of the introduction of the home child-care allowance and the child-care cash rebate and the inequities that have occurred. The Cass report—that is, the report of the National Council for the International Year of the Family chaired by Professor Cass—has called for the amalgamation of these two payments because of the problems engendered by them. The Cass report recognised this very point I am trying to make tonight—that government policy is dividing women who are at home with their children and women in the full-time work force, and that is an undesirable development in the Australian community.

I must say that I think the Cass report heads in the right direction. The government should acknowledge the costs of bringing up young children, but it should do so in a way which does not base the support on whether or not the children are in child care or at home or whether or not the mother is in the full-time work force. The payment should be based solely on the fact that there are children to be looked after. So the Cass report is to be commended for the direction in which it heads. The government said that it would respond quickly to that report, which came out in November-December. We have had no response whatsoever and I look forward to the government dealing with this report properly in the budget.

The point is that government policy, quite clearly, is loaded in favour of full-time work and the child-care option. Government documents and rhetoric are loaded with the flavour that policy should be directed at increasing the female participation rate in the work force, that policy should be aimed to that end; therefore child care should be provided and money should be spent on child care. I remind the Senate that there has been a 17 per cent increase in real terms every year for the last 10 years in government funding of child care. This is a massive increase. In fact, expenditure on child care is going to double between 1992-93 and 1996-97. In only a four-year period, expenditure will go from something like $500 million to $1,000 million. So it is nonsense for Ms Cox to claim that there is some bias the other way. That is simply not the case.

Also, to contradict Ms Cox, it is mothers at home who now feel guilty. They are the ones who feel that society is pressuring them to place their children in child care and enter the full-time work force despite their desire to care for their children at home full time. There is no doubt that the contribution of mothers at home is unrecognised by society and it is a great pity that the Ms Coxes of the world do not recognise the contribution and the sacrifices made by mothers at home caring for their young children. Certainly the Australian Family Association petition calling for a homemakers allowance which has had a most massive response is an indication of the community feeling that really the contribution of mothers at home is not recognised. For Ms Cox to say that only men benefit from a mother being at home with her children really can only be described as stone age feminism. Most feminists nowadays reject that and the enlightened feminists recognise the importance of giving credit to those mothers who do sacrifice an income to care for their children at home. They do make a very big contribution to our society and to the care of our children.

In response to Ms Cox, I think what she must recognise and what the government must recognise is the need to focus policy on providing choice for families. Mrs Carroll's organisation is most aptly named. That is what families are looking for from the government—neutrality in policy and the maximum provision of choice in the arrangements that families make as to the care of their children. The government should be giving families the maximum opportunity possible to choose the arrangements that they think are most suitable to their family environment and to their children. Government policy should be neutral on the question of whether children are in child care or cared for at home.

I applaud the recent speeches by our new leader, John Howard, on this very subject. He has made it quite clear that this will be one of our most important themes as we run up to the next election. I conclude by saying that Ms Cox's outburst two weeks ago was most unfortunate, a very sad development, but the blame for the division which clearly exists can be laid fairly and squarely at the government's door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time ago in the adjournment debate I spoke of my concern about the global arms trade and about Australia's contribution through its arms sales into our own region. In the era after the Cold War and the Gulf War, we can set long-term foreign policy goals and act on them since there is no immediate threat to Australia. One goal can be to try to avoid setting the stage for future conflicts. With the exception of Japan, the arms importers in our region are all poor countries. India, the number one importer, is desperately poor, with a per capita income of $335 per year.

PARA.TAB: With the end of the Cold War it makes little sense to pour arms into our troubled region. Yet at times the Australian government tries to make a case for it. However, this is a recent development. Earlier government statements opposed the escalation of the arms trade. In 1986 the then foreign minister, Bill Hayden, told the United Nations that `arms transfers should not become a new cash crop'. Bill Hayden, a humanist, agrees on this point with the Catholic Church. The new catechism contains the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The arms race does not assure peace; far from eliminating the causes of war, it risks aggravating them. Squandering untold wealth on the purchase of ever-newer arms impedes efforts to help needy populations and thwarts the development of peoples. Over-armament multiplies reasons for conflict and increases the danger of escalation.
Further, the catechism says:

Arms production and trafficking affect the common good of nations and the international community. Hence public authorities have the right and duty to regulate them. The short-term pursuit of private or collective interests cannot justify enterprises that promote violence and conflict among nations and compromise the international juridical order.

Yet, despite these objections, the operation of the guidelines on arms transfer put out by the Ministry of Defence are not subject to public scrutiny, so they are not meaningful regulations. The Minister of Defence can approve transfers with no public review.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats believe that it is not in the public interest for this to continue. They have placed before the Senate a bill to provide for a public inquiry into Australia's real defence and security needs. The Democrats argue that South East Asian countries are upgrading their armaments. We believe that these arms transfers to the area will lessen Australia's security—and for the following reasons: firstly, by arming a repressive government we may arm a future enemy. If that government is overthrown, the new government is likely to be an enemy of Australia. Arming potential enemies lessens Australia's security. Secondly, resources in Third World countries devoted to armaments lessen the ability of the government to meet human and environmental needs. Australia will also be affected.

Is there an example where supplying arms to an area, building up or updating armaments has increased security? Has there been a study of the political, economic, social and environmental effects of arms transfers into the South East Asian countries? If not, would it not be wise to make one before putting more arms into the area? Human rights violations have a greater importance in the arms trade than in any other type of trade. Selling shoes to an oppressive country does not add to the misery of the people; selling arms does.

Military spending is declining for the first time in our lifetime. At this rate of decline, there could be a total peace dividend of $2,000 billion in the 1990s: $1,600 billion in the developed world and $400 billion in the developing world. Except for the arms dealers, the arms makers and military bureaucrats, the arms trade is against Australia's best interests.

In 1789 William Wilberforce introduced his first parliamentary resolution to outlaw the trade in human flesh. In 1789 the trade in human flesh was accepted and legal. Eventually, the whole world outlawed slavery as well as the slave trade. In 1994 the trade in the destruction of human flesh is accepted and legal. However, it is no more acceptable than the trade in human flesh or slavery which was outlawed so long ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to refer briefly to the by-election held in Canberra last Saturday, which was won so convincingly by the Liberal Party and its candidate, Brendan Smyth, who will shortly take his place as the member for Canberra in the other place. There was an enormous amount of literature placed in letterboxes, most of it from the Labor Party. I heard of people who said that they had had five or six pieces of literature placed in their letterbox over the relevant period. I shall certainly be interested to find out exactly how much the Labor Party spent on the campaign when it is all disclosed—certainly it was a vastly greater sum than we were able to spend. One pamphlet, I would estimate, must have cost nearly as much as our whole campaign.

PARA.TAB: One of the interesting letters was from Dr Carmen Lawrence which was sent out purporting to be an individual, personally addressed letter to women in Canberra. But, in fact, that letter was virtually identical to one she wrote last year for the electorate of Torrens in South Australia for the election on 7 May there. I just want to point out, in a sense, the cynicism of this letter and the way it was used. I also wish to place the letter on the record because no doubt Dr Lawrence will continue to do this type of thing in the future.

The first and second paragraphs of the two letters are identical. The third paragraph of the letter distributed in Canberra mentions the name `Sue Robinson', `Canberra', and `25 March 1995'; the South Australian letter includes the words `Robyn Geraghty', `Torrens', and `May 7'. In the next paragraph, comparing the two letters, the only difference is `Sue' in one and `Robyn' in the other. In the next paragraph, the letters are slightly more personalised: one mentions `Sue Robinson' and her husband's name and that she had `lived and worked in Canberra'; the other letter, of course, mentions `Robyn Geraghty', her children and `the north-eastern suburbs of Adelaide'.

The next sentence of that paragraph is identical in both letters, which is why I suggest that the whole exercise is somewhat cynical. Maybe it is just a coincidence that the two women were so similar. In each it says:

SPEECH.PARA: She has had tough times herself, in her family and work life, and this has been a strong basis for her compassion and common sense.

The next paragraph refers to each of them having been community workers, one for six years, one for eight years, and again says of each of them `has taken on government departments to solve the problems of ordinary people'. That seems to be a very strange comment indeed in relation to Sue Robinson, given that she, in fact, had been working for a Labor minister in the ACT government for a period of time prior to this.

PARA.TAB: The next paragraph in both letters just has the different dates and electorate names. The PS is different: in the South Australian letter, it refers to women obtaining the vote 100 years ago; and in the letter to Canberra women, it says that at the moment only 14 out of 147 members of the House of Representatives are women.

I think the women of Australia deserve better if they are to receive personal letters—letters that really could relate candidates somewhat better to the electorate concerned than this exercise of virtually just having a few spaces in the computer and typing in a different word for a letter firstly in Adelaide and then in Canberra. But I suggest that the people of Canberra noted what had occurred and acted accordingly. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of each of the two letters from which I have quoted.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: FEDERAL MEMBER FOR FREMANTLE
MINISTER FOR HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
26th April, 1994
Dear
Things still need to change for women. In my grandmother's day women carried a huge work load but had very little say. My mother raised a family of seven and still helped manage the farm.
Today women still carry most of the family workload yet we have such a small voice in government.
I am writing this letter to support Robyn Geraghty, who is the Labor candidate for Torrens in the election on May 7.
Let me assure you I'm not supporting Robyn simply because she is a woman.

Robyn Geraghty married, with two sons and a little grandson, has lived and worked in the north eastern suburbs of Adelaide all her adult life. She has had tough times herself, in her family and work life, and this has been a strong basis for her compassion and common sense.

The election in Torrens will not change the Government. but your choice on May 7 is between yet another Liberal man to swell the back bench, and a very special woman who will voice community concerns.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I follow two very fine speakers in this debate on the adjournment this evening. My colleagues have rationally and properly condemned two ministers—the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, and the Minister for Human Services and Health, Carmen Lawrence. As a change of pace, I actually seek to praise one minister out of the whole Keating government.
—I am shocked!

—I do feel very out of place. Perhaps I should adjourn my speech and continue it tomorrow. But I will take this opportunity to speak on a matter that I raised in the Senate several weeks ago. It relates to the portfolio of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Punch.

PARA.TAB: On 6 February I brought up a matter of bureaucratic error committed by the Australian Defence Force that led to a grievance for a Gold Coast family, the family of Lieutenant John Fraser who died serving his country in the Vietnam War back in 1968. The family received a letter from the Australian Defence Force addressed `John Fraser', the deceased John Fraser. That hurt is accentuated for anyone knowing the story of Lieutenant Fraser, a story that has been told many times in the Senate. To the people of the Gold Coast he is an unsung hero of that war.

I placed a petition with the minister on 6 February and, with all the goodwill of the old style hands-on politician that he is, Mr Punch swiftly moved to address the matter. He personally phoned the Fraser family and followed up by writing them a letter. I can say here this evening that they are grateful for his actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good minister.
—He is a good minister. Senator Herron does not give away such compliments lightly, as anyone who heard his earlier contribution to this debate would know.

PARA.TAB: My second point also relates to the good minister—at least for this week—Mr Punch. If the reports are correct, he has moved to review the decision of previous governments not to establish the end of war list. I quote from the Weekend Australian of 26 March 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government is ready to heal one of the last wounds of the Vietnam War by reviewing a controversial 1972 decision not to award military honours to some Australian soldiers who committed acts of heroism.
It goes on:

The Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Punch, has ordered the Department of Defence to review the 1972 decision by the McMahon Government—later confirmed by the Whitlam Government—not to create a so-called end of war list after the Vietnam War.

I urge Mr Punch not to be swayed from this task. It can be done. The mechanisms are there, if not simple. I know that some of his advisers will say that he is in danger of lifting the expectations of and potentially disappointing the people and the families of people from that time. I have heard all those arguments in the past.

PARA.TAB: The mere establishment of the tribunal is the completion of the minister's responsibility. It is the very final step in bringing home our soldiers. It may be that few cases can properly be investigated; it may be that, on investigation, cases may warrant only honourable mention. Those pushing for an end of war list understand that and have always understood it.

It is no argument to say that too much time has elapsed to investigate acts of heroism. After all, in this parliament we passed the War Crimes Amendment Bill that sought justice some 50 years after the Second World War. The justice there was the seeking of war criminals. The end of war list similarly seeks justice in seeking heroes some 30 years after the Vietnam War. I urge the minister to plough on with his intent, to pass all the hurdles that might be put in front of him because it is a cause most worthy.

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the major tariff and non-tariff barriers to Australian agricultural exports to the following countries which will not be phased out with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) agreements: (a) Cambodia; (b) People's Republic of China; (c) Taiwan; (d) Fiji; (e) Hong Kong; (f) India; (g) Indonesia; (h) Japan; (i) South Korea; (j) Malaysia; (k) New Zealand; (l) Papua New Guinea; (m) the Philippines; (n) Singapore; (o) Thailand; and (p) Vietnam.
(2) What negotiations are currently underway to remove these barriers.
(3) For those countries which are signatories to the GATT are there any expected problems in fulfilling their GATT obligations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Agreement on Agriculture contains concessions and commitments on market access, domestic support and export subsidies. A formula-based approach was agreed as the basic framework for the negotiations on agriculture with separate, specific reductions in these three areas.

All Uruguay Round commitments are to be undertaken over the six-year implementation period of the Round, commencing in 1995 for developed countries. For developing countries the implementation period is 10 years.

The agriculture package is part of a continuing process with the long-term objective of securing substantial progressive reductions in trade-distorting support and in protection. A special provision of the Agreement calls for further negotiations in the fifth year of implementation.
As part of the implementation process, a Committee on Agriculture will be established to monitor the implementation of commitments under the Agriculture Agreement.

Non-tariff barriers for agricultural products (such as import restrictions, non-automatic import licensing, voluntary restraint arrangements, import prohibitions) have been tariffied under the requirements of the Uruguay Round Agriculture Agreement. The conversion of these barriers to tariff equivalents (often at very high and prohibitive levels) has therefore required the opening of tariff quotas at lower tariff rates to allow trade to flow. The administration and implementation of these arrangements will be important in determining the level of Australia's access to those markets which were previously closed or significantly impeded by non-tariff barriers. All WTO members' Uruguay Round obligations, including tariff quota commitments, will come under close scrutiny when they are notified to the Committee on Agriculture.

The tariffication of non-tariff barriers is the first step towards removing the impediments to trade in agricultural products. The reduction of tariffs and the reinstrumentation of agricultural support and subsidisation are part of the continuing reform agenda being pursued by Australia for agricultural trade.
(a) Cambodia
We are not aware of any major tariff or non-tariff barriers to Australian agricultural exports to Cambodia, but will be looking to ensure continuing access.
(b) China

In the context of China's application to accede to the GATT, Australia is negotiating bilaterally to reduce tariffs and, to the extent possible, eliminate non-tariff barriers. In particular we are seeking improved access for a range of products including wool, grains, dairy, horticulture, meat and processed foods, some of which currently face restrictive state trading arrangements, import licensing or quantitative import restrictions.
(c) Taiwan

In the context of Taiwan's application to accede to the GATT Australia is seeking significantly improved access for a wide range of products including beef, dairy, and horticulture, where there are currently a range of tariff and non-tariff barriers including import prohibitions, discretionary import licensing and discriminatory quantitative restrictions.
(d) Fiji

No major non-tariff barriers have been identified by exporters which are impairing market access for Australian agricultural products. However, Australia has concerns over the possible imposition of a quota system for imports of frozen chicken into Fiji.
(e) Hong Kong
There are no major tariff or non-tariff barriers to Australian agricultural exports.
(f) India

India has restrictive import licensing on most agricultural products. These restrictions remain in place because of balance-of-payments (BOP) difficulties. Under the Uruguay Round Agriculture Agreement, restrictions maintained for BOP reasons were not required to be tariffied. The negotiated tariff bindings contained in India's Uruguay Round agriculture schedule will become applicable once India has lifted its balance-of-payments restrictions. In any case, these tariff bindings are generally quite high.
(g) Indonesia

Indonesia has tariffied the non-tariff barriers applying to agricultural products under the terms of the Uruguay Round Agriculture Agreement. However, ceiling bindings on select products remain quite high and the details of how Indonesia is to implement its Uruguay Round commitments, including the administration of Indonesia's tariff quota for rice, have yet to be determined. Indonesia will be required to notify these arrangements to the Committee on Agriculture.
(h) Japan

Australia remains concerned about excessive plant and quarantine restrictions, food standards and certification requirements (affecting our trade for example in a range of horticultural products such as cut flowers, apples, oranges and lemons, meat and processed foods) and with the role of state trading bodies such as the Food Agency and the Livestock Industry Promotion Corporation (LIPC) in controlling imports.
(i) Korea

Korea has remaining balance-of-payments (BOP) restrictions on several agricultural products. Korea has indicated a liberalisation program and the tariff bindings for these products in its Uruguay Round agriculture schedule. The existing quota restrictions applying to these BOP items (with the exception of beef) will be liberalised and replaced by tariff quotas by 1 July 1997.

ANSWER.PARA: For beef, all restrictions will be removed by 2001. Current import arrangements are based on records of understanding (ROUs) with supplier countries. As part of the Uruguay Round settlement, Korea agreed that the ROUs would be the basis for discussion of the detail of access arrangements during the Uruguay Round implementation period (post-1995 when the current ROU expires).

PARA.TAB: There are an increasing number of Australian products affected by restrictive shelf life regulations (frozen cheesecake, UHT milk, UHT soy milk, frozen hamburger patties, frozen meat pies, salami).

ANSWER.PARA: Animal quarantine issues also restrict trade in an increasing range of products, for example, live bees, hatching eggs and poultry, game meats, hides and skins and dairy. Plant quarantine requirements also restrict our access for a range of horticultural products such as citrus and stone fruits.

PARA.TAB: (j) Malaysia

Malaysia has tariffied non-tariff barriers applying to agricultural products, for example, the import prohibition on liquid milk. Australia has concerns over the high tariff level for imports of infant yoghurt. Under Malaysia's tariff classification, infant yoghurt is a dairy product and therefore subject to higher tariff rates.
(k) New Zealand

Australia agricultural exports which meet Rules of Origin and quarantine requirements under the Closer Economic Relations agreement enter New Zealand duty free. There are no non-tariff barrier issues outstanding.
(l) Papua New Guinea

Papua New Guinea became a Contracting Party to the GATT in December 1994. It has also accepted the WTO Agreement and if its market access schedules are finalised by 31 March 1995, it will become a WTO member.
We have concerns over the quantitative restrictions imposed on beef imports in November 1994 (and proposed for sheepmeat from 1 January 1996).
(m) Philippines

The Philippines has tariffied the non-tariff barriers which applied to agricultural products, for example, the quantitative restrictions on live cattle. Australia faces quarantine prohibition on fresh fruit and vegetables from mainland Australia.
(n) Singapore
There are no major tariff or non-tariff barriers to Australian agricultural exports. Singapore applies zero tariffs on all agricultural products.
(o) Thailand
Australian exports of fresh citrus face quarantine prohibition. In addition, Thailand has high tariffs on selected processed foods such as breakfast cereals, chocolate confectionery and canned meats.
(p) Vietnam
We are not aware of any major tariff or non-tariff barriers to Australian agricultural exports.

(2) Australia has taken every opportunity to discuss trade issues with its trading partners. We are an active participant in GATT/WTO accession negotiations. The accession process includes a rigorous examination of an applicant's policies to determine modifications which would be required to make its foreign trade and industry policies conform with the WTO. This process includes extensive bilateral market access negotiations with interested WTO members which seek to remove or reduce barriers to trade. Relevant parties in Australia are consulted during market access negotiations.

Australia is fully engaged in negotiations with applicants where there is a direct trade interest. Our objective in WTO accession is to ensure that applicants agree to abide by the rules and to gain maximum binding commitments to market access liberalisation. Every effort will be made to ensure that Australian market access concerns with applicants are addressed during the accession process.

APEC provides a second approach through which Australia can pursue trade liberalisation: 12 of the 16 countries in question are members of APEC. APEC leaders, meeting in Indonesia last year, agreed to implement free trade in the region by no later than 2020. We will be seeking to reach agreement this year on a process that will begin to implement that commitment.
A third approach includes Ministerial representations, formal bilateral forums, regular officials discussions and direct representations through Australian posts.
(a) Cambodia

When Cambodia commences its accession process to the World Trade Organisation (WTO), we would again look to ensure continued access in areas where there are opportunities for Australian agricultural exports.
(b) China

In the context of China's application to accede to the GATT/WTO, Australia is negotiating bilaterally to reduce tariffs and, to the extent possible, eliminate non-tariff barriers. China sought to finalise negotiations on its accession to the GATT by the end of 1994, but was not able to make offers which were sufficient to enable the negotiations to be concluded. Australia is strongly supportive, in principle, of China's accession to the GATT/WTO and continues to play an active part in this process. While it is in the best interests of the world trading system that China does become a member of the GATT/WTO, China can only accede in a manner fully consistent with the rules of the GATT and the WTO.

Like other countries participating in the negotiations, Australia accepted that the proposed trade liberalisation commitments currently on offer from China are a step forward but are not sufficient to enable its accession to proceed. Australia is negotiating bilaterally with China to open the Chinese market in a way which provides practical new commercial opportunities for a wide range of Australian exports.
(c) Taiwan

Taiwan is currently in the process of negotiating its accession to the GATT and the World Trade Organisation. Australia strongly supports Taiwan's accession to the GATT/WTO and continues to play an active part in this process. As a member, Taiwan will be required to abide by the multilateral trade rules thus securing maximum opening of Taiwan's market to Australian products.
In the context of Taiwan's application to accede to the GATT/WTO, Australia is seeking significantly improved access for a wide range of products including beef, dairy, and horticulture.
(d) Fiji

Representations have been made to the Fijian Government over the possible imposition of a quota system for imports of frozen chicken into Fiji, noting the inconsistency such a move would be with Fiji's commitments under the WTO. Essentially such a move by the Fijian authorities would be to accommodate imports of U.S. sourced frozen chicken meat which are presently prohibited by quarantine restrictions.
(e) Hong Kong
There are no major tariff or non-tariff barriers to Australian agricultural exports.
(f) India
The issue of India's high level of protection for its agricultural sector has been raised in Ministerial meetings, including the Joint Ministerial Commission.
(g) Indonesia

Australia is seeking improved tariff reductions on imports on beef (and the easing or removal of the licensing requirements), a range of fresh fruits and processed foods. These issues have been raised in the Australia-Indonesia Ministerial Forum Working Group on Trade, Industry and Investment.

Australia is working with Indonesia on arrangements to gradually phase out (over 10 years) the mixing requirements facing certain dairy products as part of tariffication under the Uruguay Round. The first officials consultations were held in mid-March. These consultations will be important in determining how Indonesia chooses to implement its Uruguay Round commitments in terms of the administration of its dairy tariff quota.
(h) Japan

In response to Japan's announcement of its proposed five-year deregulation action program, Australia has lodged a submission on regulatory issues relevant to Australian market access concerns. These cover land and housing issues, information and telecommunications, financial services, legal services, food and agricultural products, government procurement and other market access and distribution issues.

The Government of Australia has also participated in Japanese Government processes addressing market access problems facing foreign enterprises (i.e. through the OTO Annual Review on Standards and Certification, the meetings of the Import Board and a submission to the Agricultural Policy Advisory Council).

Selected priority issues are raised, as appropriate, in multilateral (WTO/GATT) and regional (APEC) forums. They are also addressed at annual bilateral officials meetings and during ministerial visits.

As part of Australia's Uruguay Round settlement with Japan, annual bilateral consultations on Japanese dairy quota imports for skim milk powder and butter will be held which will enable Australia to raise any concerns over the administration of dairy imports.

With respect to rice imports, the Australian Government has made representations to the Japanese Government regarding the administration and management of imports. Australia is seeking to ensure that Japan's rice imports under its Uruguay Round commitments are as open and transparent as possible.
(i) Korea

Australia, with the United States and New Zealand, is seeking, cooperatively with the Korean Government, to develop strategies for facilitating the transition of the Korean beef industry. Specifically, Australia is seeking the removal of restrictions on access to the wholesale market for grassfed beef and the shelf life restrictions for chilled beef, increased competition among importer groups, improved transparency in the import and distribution market and a restructuring of the Korean beef industry to enable viable sections to compete in a liberalised environment.

Australia is pursuing these agricultural concerns, including on quarantine issues, through the annual ministerial trade talks: the Australia Korea Joint Economic Committee and Foreign Ministry senior officials talks. In addition, regular plant quarantine talks have been established (August 1994) and there are current discussions on the establishment of regular animal quarantine talks.
(j) Malaysia

We have made bilateral representations contending that infant yoghurt should fall under an infant food tariff classification, which would make the product subject to a lower tariff. The issue will be raised again during the March Joint Trade Committee.
(k) New Zealand
There are currently negotiations on the mutual recognition of regulations governing goods and occupations and on harmonisation of food standards.
(l) Papua New Guinea

Representations have been made to the PNG Government over its introduction of quantitative restrictions on beef imports in November 1994. We will continue to pursue these concerns bilaterally and in the multilateral/bilateral negotiation of PNG's WTO schedule.
(m) Philippines

Our concerns over quarantine prohibitions on fresh fruit and vegetables have been pursued by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) and raised in the Australia-Philippines Joint Commission.
(n) Singapore
There are no major tariff or non-tariff barriers to Australian agricultural exports.
(o) Thailand
Thailand has prepared a draft Specific Commodity Understanding (SCU) for the import of Australian citrus into Thailand. The SCU is expected to be finalised over coming months.
(p) Vietnam
In January 1995 Vietnam applied to join the GATT. No date has yet been set for the accession negotiation process to begin.

(3) Most countries have yet to notify the details of how they intend to implement their Uruguay Round obligations on agriculture, including in particular the administration of the tariff quotas opened as a result of tariffication. At this stage we know of no instance where a signatory will be unable to fulfil its obligations under the Uruguay Round Agriculture Agreement. However, Australia expects all signatories to honour their commitments and will be closely monitoring the details of import regimes for agricultural products to determine both their GATT/WTO consistency and the intent of the Round to liberalise agricultural trade.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force: Equipment and Supply Contracts

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which contracts have been let to companies sited in New Zealand to supply, service or overhaul equipment and/or supplies for the Australian Defence Forces.
(2) Please list the nature and purpose of each contract and the duration of each contract.

(3)(a) What is the value of each contract, (b) are they fixed price or are they variable, (c) if they are variable tender prices, under what conditions can the price be increased; and (d) are there any incentives for the companies concerned to perform at a lower contract price.
(4) What procedures have been instituted to maintain the skills, capabilities and capacity of Australian industry in existence for those tasks transferred offshore.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Details regarding Defence contracts awarded to New Zealand companies for the supply, service or overhaul of equipment and/or supplies to the ADF are contained in the attached report. This report identifies all contracts awarded since (and including) the 92/93 financial year.

As a summary, in FY 94-95 to date, 45 contracts have been awarded to 8 New Zealand companies totalling $13.02 million. Comparative figures for the previous two years are: FY 93-94, 57 contracts were awarded to 9 New Zealand companies totalling $9.87 million; and FY 92-93, 68 contracts were awarded to 10 New Zealand companies totalling $6.26 million.
(2) The nature and purpose of each contract is shown in the report. However, it would require inordinate departmental resources to provide details regarding the duration of each contract.

(3) The answer to the question regarding value can be found in the report. The other questions regarding whether these contracts were awarded on a firm or variable price basis, or what incentives, if any, were employed, is difficult to answer primarily because these contracts were awarded by discrete acquisition units within all Programs in Defence and the act of reconciling individual purchases represents an inefficient and inappropriate use of Departmental resources. However, current Defence policy requires that the price basis for contracts of less than two years duration must be firm unless extenuating circumstances prevail.

(4) The Government does not consider contracts awarded to New Zealand companies as going offshore. As a signatory to the National Preference Agreement and the Australia/New Zealand Closer Economic Relations—Trade Agreement, New Zealand suppliers are afforded the same opportunities to bid for Australian business. As stated in Defence White Paper, "Defending Australia 1994", New Zealand and Australian industry are con

ANSWER.PARA: sidered as a single defence industrial base. Indeed the reciprocal nature of the Agreements frequently results in Australian business bidding for, and being awarded, contracts with the New Zealand Government.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth procurement policy document regarding this matter is the Department of Administrative Services Procurement Guideline No 12, Australian and New Zealand Suppliers.

Any other instances where skills, capabilities and capacity of Australian industry are transferred offshore would only occur if the requirement was not cost effective to maintain and there had been a rigorous examination of the impact of such a move on the overall supportability of the ADF.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 9 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that AMCO Victoria Pty Ltd, an Australian manufacturer of backhoe loaders, recently objected to the granting of a number of tariff concession orders, which applications were refused on account of AMCO's local manufacture of substitutable goods and because AMCO's market would be severely affected by any concession, and given that these refusals were appealed by the applicants, and the refusals were upheld for the same reasons.

(1) Why, when this decision was then appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal did the Australian Customs Service, prior to the hearing, decide to withdraw from the case and grant the tariff concession orders.
(2) Is the Minister aware of the damage done to AMCO, an Australian manufacturer, by this decision.
(3) Will the Minister take action to reverse this decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: When a matter goes before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (the AAT), a fact finding Tribunal, cogent evidence must be adduced to support claims made by the parties. Customs is mindful of the time and cost burden such proceedings impose on parties, and the community, and will not pursue matters if prospects of success are judged to be poor.

ANSWER.PARA: Customs had extensive discussion with Mr Stuckey and other interested parties, (during which a prototype of an incomplete backhoe loader was inspected) and formed the view that there was no evidence to support claims by Mr Stuckey that at the relevant date, ie 28 days before the date of the Tariff Concession Order (TCO) application, substitutable goods were produced in Australia in the ordinary course of business. All parties to the dispute, including AMCO Victoria Pty Ltd, agreed with this assessment and all parties signed a consent agreement pursuant to S 42C of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. The AAT later made a decision finalising the matter in terms of that consent agreement.

PARA.TAB: I am well aware of AMCO's concerns about the granting of TCO's impacting on its business. However, I note that all parties agreed that there was no evidence to support claims that substitutable goods were produced in Australia in the ordinary course of business at the relevant date. You should be aware that the operation of the Tariff Concession System currently is being evaluated and a report is due to me in June 1995. Among the matters being looked at are claims that the interests of local producers are not being adequately protected under the current scheme.

The law does not permit me, as Minister, to "reverse" a decision made by the Comptroller-General in relation to a TCO. Should a party be aggrieved about a decision, it may first seek internal review by Customs of the decision pursuant to s269SH of the Act and if not satisfied with the internal review decision then seek review by the AAT.

ANSWER.PARA: Following revocation requests by Mr Stuckey for the 4 TCO's at issue, Customs revoked them in December 1994. The revocation action was based on evidence provided by Mr Stuckey about his changed production and sales situation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 1 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Australia's participation in the Fourth United Nations World Conference on Women and the NGO Forum 95 in Beijing later in 1995 please advise:
(1) How many people will make up each of the Australian delegations to the conferences.
(2) What are the criteria the Government will use to determine the composition of each of the delegations.
(3) What representation is intended from Government, Opposition and minor parties and non-government groups.
(4) What criteria will apply to allow delegates the right to speak from the floor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) a) The Fourth World Conference on Women (Beijing, September 1995) is a United Nations meeting of Member States (ie Governments). The composition and size of the Australian delegation is yet to be decided. The number of delegates is usually governed by the need to ensure appropriate expertise balanced with the need for efficient co-ordination within the delegation. As an indication of the possible size of the delegation, Australian delegations to recent United Nations conferences (the World Summit for Social Development, the International Conference on Population and Development and the Conference on Environment and Development) consisted of around 30 members.

b) Forum 95 is a meeting of non-governmental organisations (NGO) and individuals. It is open to all who wish to register, subject to the rules of the NGO Secretariat. Accordingly, there will not be a Government delegation to Forum 95. At this stage, it is expected that around 50 Australian NGOs will attend Forum 95.

(2) Australian delegations for United Nations intergovermental conferences usually comprise a Ministerial Head of the Delegation and public servants responsible to the Government. The inclusion of NGOs and others is considered on a case by case basis. An important consideration in selecting delegates for the Fourth World Conference on Women will be their ability to contribute to the work of the delegation and to represent Australian Government policy. All delegates are subject to the direction of the Head of the Delegation and must adhere to the Government policies on issues under consideration. To this end, delegates to the recent International Conference on Population and Development signed a letter that bound the entire delegation to present a single position. While the Government recognises the desirability of sending a representative delegation, this must be balanced against efficiency considerations. Selection will be based on a balance of expertise, efficiency and representativeness.

(3) The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Dr Lawrence, will lead the delegation to the Fourth World Conference on Women. The Government will consider requests from a wide range of parties, including NGOs, to join the delegation subject to the points made at (2) above.

ANSWER.PARA: All non-Government delegates are expected to meet travel and accommodation costs.

PARA.TAB: (4) The proposed criteria governing delegates' right to speak at the official Conference is set out in the United Nations Draft Provisional Rules of Procedure of the Conference. The rules of procedure will be settled at the 39th session of the Commission on the Status of Women (CSW39) which is the preparatory body for the Fourth World Conference on Women. CSW is meeting in New York from 15 March to 4 April 1995.

The Head of the Delegation will determine which members may speak from the floor on behalf of the delegation. All statements will reflect Australian Government policy and will be subject to clearance procedures determined by the Government.

According to the draft rules of procedure, accredited NGOs can attend the Fourth World Conference as observers, without the right to vote. NGOs may have the opportunity to address the Conference briefly in plenary meetings and in meetings of subsidiary bodies at the discretion of the presiding officer and with the consent of the appropriate body of the Conference.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has any significant new technical or scientific information emerged since the conclusion of the inquiry into continued use of organochlorine insecticides for termite control by the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA) which would support the South Australian Government's submission to the Agriculture and Resource Management Council for an exemption from the mid-1995 ban on the use of organochlorine insecticides, if so, what is this scientific and/or technical information and will it be tabled.

(2) Did the Standing Committee on Agricultural and Resource Management at its meeting on 20-21 February 1995 support the South Australian Department of Primary Industries' submission to be exempted from the 30 June 1995 ban on the use of organochlorines; if not, what technical or scientific information or advice would be available to Commonwealth and State Primary Industries who would want to support the South Australian submission at the approaching Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand on 3 March 1995.

(3) Has the Housing Industry Association asked that the NRA approve handspraying of the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos for the protection of slab on ground construction or else that the Commonwealth and State agricultural ministers should defer the ban on organochlorines at their 3 March 1995 meeting in Canberra, for a period of one to two years; if so, what new peer reviewed independent publishing research has become available since the 1990 publication of the CSIRO's Dr Michael Lenz et.al, into the effectiveness of insecticidal soil barriers against termites which would support an application for handspraying of chlorpyrifos for the protection of slab on ground pre-construction.

(4) On how many occasions have State regulatory authorities rejected company applications for the use of chlorpyrifos for the protection of slab on ground buildings under construction on the basis of the above CSIRO research into the effectiveness of insecticidal soil barriers against termites.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)&(2) The Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) at its meeting on 3 March 1995 confirmed its position on banning organochlorines from use for termite control in the State/Territories, other than in the Northern Territory, by 30 June 1995.

ARMCANZ also agreed to request the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA) to obtain results of degradation and efficacy studies of chlorpyrifos at termiticidal levels in representative Adelaide soils, and report back to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Policy Committee. The NRA was also requested to fast-track current applications or applications received before 30 June 1997 for alternate chemical termiticides.
(3) The Housing Industry Association has not made an application to the NRA for hand spraying

ANSWER.PARA: of chlorpyrifos. To my knowledge no additional research has been published on this matter.

PARA.TAB: (4) It is appropriate that concerns about State determined applications relating to chlorpyrifos be raised directly with the State regulatory authorities.
